The agent allegedly sent unsolicited telemarketing messages to Singapore registered numbers, advertising residential property developments. The agent will be charged in the State Courts on September 24 and faces up to 27 counts of contravening Section 43(1) of the PDPA. This marks the commission's latest enforcement action against organisations in the real estate sector, with over 3,500 complaints investigated since the DNC provisions took effect in January 2014.

site_title: Malaysian tigers chase S'pore lions in yuan race
summary: Malaysian and Singapore governments are competing for a share of bond issuance in the Chinese yuan market. Malaysian tigers (Cagamas Bhd) and Singapore lions (Lion City debentures) have joined Formosa bonds in Taiwan, but Hong Kong remains dominant with its early mover advantage in opening trade and investment in the yuan. Singapore's position as a regional private banking hub and Malaysia's Islamic finance centre will bring new investors, but Hong Kong's yuan deposits are approaching one trillion yuan, giving it a significant lead.

site_title: OEL in MOU to buy oil & gas stake
summary: OEL Holdings, a CATALIST-listed company, has entered into a non-binding MOU to buy a 60-100% stake in Hong Kong firm Allied Resources for S$22.5-37.5 million. Allied Resources is involved with PetroChina in developing two oilfields in China's Jilin province. The deal could involve issuing shares at 9.5 Singapore cents each. This investment aims to reduce OEL's losses, which currently come from property rental and ship repair.

site_title: Keppel Reit rating not affected by MBFC buy: S&P
summary: Standard & Poor's (S&P) has confirmed that Keppel Reit's BBB credit rating remains unchanged despite its proposed acquisition of a one-third stake in Marina Bay Financial Centre (MBFC) Tower 3 for S$1.2 billion. The acquisition is expected to enhance Keppel Reit's portfolio and improve its financial strength, but may increase asset concentration in the central business district. The rating agency considers Keppel Reit's financial health metrics, including interest coverage and leverage ratios, to be above thresholds for downgrading.

site_title: Cosco counts on fuel-efficient ships to cut costs, revive profits
summary: China Cosco Holdings Co plans to cut costs by adding fuel-efficient vessels to revive profits amid a capacity glut. The company ordered five fuel-efficient container transports that can carry 14,500 twenty-foot boxes. This move aims to reduce fuel spending by 18% and boost efficiency. Despite efforts, Cosco faces increasing cost pressure due to overcapacity concerns in the industry. Reducing costs is the most realistic strategy for the company, according to Guo Huawei, board secretary, as the market recovery is uncertain.

site_title: CPI hits 6-mth low in August but core inflation still firm
summary: Singapore's consumer price inflation dropped to a 6-month low of 0.9% in August, beating expectations. However, core inflation, which excludes accommodation and private road transport costs, remained firm at 2.1%, suggesting underlying inflationary pressures. Economists believe the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will not relax monetary policy stance in October, citing core inflation as the more significant concern. Experts expect headline inflation to remain subdued for the rest of the year, with some predicting a further cut in MAS's inflation forecast.

site_title: Emirates plans big expansion in US
summary: Emirates Airline plans a significant expansion in the US market, aiming to make it one of its three largest revenue sources. The airline currently generates 7% of its sales from the US, but is scouting new cities to add to its network after starting service in Chicago. Emirates has ordered 260 long-range aircraft to aid its expansion and has dismissed criticism that it enjoys an unfair advantage due to government subsidies. The airline's president, Tim Clark, stated that any subsidies are due to government investment in Dubai's airport infrastructure.

site_title: Identity politics afflicts many nations
summary: The UK's rejection of Scottish independence has shifted the debate to devolution, with Prime Minister David Cameron proposing power transfer to English, Welsh, and Northern Irish regions. This trend is seen globally, with identity politics affecting Spain, Italy, the US, and Eastern Europe, where separatist movements and civil wars are on the rise. China faces similar issues with Tibetan and Uighur identities, while the Philippines is considering a law to establish a new Bangsamoro entity. The article concludes that peaceful democratic resolution is rare in these independence movements, with many becoming "running sores" on their countries' politics.

site_title: Nakheel may follow Emaar unit's IPO lead
summary: Dubai's palm island developer Nakheel may consider listing its shares on the emirate's stock market following the successful share sale by Emaar Properties' malls unit, which could raise up to US$1.58 billion. Nakheel's CEO Sanjay Manchanda stated that the success of Emaar's IPO is an encouraging sign for the company, and it may explore this option to raise funds. The company has repaid its outstanding debt four years ahead of schedule and is shifting its strategy to improve recurring income through retail and hospitality sectors.

site_title: China's jet fuel exports hit record high in August
summary: China exported a record 1.01 million tonnes of jet fuel in August, a 260,000 barrels per day increase, according to customs data. This surge in jet fuel exports follows a rise in production by Chinese refineries, which have been boosted by higher profit margins. Petrol exports also reached a year-high of 487,380 tonnes, while diesel shipments gained 21% from July. The increase in jet fuel exports is attributed to refineries' shift in production focus from diesel to jet fuel, driven by better profit margins.

site_title: StockFacts a commendable effort by SGX
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has launched a free online initiative called StockFacts, providing valuable market information to ordinary investors. The platform allows users to screen for promising stocks in the same sector or industry, with customizable parameters such as revenue, price to earnings ratio, and dividend yield. While StockFacts has limitations, including the inability to screen for more than five parameters and lack of a watchlist feature, it is a commendable effort to support retail investors. The launch comes at a time when retail investors are being wooed back into the market following a lacklustre year, offering a new cause for cheer.

site_title: Investors should take on more risk
summary: JP Morgan Asset Management's portfolio manager Talib Sheikh advises investors to take on more risk in their portfolios, citing low return expectations from global equities. Despite a recent rally, investors are still holding too much cash and waiting for dips to buy, missing out on gains. Sheikh expects single-digit returns in developed markets over the next one to two years, driven by earnings growth rather than multiple expansion. He advises investors to be cautious but still invest in equities, as they offer a decent place to be in, even at all-time highs.

site_title: Boeing to set up cyber analytics centre in S'pore
summary: Boeing is launching its first Cyber Analytics Centre outside the US in Singapore, set to open in the first quarter of 2025. The centre will address cybersecurity challenges in the Asia-Pacific region, employing and training cybersecurity professionals. It will offer advanced cybersecurity capabilities and services to clients, as well as serve as a regional centre of excellence. The centre aims to address growing cybersecurity risks in the region and demonstrate Boeing's and Singapore's commitment to addressing cyber threats.

site_title: Citimac complex seeks S$1,350 psf ppr in en bloc sale
summary: The owners of Citimac Industrial Complex in Singapore have launched an en bloc sale with a minimum price of S$550 million, equivalent to S$1,350 per square foot of potential gross floor area. The site, zoned for Business 1-White use, has a maximum gross floor area of 489,261 sq ft and is located near Tai Seng MRT Station. Market watchers have expressed skepticism about the ambitious pricing, citing comparable sales of nearby industrial sites at lower prices.

site_title: S'pore pivot in Mizuho Bank's Asia expansion
summary: Japan's Mizuho Bank plans to boost its staff strength in Singapore by about 50% over the next few years as part of its Asia expansion strategy. The bank, one of Japan's three mega banks, has a 40-year presence in Singapore and has increased its total assets to US$37 billion from US$8 billion over the past decade. Mizuho aims to increase profit from the region to 30-35% within two years, with Singapore playing a pivotal role in its offerings and opening up more branches. The bank has already opened new branches in Chennai, Bangalore, and Kuala Lumpur, and plans to open a new branch in Thailand.

site_title: At US$25b, Alibaba IPO becomes the world's largest
summary: Alibaba Group Holding's initial public offering (IPO) became the world's largest at US$25 billion, after bankers exercised a 15% boost in deal size due to strong demand. The offering was managed by major banks and saw shares soar 38% on their debut, the biggest first-day jump for an IPO of at least US$10 billion. Interest from prominent money managers, including Fidelity Investments and BlackRock, further fueled the success of the IPO.

site_title: Rate hike fears overdone, again: Amundi CIO
summary: Asset manager Amundi's Pascal Blanque says fears of an interest rate hike are overdone due to stagnant economic growth in the West and excess liquidity in Europe and Japan. This will lead to continued low rates and higher asset prices. Blanque notes that a low-growth world means lower returns and investors must adjust their expectations. He also supports the "secular stagnation" thesis, citing permanently slower growth in the West due to an ageing population and glut of savings.

site_title: London apartments reach £5,000 psf
summary: British Land Co sold 18 luxury apartments in London's Mayfair for an average price of £4,750 per square foot (psf), breaking the previous record of £5,000 psf in 2013. The total sale price was £210 million, with over £5,000 psf paid for some units. The sale follows a five-year rally in London's luxury home market, with prices now 38% above their previous peak. The development is close to the former In and Out Club, where billionaire investors are likely to build the UK's most expensive home.

site_title: Temasek takes on sustainability challenge
summary: Temasek Holdings, a Singapore government-owned investment company, is addressing the issue of sustainability in its long-term investments. Chairman Lim Boon Heng emphasized the importance of considering the environment and promoting good governance, citing the company's 40th anniversary as a milestone. Temasek has organized an "Ecosperity" conference and is in talks with the JTC Corp regarding a potential merger, highlighting its commitment to sustainable growth. The company's focus on sustainability extends beyond environmental concerns, also encompassing financial, organizational, and social aspects.

site_title: Keeping personal data personal
summary: The Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA) in Singapore has had a positive impact on the country's economic competitiveness and reputation as a trusted hub for businesses. Companies such as International SOS, Singapore Power, and Criteo have implemented stringent data protection measures, with minimal cost and burden. The PDPA has encouraged businesses to establish trusted relationships with customers, with Singapore Power reviewing processes to comply with the Act. Experts, including Imperva and Bosch, support the PDPA, citing its benefits for data security and privacy. The Act has also boosted Singapore's position as a global business hub, with companies such as Kelly Services and Adecco Asia adapting to its requirements.

site_title: Corrections
summary: A correction has been issued by The Straits Times regarding a previous article, where it was incorrectly attributed to director Ong Boon Chuan that he purchased 34.97 million Edition Ltd shares. The shares are actually held by his wife, Kok Lee Kuen, a substantial shareholder, with an increase of 9.39 percentage points to 61.75% of the shares. The Straits Times apologizes for the error and any confusion caused.

site_title: LVMH's private-equity arm on the prowl in S-E Asia
summary: L Capital Asia, the private-equity arm of luxury goods maker LVMH, is seeking investments in Singapore's food and beverage, entertainment, and beauty-care industries. The firm sees opportunities due to the city's large expatriate population and tourist flows. L Capital Asia also eyes tourism and hospitality deals in Thailand and Vietnam. This move comes as consumer spending in the region is expected to rise. The firm's regional managing director, Sanjay Gujral, believes the investments will help L Capital Asia capitalize on the growth.

site_title: Keppel Land sells 80% stake in Surabaya mall
summary: Keppel Land sold its 80% stake in Surabaya mall, BG Junction, to Silverise Enterprise and PT Pelangi Arjuno for S$42.8 million. The sale is expected to yield an after-tax profit of about S$12.5 million for KepLand. The mall, with a 95% occupancy rate, features anchor tenants like Carrefour and Cahaya Departmental Store. The transaction is expected to be completed by the end of this year, and Indonesia remains a key growth market for Keppel Land.

site_title: JetBlue to impose fee for first checked bag
summary: JetBlue Airways is introducing a fee for checking the first bag, a departure from its previous policy, as part of its efforts to boost revenue under new CEO Robin Hayes, who will succeed Dave Barger on February 16. The move is seen as a shift towards more investor-friendly changes, with analysts expecting Hayes to focus on increasing revenue and reducing debt. The airline's stock has lagged behind the industry average during Barger's seven-year tenure, and the fee change is part of a broader effort to improve JetBlue's financial performance.

site_title: Peter Lim joins Man U old boys in Salford City
summary: Singapore businessman Peter Lim has joined five former Manchester United players as shareholders of Salford City FC, a club playing in the eighth tier of the English league system. Lim holds a half-stake, while Gary and Phil Neville, Ryan Giggs, Paul Scholes, and Nicky Butt share the remaining 50%. The club aims to develop local talent and eventually reach the Football League.

site_title: Oxley unit signs deal on Myanmar project
summary: Oxley Holdings' subsidiary, Oxley Myanmar, has signed an agreement to build a 20-storey commercial and residential development, Min Residence, in Mayangon Township, northern Yangon, Myanmar. The project, expected to last three years, will be built on a 3,185-acre plot of land owned by U Yang Ho. Oxley will pay for construction costs and split profits evenly with the land owner after deducting expenses, with a potential shortfall to be split equally between the parties if the project is not profitable.

site_title: Singapore bond market posting strong 2014 growth
summary: Singapore's bond market experienced strong growth in 2014, with Singapore-domiciled firms issuing US$19.7 billion in bonds, a 22.6% increase from the first nine months of 2013. The third quarter saw US$7.9 billion raised, a 23% increase from the second quarter and 60.3% higher than the same period last year. DBS Group Holdings led the market with US$4.3 billion in proceeds, followed by foreign issuers tapping the Singapore-dollar market with S$18.9 billion in proceeds, a 39% increase from 2013.

site_title: SGX sees end to Chinese IPO hiatus
summary: SGX expects Chinese companies to list on the exchange for the first time in two years, following a deal with the China Securities Regulatory Commission. The arrangement allows mainland companies to list directly in Singapore without an overseas holding company. This marks a significant development for SGX, which has been eyeing Chinese companies for a long time. Initial listings are expected next year, with the last one being Sincap Group Ltd in June 2012.

site_title: Can-do spirit helps non-grad mark 35 years in DBS
summary: Amy Low, a non-graduate, has marked 35 years with DBS Bank, rising from a clerical assistant to vice-president of trade services, technology & operations, leading a team of 49 people. At 57, she defies stereotypes of bank employees being graduates with a penchant for job hopping. Low's perseverance and adaptability have enabled her to excel in the industry, making her a rare example of a non-graduate achieving seniority at DBS.

site_title: FOC fires up the tapas bar scene
summary: FOC, a new restaurant in Singapore, has elevated the tapas bar scene with a substantial menu and creative cocktails. Located at 40 Hong Kong Street, FOC offers a unique dining experience. The restaurant's focus on substance and fun sets it apart from other establishments in the city.

site_title: Danger lurks when property consultants also trade
summary: Property consultants may be tempted to invest in real estate, but it's essential to remain detached. Knight Frank Singapore's executive chairman, Tan Tiong Cheng, advises against taking positions, as it creates conflict of interest and clouds judgment. He attributes Singapore's high property interest to the government's encouragement of home ownership, which can lead to excessive preoccupation. His key advice is to ensure there's a pool of similar-minded buyers, allowing for easy offloading if the property isn't the buyer's dream home. This helps maintain objectivity and avoids potential pitfalls.

site_title: CapitaLand's Iskandar township project hits snag
summary: CapitaLand's Iskandar township project in Malaysia has hit a snag, seeking a 6-month extension on the launch of its first phase, a $3.2 billion waterfront condominium project. The delay is attributed to a lack of key approval from the Johor state authorities, despite being a high-profile project with significant Singapore-Malaysia ties. The project's delay may be linked to strained relations between the project's developer, Lim Kang Hoo, and the Johor state government, which could impact the project's success and the overall Iskandar real estate market.

site_title: US logistics firm to build Gulf Coast oil hub
summary: Kinder Morgan Energy Partners plans to invest $1.5 billion in Houston to build a flexible oil and fuel transport hub, capitalizing on the US shale boom and growing domestic and Canadian crude imports. The project includes storage, pipeline connections, and a wider export platform, aiming to secure Kinder's central position in moving oil from the US to market. The investment responds to the dynamic world of physical crude trading in North America, where refiners need multiple options to switch delivery modes and snag the best price.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: Wee Hur Holdings' subsidiary won a S$157.7 million HDB project, bringing its order book to S$404.9 million. Tritech Group secured an S$13.795 million contract with the LTA for construction supervision services. CNA Group's investment platform debuted on the Australian Stock Exchange, with a market capitalisation of A$152 million. Rex International's shareholding structure changed after a private placement exercise, and Trek 2000 International is discussing tech commercialisation opportunities with potential partners.

site_title: Sime is 'preferred bidder' for 49% stake in NBPOL
summary: Malaysian multinational Sime Darby is the "preferred bidder" for a 49% stake in Papua New Guinea-based New Britain Palm Oil Ltd (NBPOL), with a 60-day deadline to finalize the terms of the transaction. However, Felda Global Ventures (FGV) remains interested in the firm, and officials say another bidder could emerge during the 60-day period. NBPOL is a profitable plantation firm with 77,000 hectares of oil palm plantations and is listed on the London stock exchange, valued at £657 million. The firm's yields are superior to Malaysian plantations, averaging 26-27 tonnes per hectare.

site_title: Mass appeal
summary: Chefs in Singapore are shifting towards smart casual eateries as an affordable alternative to fine dining restaurants. Gourmet food can be successfully sold in humble fare like sandwiches, hot dogs, and burgers, offering a creative outlet for chefs. Trendy eateries like db Bistro Moderne, Park Bench Deli, and Bazuka Yakibuta are sprouting up, applying artistry to simple dishes. This trend allows chefs to reach a wider audience, reducing operating costs, and providing foodies with an opportunity to experience gastronomic creations.

site_title: Swapping scalpels for clubs
summary: A team of doctors from Mount Elizabeth Hospitals in Singapore participated in a golf tournament, swapping medical procedures for clubs. The team, led by CEO Dr Kelvin Loh, enjoyed the experience, bonding with other players and playing on premier golf courses. The team's strategy for the final round was to relax and enjoy themselves, leading to improved golf scores. This unique event allowed doctors to connect with each other and have fun outside of their medical work.

site_title: Maersk turns to China on alliance plan
summary: Maersk Line, the world's largest container shipping firm, has met with Chinese authorities to discuss its planned vessel-sharing alliance with MSC. The new pact, called 2M, aims to reduce costs and has a lower capacity share than a previous agreement that was blocked due to competition concerns. Maersk's CEO, Soren Skou, met with Chinese officials, including the director-general of the anti-monopoly bureau, to address concerns about the alliance's impact on China's import-export firms. The US regulatory approval for the 2M service is pending.

site_title: Seb, SIA and the Singapore GP
summary: Sebastian Vettel, the 2013 F1 World Champion, is no longer leading the championship. This year's Singapore Grand Prix has a new title sponsor and a new championship leader, marking a significant change from last year when Vettel was on the cusp of a record nine-race winning streak. Vettel's winless start to the 2014 season has led to him falling behind his rookie teammate, who has secured three podiums.

site_title: SingPost delivers a new business
summary: SingPost is transforming itself from a government monopoly into a competitive regional e-commerce power house. The company is building an end-to-end e-commerce platform through its unit Quantium Solutions, leveraging its strengths to develop a new "wing" in regional e-commerce logistics. SingPost has invested in enhancing its postal infrastructure, developing a low-cost e-commerce logistics delivery model, and a strong e-commerce technology platform. The company aims to focus on enabling a regional set-up, allowing brands to leverage implementation and operations costs across multiple countries.

site_title: Falling yen not an issue at G20 meeting
summary: The Japanese yen's sharp decline against the dollar and other major currencies at the G20 finance ministers and central bank governors meeting in Cairns, Australia, sparked little controversy. Experts predict further falls, with Rei Masunaga and Eisuke Sakakibara forecasting the yen could drop below 110 to the US dollar. Despite the yen's drop, currency issues received little attention at the meeting, which focused on finding ways to restore global economic growth.

site_title: The loyal supporter
summary: Team Emerio, a four-year participant in the league, expresses gratitude for the event's camaraderie and challenging courses. Team captain Harish Nim praises his teammate Sreerangan Kurup for being the most consistent player this year. The team has benefited from playing at each course before the actual game, allowing them to compete more effectively. With a goal to double the number of participating teams, Harish Nim commends the event's management and encourages more companies to join.

images.alt_text: GETTING PUMPED UP(From left) Team Emerio's Manish Mahajan, Sreerangan Kurup, Harish Nim, Winston Baptista
GETTING PUMPED UP(From left) Team Emerio's Manish Mahajan, Sreerangan Kurup, Harish Nim, Winston Baptista

site_title: Dow looks set to scale new highs this week
summary: The Dow Jones is expected to scale new highs this week as a combination of factors, including the Federal Reserve's rate hike policy, the strength of the US dollar, and a surge in mergers and acquisitions deals, support the market. The Fed's shift away from extraordinary stimulus to a rate-hiking policy has boosted bank stocks, while the deal market has seen a surge in activity, with Alibaba's IPO being a notable example. Economists expect a rate hike in mid-2015, but the market is already responding to the Fed's intentions, with mortgage rates and M&A deals on the rise.

site_title: Buying remains high, selling flat
summary: Singapore Exchange filings show buying activity remained high for the fourth consecutive week, with 46 purchases worth S$20.6 million, while selling activity remained flat. Nine companies repurchased shares worth S$11.3 million. Notable trades included Ban Leong Technologies' S$20,000 share purchase, 800 Super Holdings' S$100,000 share buy, and UOL Group's S$6.41 average share purchase price. The corporate shareholder sentiment was mixed, with Venstar Investments Ltd selling 2.3 million shares, and Tee Wee Sien increasing his stake in Oxley Holdings.

site_title: Attendance down slightly at this year's F1 Singapore race
summary: The 2014 Formula 1 Singapore Grand Prix saw an attendance of 84,454, slightly lower than the previous year's 87,500, but still the third highest since the event's inception in 2008. The event, sponsored by Singapore Airlines, attracted 40% of overseas fans, with die-hard supporters coming from Australia, the UK, and Germany. Despite lessons learned from this year's event, organizers are already releasing tickets for the 2015 Singapore Grand Prix, which marks 50 years of independence for Singapore.

site_title: Formula for speed
summary: A recent article discusses various global news topics. The US reported a drop in weekly jobless claims, while China unveiled new employment aid steps amid trade tensions. Chinese property shares surged on unverified reports of a meeting to revive the sector. Reliance Jio, backed by Ambani, has delayed its India IPO beyond this year. Meanwhile, China urged South-east Asian nations to support openness as US tariffs loom. These events highlight the ongoing impact of global trade tensions and economic shifts.

site_title: SGX starts StockFacts portal to win investors
summary: SGX has launched StockFacts, a new online stock information portal aimed at retail investors. The platform allows users to screen for stocks based on 20 criteria, including market capitalization and revenue, and incorporates data from S&P Capital IQ. The move is part of SGX's efforts to drive up retail participation, following a 26% growth in new clearing accounts and a 5% drop in net profit to S$320.4 million in the year ended June 2014. The platform is part of SGX's goal to "educate, engage and enable" retail investors, responding to growing interest in stock investing and retirement planning.

site_title: Correction
summary: A Singaporean property developer has corrected an error in a previous article, stating that the booking dates for Bellewoods and Bellewaters are actually from Oct 15 to Nov 2, not Nov 1. The correction was made to the article "Five new ECs break 9-month dry spell" published on Sept 20, 2014.

site_title: More Singaporeans turn to virtual stores for shopping
summary: Singaporeans are increasingly opting for online shopping, with revenues predicted to reach S$4.4 billion by next year. According to research, Singapore was the largest e-commerce market in South-east Asia last year, generating US$1.7 billion in sales. Online shopping is expected to account for 30% more of total spending by 2020, with mobile e-commerce revenues anticipated to reach S$3.1 billion. Rising internet penetration, smartphone adoption, and an affluent middle class are driving the growth in e-commerce sales.

site_title: Enter the social enterprise
summary: A recent SID Directors' Conference highlighted the potential of social enterprises in the emerging world of new capitalism. Social enterprises combine business and social mission, creating external, internal, or redistributing social impact through various means. The conference saw 95% of attendees express interest in learning more about social enterprises, with 66% wanting to start working with them. Companies can engage with social enterprises through volunteering, investing, or integrating them into corporate social responsibility programs, with DBS Bank serving as an example of extensive social enterprise involvement.

site_title: Hot chase on a hazy night
summary: Lewis Hamilton secured his seventh win of the season at the 2014 Singapore Grand Prix, taking the lead in the Formula One world championship. Nico Rosberg, Hamilton's teammate, failed to finish the race, allowing Hamilton to overtake him. Daniel Ricciardo is the only other driver to have won this season. The race took place on a hot and humid night at the Marina Bay Street Circuit.

site_title: Alibaba surges past US$90 in debut trading
summary: Alibaba Group Holding's shares surged 46% on their first day of trading, reaching a value of $244 billion. The company's initial public offering raised over $8.2 billion for the company and $13 billion for major shareholders. The IPO is expected to fund Alibaba's expansion in the US and elsewhere, marking one of the largest IPOs in history.

site_title: Deal-buying sites enter new era of e-commerce
summary: Deal-buying sites, which gained popularity after Groupon's acquisition of a local site, are shifting towards e-commerce with a wider selection of goods and services. Four years after their peak, most sites have folded, while the ones that survived are adapting to a new model, focusing on travel, cosmetic services, and general product deals. Online marketplaces like Qoo10 and Taobao are also gaining ground, with Qoo10 remaining unfazed despite growing competition. Experts note that transforming from a deal-buying site to an e-commerce site requires significant changes, including logistical networks and customer experience.

site_title: Staying relevant amid changes
summary: Knight Frank Singapore is preparing for succession planning by grooming a team of experienced younger professionals to take over the company in the next few years. The team includes Low Kin Hon, Ian Loh, Png Poh Soon, Tan Tee Khoon, and Margaret Ang, who collectively have over 60 years of experience in the property consultancy industry. This move aims to ensure the company remains relevant in a rapidly evolving industry, with group managing director Danny Yeo stating that the top priority is to have a group of experienced and energetic younger professionals ready to lead the firm.

site_title: Know your heart specialist
summary: A study examining the impact of heart specialists' experience on the outcomes of percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) procedures found that death and complication rates decreased significantly with increasing annual procedural volume. Specialists performing more than 100 PCIs per year had significantly lower death and complication rates compared to those performing fewer than 50 PCIs per year. The American cardiology organizations have recommended a minimum competence requirement of 50 PCIs per year for heart specialists performing PCI, but many specialists still do not meet this standard, increasing the risk of complications and mortality.

images.alt_text: STENT OPTIONS Although conventional stents are less costly, there is a need for life-long consumption of blood-thinning medication. The new generation of stents are more expensive but, after an initial period, blood-thinning medication can be discontinued. - FILE PHOTO

site_title: Bank of China to clear SGX derivatives
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has partnered with the Bank of China (BOC), making BOC the first Chinese settlement bank for the SGX derivatives market. Three new Asian foreign exchange futures contracts will be added to the market, including Chinese RMB, Japanese yen, and Thai baht, available for trading from October 20. This partnership strengthens Singapore's position as an offshore renminbi hub, enhancing the country's attractiveness to investors and traders.

site_title: Sharper, spicier Cayenne
summary: The Porsche Cayenne has undergone a mid-life makeover with a new, more efficient engine, resulting in increased fuel efficiency. The redesign improves the exterior dimensions with new LED lights, bonnet, and front fenders, while the interior features a new steering wheel and more standard equipment. Five versions are available, including the Cayenne S E-Hybrid, which boasts improved fuel economy and performance. The Cayenne S also features a downsized engine with increased power and a new Sport Chrono package, offering enhanced handling and acceleration.

site_title: Scots' no vote still leaves UK in limbo
summary: Scotland's independence referendum resulted in a 55:45 split against independence, leaving the UK intact. The concessions offered by Westminster parties and pledges of devolution are unprecedented and contradictory, potentially leading to a national division. UK investors and companies will benefit from the decision, as will the UK's economy and politics, with the risk of Brexit decreased. However, the vote will still change the UK, with Scotland's parliament potentially gaining control of over half its tax-raising powers, and the terms of the unionist victory introducing tensions that could lead to further division.

site_title: F1: as much a technology race as a car race
summary: Formula One racing is shifting from a traditional car race to a technology battle, with teams relying on advanced technology and data analysis to gain a competitive edge. F1 cars are equipped with over 100 sensors that produce live telemetry data, which is transmitted to pit walls and laboratories for analysis. The use of real-time data analysis can save a thousandth of a second, with some cars within one second of each other. Top tech companies, including NetApp, EMC, SAP, and AT&T, partner with F1 teams to provide cutting-edge technology and support their data-driven strategies.

site_title: Vivendi, Telefonica seal US$9.3b broadband deal
summary: Vivendi has sold its Brazilian broadband business GVT to Telefonica for approximately $9.29 billion in cash and shares. The deal will see GVT merged with Telefonica's Vivo-branded mobile phone business to create the country's largest telecom group, Telefonica Brasil. The transaction marks a significant expansion for Telefonica in Brazil, bolstering its market presence.

site_title: Lum Chang sells LCD Global stake
summary: Lum Chang Investments and other shareholders have sold a 29.5% stake in LCD Global Investments to privately held JTrust Asia for S$93.1 million. The sale involves 310 million shares and will result in LCD being renamed JTrust International Ltd. David Lum will resign as a director and retire as an executive, while Kelvin Lum will also resign as a director within six months. JTrust Asia, a wholly owned subsidiary of JTrust Co Ltd, will appoint two new executive directors.

site_title: Realtor HSR's commission scheme shakes status quo
summary: HSR International Realtors, owned by Catalist-listed 3Cnergy, has introduced a "100 per cent Powered Scheme" that undercuts traditional commission schemes in the Singapore real estate market. Under the scheme, HSR will charge salespeople a maximum of S$3,800 per year, compared to 10-30% of their commission. The move aims to attract top sales talent and increase the firm's market share, despite the challenging real estate market. HSR's chairman, Tong Kooi Ong, believes the scheme is a sustainable business model that will prove to be a winning strategy in two years.

site_title: Dark pools need to let light in and gain mass: Liquidnet CEO
summary: Liquidnet CEO Seth Merrin stated that dark pools need to gain mass and increase transparency to remain viable. He emphasized that strong institutional volumes are necessary to build a functioning off-market trading venue. This comes as dark pools face challenges in the market, with many struggling to attract investors and maintain profitability.

site_title: Their Kallang high point
summary: Michelle Tan and her husband, co-founders of Own My Grain, have transformed their 26th-floor Kallang apartment into a fuss-free home with a Scandinavian look. After a six-month search, they found the perfect spot, despite its small size and lack of exciting design features. Renovated by Carl Lim of Czarl Architects, the apartment now boasts clean lines, a sleek black gate, and a concrete kitchen. The couple loves the apartment's location, with a park just next to it and a 10-minute walk to the Sports Hub. They have no plans to sell the home, citing its perfect balance of space and location.

site_title: SunMoon still shining bright
summary: Team SunMoon remains in first place with a 9-point lead after the fifth round of the 2014 Business Times Corporate Golf League. Team Emerio is in second spot, just behind, after scoring 109 points in the round. Team Zyfas took the highest score of the round with 110 points and secured a bottle of red wine sponsored by Le Vigne. The top stableford score went to Clinton Ang of Team Boustead, and the best team position was won by Park Hotel Group.

site_title: UK stays intact; focus shifts to power devolution
summary: The UK has maintained its unity after Scotland's 85% turnout in favor of remaining part of the UK. British Prime Minister David Cameron has pledged devolutionary constitutional change for other regions, following the resignation of Scottish nationalist leader Alex Salmond. The pound and London stocks initially rallied before easing due to uncertainties over the timing of the promised powers and the upcoming general election. Cameron has promised to deliver new powers to the Scottish Parliament, with a Scotland Bill to be introduced by March 2015, but has indicated that this will be a long process, with a new parliament to be formed after the May 2015 election.

site_title: Loyz Energy, lender in row over S$4m loan
summary: Loyz Energy, a Singapore-listed oil and gas company, is involved in a legal dispute with Advance Capital Partners over a S$4 million loan. Advance Capital Partners claims Loyz Energy failed to repay the loan, while Loyz Energy considers the claim without merit. The dispute is seen as separate from a proposed note subscription that allegedly fell through. Loyz Energy has announced the writ of summons to the Singapore Exchange, indicating the company will defend itself against the claim. The outcome of the dispute is yet to be determined.

site_title: Culinary shake-up
summary: Singapore's food and beverage scene continues to evolve with a recent wave of restaurant departures, closures, and takeovers. Notable closures include Nektar, a four-year-old cocktail bar, and Ujong, a mod-Sin restaurant at the Raffles Hotel. Meanwhile, a new take on the traditional hawker center, The Bedok Marketplace, is set to open on the second floor of the Bedok Marketplace by November, with a focus on working adults and young families. Other notable takeovers include Hopscotch, a year-long pop-up cocktail bar, and Shen Tan's departure from Ujong to become culinary director at Gastrogig, a pop-up and private dining events organiser.

site_title: Latin passion
summary: Two grape varieties, Tempranillo from Spain and Sangiovese from Italy, dominate four wines in The Business Times Wine Challenge 2014, while a French Bordeaux blend is the fifth. Spain's Rioja region is renowned for its Tempranillo, with Bodegas Roda producing a highly-regarded wine. In contrast, Italy's Tuscany region is known for its Sangiovese, with the Poliziano Vino Nobile de Montepulciano and Le Potazzine Brunello di Montalcino showcasing the variety's complexity. The fifth wine, Terra di Monteverro, is a concentrated Super-Tuscan blend.

site_title: Women of the world take centre stage
summary: Flamenco choreographer Maria Pages' new production, "I, Carmen," premieres in Madrid and Singapore, featuring a diverse cast and showcasing women's voices from around the world. Pages interviewed over 100 women for the piece, highlighting their experiences, insecurities, and contradictions. The show features Bizet's music without the traditional storyline, aiming to give voice to all women and represent their diverse perspectives. Pages found that many women prioritize their careers and development over maternal duties, revealing a more nuanced view of women's lives.

site_title: Land prices up across Japan's big cities
summary: Land prices in Japan's three largest metropolitan areas (Tokyo, Osaka, and Nagoya) rose 1.7% in the year to July 1, driven by office property investments and housing demand. Residential land prices in these areas increased 0.5% for the first time in six years. In contrast, land prices in 80% of Japan's smaller cities fell, with some areas experiencing significant increases due to foreign demand and the weakening yen.

site_title: See (Michelin) stars
summary: Singapore's first full-service pop-up restaurant, 4XFOUR, is set to return in November with a star-studded line-up of Michelin-starred chefs. The event will feature four internationally acclaimed European chefs, including Mads Refslund, Nathan Outlaw, Henrik Yde, and Rolf Fliegauf, over three weekends. The pop-up will be held at the F1 Pit Building's Temasek Suite, with up to 100 diners per session. The event aims to bring together culinary and visual art, with curated artworks by acclaimed contemporary artists.

site_title: The ugly nature of hacktivism
summary: Hackers, particularly those associated with the collective Anonymous, have been targeting businesses and government agencies in Singapore, exposing personal data and threatening to disrupt critical infrastructure. The hackers, known as hacktivists, use a criminal activity to justify their actions, posing a significant threat to due process and freedom of expression. In response, the government and companies must take a stand against these aggressors, and the public should be aware of the risks and consequences of their actions.

site_title: Scottish vote, FOMC meeting main features in quiet week
summary: The US Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting and the Scottish referendum on independence had minimal impact on the markets, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average reaching all-time highs despite mixed signals from the Fed. The FOMC cut its bond buying by $10 billion to $15 billion and kept the phrase "for a considerable time" when referring to the length of time interest rates would stay depressed. Scotland voted to stay in the UK, saving the currency and stock market from potential turmoil.

site_title: Boeing to start flying lessons this year
summary: Boeing plans to launch a Pilot Development Programme to train up to 500 pilots annually, aiming to meet growing demand worldwide. The two-phase programme includes general aviation training (12-18 months) and jet bridging and type rating (approximately two months), enabling pilots to fly specific models of aircraft. This initiative is expected to support Boeing's clients in meeting rising pilot requirements.

site_title: Fragrance plans to list Aussie business on Catalist
summary: Fragrance Group plans to list its Australian property business on Singapore's Catalist board, pending necessary approvals and market conditions. The spin-off, in preliminary stages, has seen the company's share price rise 6.7% to 24 cents. Fragrance has appointed SAC Capital to advise on the restructuring, which will focus on redeveloping four Australian plots into mixed-use developments and commercial projects. The outcome is dependent on preparatory work and market conditions, with no assurance it will materialize.

site_title: Thrift, moderation help - plus a loving kid
summary: Singapore's retiree population shows thriftiness, with most households spending around S$1,000 a month, leaving some with a shortfall of S$200-300. However, many retirees have built up a substantial portfolio to provide passive income, and social support from relatives and friends is common. The data debunks the notion that S$1 million is insufficient for retirement, and highlights the need for alternative resources to alleviate the effects of healthcare inflation.

site_title: To stay or not to stay - the final scene unfolds
summary: Scotland held a historic independence referendum on September 18, 2014, with the outcome uncertain. Opinion polls showed a narrow lead for the union, but with 600,000 undecided voters, the result was too close to call. Financial investors braced for potential fluctuations in the value of the pound, and currency dealers expected choppy trading if Scotland voted for independence. Leaders from both sides urged Scots to make their decision, with the nationalist leader Alex Salmond urging Scots to "seize this opportunity" and the Prime Minister David Cameron warning of the risks of secession.

site_title: A regulatory body separate from SGX?
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has proposed setting up an external and independent listings disciplinary committee (LDC) and listing appeals committee (LAC) to boost its disciplinary powers. The LDC would have the power to issue public reprimands, impose limited fines, and prohibit issue managers from participating in specific listings, among other things. However, the proposed setup relies on statutory backing, which may not be available, and critics argue that the current setup conflicts with SGX's role as a profit-making publicly listed business. A separate, independent regulatory body is seen as a cleaner and more efficient solution to ensure greater transparency and investor confidence.

site_title: Household income rises faster than expenditure
summary: Singapore households are earning more than they are spending, according to the latest Household Expenditure Survey by the Department of Statistics. The average monthly household income rose 5.3% to S$10,503, outpacing inflation of 3.1% between 2008 and 2013. The bottom 20% of families experienced the largest income growth, with average incomes increasing by 6.6% per annum. Meanwhile, households spent an average of S$4,724, with housing, food, and transport accounting for 65% of monthly expenditure.

site_title: SpiceJet to reduce fleet, workforce in cost-cutting bid
summary: SpiceJet, an Indian budget airline, is reducing its fleet and workforce as part of a cost-cutting bid to return to profit. The airline has cut capacity by 10% this year and plans to shrink by up to 14% in the year ending December. SpiceJet has also stopped services to some cities, deferring the delivery of two Boeing 737 planes, and is seeking to raise funds through the sale of stakes or debt. The airline aims to lower costs by flying fewer and newer aircraft, with the goal of improving fleet efficiency and reducing fuel costs.

images.alt_text: Tightening: SpiceJet is shrinking the size of its fleet and workforce to lower costs in one of the world's most expensive markets for airlines. - PHOTO: BLOOMBERG

site_title: S'pore seriously considering third China park project
summary: Singapore is considering a third China park project, focusing on connectivity and modern services, in the western region. The project's details are still being discussed with the Chinese side, with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasizing the need for a balance between policy and commercial goals. The project is expected to follow a private-sector-led and government-backed model, similar to the Sino-Singapore Guangzhou Knowledge City project, which Lee visited last week.

site_title: Pick of the Week
summary: Filipino artist Andres Barrioquinto returns to Singapore with a solo show at Galerie Sogan & Art, featuring new paintings and sculptures. The show, titled "The Scream of the Butterfly," showcases resin and acrylic sculptures with hollow facial features and surrealistic qualities. Barrioquinto's works are inspired by personal experiences, human passions, and cultural elements, with a focus on the trials and tribulations of marriage and love. The exhibition runs until September 28.

site_title: F1 to rev up numbers for tourism
summary: The Formula 1 Singapore Grand Prix is back, with Singapore Airlines (SIA) as the new title sponsor, aiming to boost tourism and brand exposure globally. The event typically attracts 40% of overseas visitors, generating S$150 million in tourism receipts annually. This year, SIA is promoting F1 packages and leveraging its network to tag on stopovers in the region. With 80,000 tickets released, the tourism industry is expected to see a fillip, despite subdued performance in the first half of the year, with visitor arrivals from China showing signs of recovery.

site_title: Shooting on the fly
summary: American photographer Justin Mott, 36, is competing in HISTORY Channel's reality TV photo competition, Photo Face-Off, alongside local photographers from Southeast Asia. In five half-hour episodes, Mott will face off against a local photographer and compete in Speed, Theme, and Extreme challenges. He will also judge the final episode, where the winner will receive a trip to New York and Japan to photograph a red carpet event and attend a Canon Photo Clinic. Mott finds the competition humbling, highlighting the importance of having a good eye and intuition in photography.

site_title: Around Town
summary: Upcoming events in Singapore include Whisky Live 2014, a whisky and spirit show at Raffles Hotel on Oct 25, featuring over 40 brands and spirit brands. The National Geographic Live Photo Exhibition will run from Sept 23 to Nov 13 at the East Garden Foyer Gallery, showcasing works by filmmaker Bryan Smith and underwater photographer David Doubilet. Opera Gallery is celebrating 20 years of art with "A Retrospective Journey" from Oct 1 to Oct 19, featuring works by prominent artists.

site_title: China set to launch longest freighter
summary: China is set to launch the world's longest freighter, a 400-meter-long ship that can haul 190 million iPads. The vessel, built by Hyundai Heavy Industries, will displace less water than a 200,000-ton bulk freighter and use one-fifth less fuel than traditional ships. The ship's launch follows China Shipping Container Lines' five new vessels, which will carry 19,100 standard 20-foot containers and give the company bragging rights in the industry. The move aims to reduce fuel costs and increase economies of scale in a depressed container market.

site_title: Time for prodigal fan to return to Apple?
summary: Apple's new iPhone 6 and 6 Plus models may help the company reclaim consumers who switched to Android for larger screen sizes. In Singapore, trade-ins of Samsung phones tripled week-over-week at Gazelle Inc, and more than 50,000 customers registered interest in buying the new iPhones. The iPhone 6 Plus is sold out, with prices already listed online for up to S$1,500. Analysts expect the new iPhones to outdo their predecessors, with 10 million units sold in the first quarter. The increased prices of mobile subscriptions may offset some of the costs, but could provide long-term benefits for telcos.

site_title: Looking for a disruptive edge
summary: Singapore companies must adopt disruptive innovation to stay ahead in the volatile business world, rather than just relying on new technologies and products. Disruptive innovation involves transformational changes that can replace current industry leaders. Despite government initiatives, many local firms are still hesitant to jump on the innovation bandwagon, preferring incremental productivity enhancements. Experts argue that businesses need to overhaul their business models to achieve game-changing performance, engaging top management and encouraging employee ideas. A comprehensive approach to innovation, including design development and intellectual property management, is crucial for companies to reap exponential results.

site_title: Raffles Education skis into Switzerland
summary: Raffles Education Corp, a private school operator in Asia, has made its European debut by purchasing a four-star hotel in Switzerland for 29.12 million Swiss francs (S$39.8 million). The acquisition will allow students to gain hospitality experience through internships and is expected to increase student intakes. The company plans to set up schools for hospitality management and design, as well as a Swiss International Baccalaureate school. The purchase is expected to positively impact the company's financial year and is part of its "progressive morphing" into three related businesses.

site_title: Fed flags October end to bond buying
summary: The Federal Reserve announced the end of its monetary stimulus in October, with the purchase of a final $15 billion in bonds. Chair Janet Yellen stated that most Fed members expect to hike rates in 2015, despite a low-profile dissent from two voting board members. The Fed also reaffirmed its commitment to keeping interest rates at low levels for a "considerable time."

site_title: Taking aim at family dysfunction
summary: The movie "This is Where I Leave You" follows Judd Altman, a radio producer, as he navigates his family's dysfunction after their father's death. The family, including his wife, sister, and siblings, gather at their home for a week of "sitting Shiva," where they confront past relationships and secrets. The film attempts to balance humor and seriousness but fails to deliver, with a final twist that undermines the story. The movie's inability to take risks and its well-developed main character, Judd, are notable shortcomings.

site_title: Ley Choon's asphalt-recycling plant opens
summary: Ley Choon Group Holdings has officially opened its S$30 million asphalt-recycling plant in Sungei Kadut, Singapore, the largest by capacity in the country. The plant, which employs state-of-the-art technology, can recycle bitumen and aggregates up to 70 per cent, more than tripling the company's production capacity. A S$2 million R&D centre has been established to develop new asphalt formulations, with one already being used in the construction of expressways. The opening is seen as a step towards reducing Singapore's reliance on imported construction materials and alleviating waste disposal issues.

site_title: FCL S$600m perpetual bonds priced at 4.88%
summary: FRASERS Centrepoint Ltd's (FCL) S$600 million debut perpetual bonds priced at 4.88%, lower than initial guidance of 5%. The subordinated NC-5 perpetual bonds cannot be redeemed until the fifth year, or Sept 24, 2019. Strong demand led to the successful issuance, making it the largest perpetual deal this year.

site_title: Fostering business model innovation
summary: Professor Serguei Netessine of Insead suggests that Singapore can foster a culture of business model innovation by providing small amounts of seed money, easing immigration rules, and creating stable institutions. This can attract key talent and encourage innovation. Subsidies for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) can also help. Additionally, easing bankruptcy laws can support innovators. Examples of successful startups in Singapore, such as PropertyGuru.com and RedMart.com, demonstrate the potential for business model innovation in the country.

site_title: Global shares mostly up after Fed decision
summary: Global shares rose on Thursday, with the US dollar rallying, after the Federal Reserve maintained its interest rate hike timeline, but indicated sharper increases may be on the horizon. The Dow hit a record high, and European stocks climbed for a second day. The Fed's statement that federal funds rates would remain low for "some considerable time" fueled the rally. Asian markets also rose, with Tokyo and Shanghai advancing, while Seoul fell.

site_title: Toast to fine Italian Barolo
summary: A wine dinner at La Strada featuring the wines of Bruno Giacosa, a renowned Barolo producer, was fully sold out. The dinner showcased Giacosa's 2008 and 2009 Barolo vintages, including Barbaresco Santo Stefano, a single cru wine from the finest site in Barbaresco. The event highlighted the modern trend towards producing wines from specific vineyard sites, echoing Burgundy's practice. Giacosa's wines were praised for their transparency, delicacy, and complexity, setting them apart from traditional Barolos, which often require time to mature.

site_title: Pursuing value
summary: Singapore's private residential property transactions have fallen to levels last seen during the global financial crisis, with discussions on lifting cooling measures. Despite this, experts believe the long-term fundamentals remain sound, citing rising wages, full employment, and a growing resident population. Recent studies show real estate remains a favored asset class among investors, with Asian HNWIs preferring to hold real estate as an investment.

site_title: Air France pilot strike still on as unions reject offer
summary: Air France pilots rejected a government offer and management's proposal to ease strike concerns, with the work stoppage continuing to ground over half of the airline's flights. The strike, which began in protest of plans to expand low-cost operations Transavia, threatens to cost the company 10-15 million euros a day. Unions fear job losses and pilots' lower pay in Transavia operations, while management claims the plans are to develop Transavia's European units equally. The strike, which started on September 17, 2014, has already caused significant disruptions and is expected to continue unless an agreement is reached.

site_title: Plunging yen fails to lift Japan's Aug exports
summary: Japan's August trade data showed a 1.3% decline in exports and a trade deficit of nearly $11.1 billion, despite the yen hitting a six-year low against the US dollar. The decline in exports was attributed to weaker demand for motor vehicles and a 33% drop in shipments to China. The yen's depreciation is expected to continue, with former vice-finance minister Eisuke Sakakibara predicting a drop to 110 by the end of the year. The Bank of Japan is under pressure to boost the economy, leading to further monetary easing and potential falls in the yen's value.

site_title: S'pore backs US alliance against ISIS
summary: Singapore supports the US-led coalition against the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS), but has yet to decide on the form of backing. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that the US will not deploy troops on the ground, citing the complexity of the situation. The ISIS poses a threat to people worldwide, with Singaporeans, Indonesians, and Malaysians among those who have joined the group. The militant organization controls a large swath of land in Iraq and has resources, a government, and oil. Singapore's support will be discussed, but no decision has been reached.

site_title: HK builders slash debt, raise cash to buy more land
summary: Hong Kong developers, including Li Ka-shing and Robert Ng, have cut debt to near-record lows to buy land as prices fall. Developers expect further price declines as the government releases more sites for sale. Billionaires have boosted cash reserves, with Cheung Kong Holdings having HK$29.7 billion available for land acquisitions. The average net debt-to-equity ratio for Hong Kong-based developers is 12.2%, the lowest in more than two decades. Developers plan to sell a record HK$150 billion of new homes this year, reducing inventories and boosting cash reserves, as prices fell 34% from last year.

site_title: A dance from within
summary: Choreographer Wayne McGregor, 44, combines dance and scientific research, collaborating with scientists and experts from other fields. His piece, FAR, explores the mind-body connection, inspired by historian Roy Porter's book "Flesh in the Age of Reason." McGregor believes creativity can be taught through movement science and technology. The dance, set to be performed in Singapore, features 3,000 LED bulbs and pushes the dancer's body to extreme limits, showcasing the relationship between movement and the human mind. McGregor's work aims to understand the human body and mind through scientific research and collaboration.

site_title: Gritty vendetta hits pay dirt
summary: The Rover, a contemporary Western film directed by David Michod, presents a bleak and unrelentingly violent vision of the Australian Outback. Starring Guy Pearce as Eric, a bitter loner, and Robert Pattinson as Rey, a wounded gang member, the film follows their unlikely friendship as they navigate a lawless existence. With a sparse plot and dialogue, the movie explores the harsh realities of a desperate future, where empathy is hard to come by and cruel men are driven by violence. The film's gritty approach marks a departure from Hollywood's typical fare.

site_title: KepLand sells MBFC Tower 3 stake for $1.2b
summary: Keppel Land sold its 1/3 stake in MBFC Tower 3 to Keppel Reit for $1.248 billion, including a rental support of up to $49.2 million. The deal will give Keppel Reit ownership in all three towers at MBFC and increase its portfolio's average age to 5.5 years, making it the youngest portfolio of premium assets. The transaction will be subject to minority unitholder approval and is expected to benefit both Keppel Land and Keppel Reit, with Keppel Land recycling capital and Keppel Reit upgrading its portfolio.

site_title: Asian sports market still at early growth stage: Sport Singapore CEO
summary: The Asian sports market is still in its early stages of growth, according to Sport Singapore CEO Lim Teck Yin. The total value of sports sponsorship in Asia is a small fraction of global spending. Sport Singapore cited this at the Sports Matters conference in Singapore. The market's growth is expected to continue, but its value is still much lower than that of the global sports market.

site_title: STATS ChipPAC Q3 net revenue outlook bleaker
summary: STATS ChipPAC has revised its third-quarter net revenue outlook downward to between $398 million and $405 million, a 1-3% dip from Q2, due to a shift in demand from high-end to low-cost smartphones. The company now expects adjusted Ebitda to be 20-23% of revenue and capital expenditure to be $165-185 million, including $80-90 million for a Korean factory construction. The revised outlook follows a delay in wafer supply at key customers.

site_title: Hammer time
summary: Christie's Asia+ woos young collectors with affordable contemporary art auction. The auction house has created a new platform offering works by established artists at lower price estimates, with lots priced in the five- or low six-figure sums. Christie's sees growing international interest in contemporary art and a younger generation of collectors entering the market. Meanwhile, Bonhams expands its Asian outposts, opening a Singapore office and doubling its specialist staff in existing offices. The non-profit artspace Substation hosts a silent auction with attractive buys, while Singapore entrepreneur Wong U-Yun launches Asia's first online boutique auction house, Lucanna.

site_title: Spare Iranian theatre brims with emotion
summary: Iranian play "Amid the Clouds" at the Singapore International Arts Festival received critical acclaim for its poignancy and meaning. The production, directed by Amir Reza Koohestani, follows the story of two Iranian exiles, Imour and Zina, who leave their homeland in search of greener pastures. With minimal stage and props, the play weaves a spell through the actors, words, and symbolism of water, exploring themes of loss, separation, and the human condition. The performance was praised for its gentle pacing and low-key expressionism, evoking an Arabian Nights quality.

site_title: StarHub teams up with US-based IO
summary: StarHub has partnered with US-based IO to offer a joint data centre service, "StarHub Data Centre Powered by IO". This strategic move aims to boost StarHub's enterprise business by increasing efficiency, managing costs, and speeding up time to market. The service is already being used by several companies in the financial, media, and IT sectors, and will be a key component of StarHub's end-to-end enterprise network solutions.

site_title: Italian artist's sellout pixel paintings
summary: Italian artist Cristiano Pintaldi has created a series of sellout pixel paintings, using a laborious technique of layering three primary colours (red, green, and blue) onto a black canvas to create naturalistic images. The paintings, titled Suspended Animation, feature extraterrestrial beings and urban landscapes, and are derived from real photographs. Pintaldi's technique mimics how original TV images are created, with each layer requiring precise gradation of colour to achieve the desired effect. The exhibition, held at Partners & Mucciaccia Gallery, has already sold out, with prices ranging from S$32,000 to over S$200,000.

site_title: Gold could sink to US$1,000 if support lines breached: analysts
summary: Gold prices may plummet to US$1,000 an ounce if support lines are breached, according to analysts. The metal has slid to eight-month lows, approaching its 2013 lows of US$1,180 an ounce. A breach of this support line could lead to a significant drop, potentially reaching triple figures by early next year, with Fibonacci retracement levels at US$1,150.

site_title: Noir side of Peter Pan
summary: Peter Pan, a lavish musical for children, has been reimagined by avant-garde director Robert Wilson. The production oscillates between light and dark, exploring themes of cruelty, unrequited love, and the impermanence of utopias. This adaptation is geared towards children aged 5-95, appealing to both younger and older audiences. Wilson's rich spectacle brings JM Barrie's classic children's book to life, offering a unique interpretation of the beloved story.

site_title: Airbus to keep one A380 a day build rate
summary: Airbus plans to maintain a production rate of nearly 30 A380s per month, despite soft demand. The company has enough orders to sustain this rate, and is seeking to revive interest in the superjumbo by offering higher-density configurations with 600 seats. Existing and potential customers are being encouraged to consider these configurations to boost per-seat revenue. Leases on Emirates and Singapore Airlines' A380s are set to expire, providing another potential market for buyers.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: Jefferies Singapore has joined the Singapore Exchange's derivatives market, increasing the number of trading members to 48 and clearing members to 26. CATALIST-LISTED Metal Component Engineering has signed a non-binding MOU with Hangzhou Honghua Digital Technology to develop and manufacture a digital textile printer. Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group has acquired 750,000 units of Accordia Golf Trust, now owning 5.048% of the trust. COMMUNICATION Design International plans to raise S$28.34m through a placement of up to 245 million new shares, with 95% intended for acquisitions and 5% for working capital.

site_title: China's property trusts wary of funding projects
summary: China's property trusts are reducing funding for developers due to maturing debt, with US$9.1 billion in bonds and loans maturing by year-end. Issuance of property trusts for real-estate projects fell to 30 billion yuan in the third quarter, the lowest since 2010. Rising borrowing costs and weak home sales, which fell 10.9% in the first eight months of the year, are escalating default concerns. Standard & Poor's warns of a risk of developer default in the coming 12 months, citing weak earnings at several property companies.

site_title: OECD starts big push to stop corp tax avoidance
summary: The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) has launched its plan to rein in corporate tax avoidance, known as the "Action Plan on Base Erosion and Profit Shifting" (BEPS). The plan aims to prevent corporations from abusing bilateral tax treaties, which have allowed companies like Google to pay low or no taxes. The OECD's move could impact Singapore firms with cross-border presence, as it seeks to close loopholes in the global tax system. The plan's first elements were unveiled on Tuesday, marking a significant push to address corporate tax evasion.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end 14.97 points higher
summary: Singapore shares ended 14.97 points higher on Friday, closing at 3,169.18, as the Straits Times Index rose 0.4% on Thursday. Losers outnumbered gainers 284 to 162, with volume reaching 1.12 billion shares worth S$1.02 billion. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and follows a 5-day rally.

site_title: American Airlines' passenger service agents vote to unionise
summary: American Airlines' passenger service agents voted to unionize, with 86% of members supporting collective bargaining. The 14,500 agents will be represented by the Communications Workers of America and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. The vote marks a change in mindset at American, which previously discouraged organizing efforts. The decision is seen as a rare pro-union vote in the US South, where most agents are based. Bargaining for a revised contract is expected to begin in November.

site_title: Independence may hurt Scottish housing market
summary: A vote for Scottish independence may negatively impact the country's housing market due to the potential for higher mortgage costs and default risk if foreign currency-denominated loans become due. If Scotland adopts a new currency, homeowners with pound mortgages may face higher payments, with one in five potentially struggling to afford their mortgage payments. The UK government is warning of a "painful divorce" if Scotland leaves the pound, but independence leaders argue a currency union would benefit both nations.

site_title: Triyards in placement to raise S$19.96m
summary: Triyards Holdings will raise S$19.96m by issuing up to 29.5 million new shares at 70 Singapore cents each. The funds will support future growth and working capital. The company plans to use 90% of the proceeds for business expansion and 10% for general corporate purposes. This will increase the company's issued and paid-up share capital by 9.1%. Net tangible asset per share and earnings per share will decrease. Triyards has recently secured a liftboat contract worth US$50.5 million and reported a 17% fall in net profit in its fiscal third quarter.

site_title: Faster immigration clearance for S'poreans visiting HK
summary: Singapore and Hong Kong have agreed to an automated immigration clearance system, allowing Singaporean passport holders to sign up for the e-Channel services in Hong Kong starting September 22, 2014. Eligible holders must have visited Hong Kong at least three times in the past 12 months and have no adverse records. A similar arrangement exists between Singapore and Malaysia. The system aims to enhance trade, business, and tourism links between the two cities.

site_title: Sydney housing gamble alarms central bank
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia has expressed alarm over a 16% surge in Sydney home prices in the past year, warning that an investor-led boom may amplify any subsequent fall and risk a drop in consumer spending. The bank cited a record-low interest rate and high-risk mortgages as contributing factors. Australian dwelling prices rose 11% in August, led by gains in Sydney and Melbourne, with concerns over foreign investment and the potential for mortgage delinquencies when interest rates rise.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit refinances RM330m senior MTNs
summary: Starhill Global Reit has refinanced RM330 million senior medium term notes at a lower interest cost by issuing a new five-year secured and fixed-rate senior MTN. The new MTN was issued under Ara Bintang Berhad's existing asset-backed MTN programme and was managed by CIMB Investment Bank Berhad. The refinancing reduces Starhill Global Reit's interest cost and provides the company with a more stable funding structure.

site_title: Aug exports rebound, but spots remain
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) rebounded in August with a 6% rise, ending a three-month decline. The growth was driven by a recovery in non-electronics exports, particularly in petrochemicals and pharmaceuticals. However, electronics exports remained weak, contracting 6.9% for the 25th consecutive month. Analysts expressed mixed reactions, with concerns about the continued poor performance of the electronics sector. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is expected to keep the Singapore dollar firm at its next policy meeting in October.

site_title: New ECs versus private condos: price gap widening
summary: The price gap between new executive condominiums (ECs) and private condos in Singapore is widening, with EC buyers potentially saving up to 31.7% on average compared to private condos. However, analysts argue that ECs are not a good value proposition due to restrictions on renting and selling, and that the data may be skewed by one-bedroom unit prices. Despite this, EC units resold this year fetched prices close to those of private homes, making them a draw for savvy buyers. The EC market is expected to recover with the launch of new EC projects, but at a higher price point of around S$750 psf.

site_title: Norway to invest in US office buildings
summary: Norway's sovereign-wealth fund, the world's largest, has agreed to buy stakes in three US office buildings for approximately $1.5 billion. The properties include 601 Lexington Ave in New York, the Atlantic Wharf Office Building, and 100 Federal Street in Boston. This investment extends the fund's real estate expansion, with plans to invest almost $10 billion annually over the next three years. The fund has also recently acquired stakes in other high-quality properties, including the Orrick Building in San Francisco and the Times Square Tower in New York.

site_title: Boeing, SpaceX win US$6.8b Nasa deal to ferry astronauts
summary: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) has awarded contracts worth up to $6.8 billion to Boeing and SpaceX to ferry astronauts to the International Space Station. The contracts, set to launch in 2017, will allow the US to end its reliance on Russia, which has been ferrying American astronauts since the retirement of the space shuttle. Boeing's contract is worth up to $4.2 billion, while SpaceX's is valued at $2.6 billion, with both companies to provide up to six flights to the space station once certified by NASA.

site_title: 21 trillion yuan cleared in S'pore in January-August
summary: Singapore's yuan-clearing business continues to grow rapidly, with a cumulative clearing amount of 21 trillion yuan (S$4.3 trillion) from January to August. ICBC Singapore, the only authorized yuan-clearing bank, is seeking more banking products to accommodate the growing demand. The bank will host its first RMB Internationalisation Summit on September 22 to discuss the market's future direction. The summit aims to explore product areas such as credits, derivatives, and private banking to tap into the growing market.

site_title: Average 9.6% YTD total return for S'pore office Reits
summary: SINGAPORE-listed office real estate investment trusts (Reits) have achieved an average year-to-date return of 9.6% and a median of 10.4%, surpassing global office Reits. The median indicative yield of Singaporean Reits is 6.1%, compared to the global average of 4.5% and the global median of 4.3%.

site_title: Asean haze agreement must show its teeth
summary: Indonesia's Parliament ratified the Asean Agreement on Transboundary Haze Pollution, 12 years after signing the pact with other Asean member states. The move aims to strengthen Indonesia's policies on forest fires and haze, but critics argue the agreement lacks enforcement mechanisms. The ratification comes amid recent haze hotspots in Sumatra and Kalimantan, and Singapore has passed a new bill to fine companies causing haze. Effective enforcement is crucial to the pact's success, and all Asean countries must work together to prevent and mitigate haze.

site_title: Calpers removing entire US$4b put in hedge funds
summary: Calpers, the largest US pension fund, plans to divest its $4 billion investment in hedge funds due to their complexity and high costs. The decision, announced by interim chief investment officer Ted Eliopoulos, aims to reduce the fund's costs and simplify its investment strategy. The move comes as other large public pension funds, such as New Jersey's, increase their hedge fund investments. Calpers will take about a year to complete the pull-out, with no decision yet on where to invest the funds.

site_title: M1: Bank details not accessible during website breach
summary: M1 Singapore's website experienced a security breach, compromising the personal information of 12 customers, including names, addresses, and IC numbers. The breach was attributed to a security flaw in the website's customer authentication mechanism, which was subsequently patched. In a separate incident, the personal data of over 300,000 K Box Singapore customers was leaked online. The Personal Data Protection Commission is investigating both incidents. M1 is contacting affected customers and has assured that bank details were not accessible during the breach.

site_title: Asia's securitisation market in its infancy
summary: Asia's asset-backed securities market is still in its infancy, with banks in Singapore set to issue covered bonds. Industry players see a need for more work to develop the market, with clients seeking cheaper funding options and assets typically being triple-A rated. Despite this, there are signs of healthier demand, with companies looking for structures that meet specific needs rather than just cost of funds. The market's growth is expected to be driven by banks seeking to diversify their funding sources, with covered bonds seen as a means to fulfill liquidity requirements under Basel III.

site_title: Master remaker of the classics
summary: Matthew Bourne's 1995 reworked version of Swan Lake has been performed more times in 20 years than the Royal Ballet's original production in its 75-year history. The ballet, now on a world tour, has become a global phenomenon, with sold-out shows in the UK, Singapore, and other cities. Bourne's unique twist, featuring a male ensemble and a prince's longing for love, has reinvigorated the classic tale, making it an emotional and passionate experience for new generations. The production, now on a UK tour and set to premiere at da:ns Festival in Singapore, has cemented Bourne's status as a master remaker of the classics.

site_title: United offers buyouts to flight attendants
summary: United Airlines is offering buyouts to flight attendants, with payments ranging from $50,000 to $100,000. The airline aims to reduce costs by luring senior employees into early retirement.
