The play, part of a planned trilogy, explores the complex relationships between Lee's family and a Japanese officer who lived next door. Lee, known for his music, has faced criticism for past works, but views failures as opportunities to stay creative and relevant. "Rising Son" premieres at the DBS Arts Centre from March 12 to April 12, with tickets available from $35-$55.

site_title: CEO pay in S'pore holds steady as profits slip: report
summary: Singapore's median CEO salaries remained steady at $875,000 in the last financial year, despite a 0.5% decline in company profitability. CEOs in the property and finance sectors were the best paid, followed by those in hotels and restaurants. A report by Hay Group found that companies with better pay for performance alignment tend to have higher shareholder returns, but 14.6% of companies had significant misalignment between CEO bonuses and company profitability. Only 28% of companies used long-term incentive plans to reward top executives.

site_title: Tips on evaluating a Reit
summary: Real estate investment trusts (Reits) are often evaluated based on their yields and net asset values (NAVs), but this simplistic approach can be misleading. High yields don't necessarily mean a Reit is an attractive buy, as they can be related to risk and growth potential. For example, CapitaMall Trust (CMT) trades at a low yield of 5.4% due to its stable performance and ability to increase distributions year-over-year, while Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust trades at an 8% yield due to its riskier nature and currency fluctuations. Investors should consider a Reit's yield and NAV in context, taking into account its growth potential, risk, and valuation methods.

site_title: Yangzijiang posts 8% dip in Q4 profits to 746m yuan
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, a China-based shipbuilder, reported an 8% year-on-year decline in Q4 profits to 746 million yuan due to a decline in other income. However, the shipbuilding segment saw a 68% increase in gross profits to 1,304 million yuan, driven by higher margin shipbuilding contracts. The company delivered 6 vessels in Q4 2013, lower than the previous year, but maintained a 43% gross profit margin. The group's FY13 attributable net profit declined 14% to 3,096 million yuan due to higher taxes and impairment provisions.

site_title: 220 out of 300 units at RiverTrees Residences sold
summary: RiverTrees Residences in Sengkang, Singapore, saw strong sales over the weekend, with 220 out of 300 units sold, including two-bedroom suites starting from $618,000 and strata-titled landed homes for under $2 million. The project's psf prices appear to be in the right range, attracting both HDB upgraders and investors. Experts attribute the strong sales to the project's design, location, and pricing, which has put units within reach of upgraders and first-time buyers, validating market demand for high-quality homes.

site_title: BreadTalk Q4 net profit up 33%
summary: BreadTalk Group reported a 33% increase in its Q4 net profit to $5.6 million, with revenue rising 23% to $147.1 million. The company declared a final dividend of 1.3 cents per share, totaling 1.8 cents for the year. Full-year revenue increased 20% to $536.5 million, while net profit rose 13% to $13.6 million, with profit margins improving despite cost pressures.

site_title: ST Engg posts $580.8m full-year profit
summary: ST Engineering reported a net profit of $580.83 million for the 12 months ended Dec 31, 2013, a 1% increase from the previous year. Revenue inched up 4% to $6.63 billion, driven by stronger contributions from the marine business. The aerospace sector accounted for 31% of revenue, while the electronics sector and land systems sectors contributed 25% and 22% respectively. The group announced a final dividend of four cents and a special dividend of eight cents, with a strong order book of $13.2 billion.

site_title: Silver lining in EU threat to ban Filipino seafarers
summary: The European Union is threatening to ban Filipino seafarers due to concerns over the country's standards of training and certification. However, the Philippines has taken steps to address these issues, with both houses of Congress passing a bill to put the Maritime Industry Authority in charge of training and certification. The EU has indicated that it will not impose a ban on valid and active certificates of competency, giving Filipino officers a five-year grace period. Industry representatives are working to rectify the original findings and ensure that Filipino seafarers meet international standards, potentially benefiting the country's shipping industry.

site_title: China's home price gains slow in major cities
summary: China's home prices in major cities, including Beijing, Shanghai, and Shenzhen, showed a slowdown in January, with growth rates of 0.4-0.7% from a month earlier. This is the slowest pace since October 2012. Local governments have implemented measures to curb escalating values, and banks have tightened lending. The Shanghai Stock Exchange Property Index fell 5.4%, and some developers may default on debt due to maturing property trust loans worth 350 billion yuan. Experts predict property sales will continue to weaken until March.

site_title: Swiber FY13 net profit up 36% at US$62.12m
summary: Swiber Holdings posted a 36% increase in net profit to US$62.12 million for FY13, driven by a 169.4% increase in other operating income. Revenue rose 11.2% to US$1.06 billion, mainly from South-east Asia projects. The company expects strong rig demand in Asia and is well-positioned to expand in the Latin America market.

site_title: Haw Par profit slips 10% to $107.9m
summary: Haw Par Group reported a 10% decline in full-year profit to $107.9 million, primarily due to poor performance from associated companies and fair-value losses. The leisure division saw a 68% drop in profits, while the healthcare division experienced a 51% increase. Excluding non-recurring items, operating profit would have grown 14.3%. The company is recommending a final dividend of 14 cents per share, bringing the full-year payout to 20 cents per share.

site_title: ICE cancels all SMX contracts, plans relaunch
summary: ICE cancels all SMX contracts, a bourse it acquired for $150 million in 2014, and plans to relaunch later this year. The delisted contracts include iron ore, pepper, and metals, and currencies. The move is part of a business transition to implement technology changes. ICE's CEO Jeff Sprecher stated that the company was not interested in SMX's business but wanted the infrastructure to tap into the Asian market. This move follows other global exchanges increasing their presence in the region.

site_title: China unlikely to see sharp correction in property prices
summary: China's property market is expected to see a moderate correction in prices in some small cities this year, with a slim chance of a sharp fall nationwide. Analysts believe the market has overreacted to recent slowdown indicators, citing strong housing demand in wealthy cities and a drive to move people to cities. Most respondents expect a 10% price drop in smaller cities, but no correction in large cities like Beijing, Shanghai, and Guangzhou, where demand and short supply have pushed up prices.

site_title: US housing wealth centred in a few markets
summary: A US study by the Demand Institute found that 10% of communities held 52% of total housing wealth, worth approximately $4.4 trillion, while the bottom 40% held 8% of the wealth, or $700 billion. The disparity has remained constant, with the top 10% experiencing nearly $2 trillion in gains from 2000 to 2012, while the bottom 40% gained $260 billion. The report suggests that the national housing recovery may mask local discrepancies, with some areas lagging behind others.

site_title: S'pore private home rent rates expected to fall
summary: Rental rates for private homes in Singapore are expected to decline by 5% this year, according to analysts, due to a shrinking expatriate population and rising supply of new homes. The decline in demand is expected to be most pronounced in the Central Region, with rents in Outside the Central Region likely to hold. Experts predict a further easing of 2% in 2015 if vacancy rates continue to rise, with occupancy levels of non-landed private homes expected to improve after mid-2016.

site_title: Qantas to cut 15% of staff as it falls into red
summary: Qantas Airways is cutting 15% of its workforce, approximately 5,000 jobs, as part of a radical revamp to cut costs by A$2 billion over the next three years. The move aims to convince the Australian government to provide state aid and address high fuel costs, stiff competition, and increasing debt. Qantas plans to sell oil-guzzling older planes and reduce spending, while seeking a debt guarantee and changes to a law restricting foreign investment in the airline.

site_title: S'pore team launches Asia's first Bitcoin machine
summary: Singapore has launched Asia's first Bitcoin vending machine, located in a pub in Boat Quay. The machine, called "Tembusu," allows users to purchase Bitcoins using cash and then transfer the value to a Bitcoin wallet app. The machine has a 5% fee and is backed by a three-man team who designed and manufactured it in-house. This launch comes ahead of other countries in the region, including Hong Kong and Taiwan, and is seen as a milestone for the Bitcoin community.

site_title: Purchases of new homes in January climb to 5-year high
summary: US home sales rose 9.6% to a 5-year high in January, reaching 468,000 annualized pace, driven by improved demand in three of four regions. Despite harsh weather, consumer confidence remains strong, with property values and the economy improving. However, limited housing supply and rising borrowing costs hinder further growth, with the months' supply of homes at its lowest since June.

site_title: Londoners at odds over restoration
summary: A £160 million proposal to restore historic Victorian market buildings in London's Smithfield Market is being met with opposition from local conservationists, who fear the project will destroy the area's character. The project, backed by global investment fund Henderson Global Investors, aims to create shops, restaurants, and offices, but critics argue that it will only benefit large corporations and not local businesses. The debate highlights broader issues in London, including the high cost of real estate and the need for more diverse and inclusive development.

site_title: ThaiBev FY13 drops 33% on one-offs
summary: Thai Beverage Public Co's full-year profit dropped 33% to 19.1 billion baht due to a one-off gain from its acquisition of a 29% stake in Fraser and Neave in 2012. Excluding the gain, profit before minority interests would have risen 18%. Revenue decreased 3.3% to 155.8 billion baht, with the spirits business growing 3.2% and the beer business narrowing its loss. ThaiBev proposes a dividend of 0.3 baht per share.

site_title: EM valuations attractive, but it's not time to buy big
summary: Emerging markets are considered attractive but not suitable for a large-scale investment due to poor sentiment and capital's fickle nature. Experts, including Barclays' Kevin Gardiner and JP Morgan Asset Management's Jed Laskowitz, recommend being underweight emerging markets and overweight developed markets. Households in both emerging and developed Asia remain heavily weighted in cash, with a heavy home bias. Multi-asset funds, which invest in a mix of equity and fixed income, are seen as a means to get investors into equities. The long-term outlook for emerging markets is positive, but short-term returns are uncertain.

site_title: Maybank profit rises 14% to RM6.55b
summary: Maybank reported record net earnings of RM6.55 billion for the year ended Dec 31, 2013, with a 14% increase in profit. The bank plans to deepen its portfolio in the region, expanding cross-border banking solutions, insurance, and takaful services. Net 2013 earnings were driven by 14% loan growth, with its Indonesian unit posting 28% profit growth despite challenging conditions. Maybank expects satisfactory growth in 2014, targeting 13% loan growth.

site_title: Two offshore marine firms' Q4 earnings hit record
summary: Offshore marine firms Nam Cheong and Pacific Radiance announced record fourth-quarter earnings, with Nam Cheong's net profit increasing 43% to RM70.5 million and Pacific Radiance's net profit rising 76% to US$56.8 million. The companies attributed the growth to increased spending in the exploration and production sector and robust oil prices. Nam Cheong proposed a first and final dividend of 0.5 cents, while Pacific Radiance recommended a final dividend of two cents. Both firms expect to benefit from the growing demand for their services.

site_title: CapitaLand and CityDev Q4 profits slide, KepLand bucks the trend
summary: Singapore's top three residential developers, CapitaLand and CityDev, posted mixed Q4 results, with CapitaLand experiencing a 45.6% drop in net profit and CityDev a 11.4% drop. In contrast, Keppel Land's Q4 net profit rose 7.6% due to a one-off gain from the divestment of its stake in Jakarta Garden City. All three developers are expected to ramp up their overseas presence, with CDL set to launch projects in London and Keppel Land focusing on China. Despite domestic challenges, CDL plans to launch two projects in Singapore in the first half of the year.

site_title: Indian billionaire Uday Kotak's property fund to raise US$200m
summary: Indian billionaire Uday Kotak's property fund, Kotak Investment Advisors Ltd, plans to raise $200 million to invest in residential properties in top cities like Mumbai, Delhi, and Bangalore. The fund aims to provide debt and structured financing to large developers, targeting a 20% return. This move comes as the Indian real estate market has seen a decline in sales, with home prices rising by 70% since 2010 and volumes plummeting by 50% in some areas. The fund's investment is expected to address the capital shortage in the residential space.

site_title: Vard's Q4 earnings more than quadruple
summary: Vard Holdings, an offshore supply vessel builder, reported a 4.3-fold increase in Q4 net profit to 113 million Norwegian kroner, driven by a tax write-back and turnaround at associates. Revenue grew 22.5% to 3.09 billion kroner, while Ebitda fell 45% to 158 million kroner. The company delivered 5 vessels in Q4 and secured contracts for 3 newbuildings, but margins were impacted by higher material, subcontract, and labor costs. Vard's FY2013 net profit declined 55.6% to 357 million kroner, and the company maintained a positive outlook for new order wins in 2014.

site_title: CRT to acquire two Tokyo retail properties
summary: CROESUS Retail Trust (CRT) has agreed to acquire two retail properties in Tokyo for 14.25 billion yen (S$176.7 million), expanding its portfolio from four to six malls and increasing its total net lettable area by 9%. The acquisitions are expected to raise CRT's distribution per unit by 5.7% and increase its portfolio value by 28.3%. The trust is focused on growing its portfolio in Japan, where it sees opportunities for investors, and aims to achieve a 6.2% capitalisation rate for new assets.

site_title: The right wine for Asian food
summary: A wine enthusiast shares his experience of pairing wine with Asian cuisine, highlighting the importance of making an informed choice. He visited a popular HDB coffee shop, where he enjoyed a white and red wine, including a 26-year-old Puligny-Montrachet and a 16-year-old Hermitage, both from renowned producers. The writer notes that Asian cuisine offers a wide variety of options, and traditional wine pairing guidelines can be modified through experience and practice. He concludes that wine can elevate the dining experience and recommends exploring different wine options to find the perfect match for Asian dishes.

site_title: Consumer confidence falls in February
summary: Consumer confidence in the US fell to 78.1 in February, down from 79.4 in January, exceeding forecasts. Americans became more pessimistic about the economy and employment, with the share of those expecting business conditions to improve declining to a four-month low. The Conference Board's measure of consumer expectations for the next six months dropped to 75.7, while the present conditions measure increased to 81.7, the highest since April 2008. Experts attribute the decline to concerns over the short-term outlook for jobs and earnings.

site_title: Finance not exploiting technology: report
summary: A new report from ACCA (Association of Chartered Certified Accountants) finds that finance functions globally are not fully utilizing emerging technologies to support their businesses. Despite the availability of technology, finance operations are often hindered by complex and fragmented systems, manual work, and a lack of leadership in pushing a bigger technology agenda. Experts suggest that finance professionals need to become more technology-savvy and collaborate with technology experts to drive innovation, with a new duality in the relationship between finance and technology emerging.

site_title: Stock market likely to continue rebound this week
summary: The US stock market is expected to continue its rebound this week, with bulls attributing recent weakness to temporary issues such as weather and emerging markets concerns. Economists at Nomura Securities say weak data and the potential for a rate hike by the Federal Reserve are concerns, but bulls believe these issues will pass. The Dow Jones Industrial Average is near its record high and is in the midst of "retesting" the peak.

site_title: LNG T2 likely to be similar in size as Jurong Island's
summary: Singapore's second liquefied natural gas (LNG) terminal, LNG T2, is likely to be similar in size to the current Jurong Island facility to meet the country's future gas needs. The Energy Market Authority's chief executive, Chee Hong Tat, stated that sufficient capacity is needed to ensure long-term gas security. LNG T2 will have a capacity of at least 15 million tonnes per annum, matching the current Singapore LNG terminal's expected capacity once Jurong Island is fully utilized. The terminal's expansion will help diversify Singapore's gas supplies and increase competition, leading to lower prices.

site_title: Airbus profit rises, increases plane output
summary: Airbus reported a 22% increase in net profit for 2013, driven by higher production and reduced restructuring charges. The company plans to boost A320 jet production to 46 aircraft per month by 2016. This comes as demand for fuel-efficient planes surges, with plane manufacturers producing a passenger plane every few hours. Despite cautious forecasts for 2014, Airbus aims to increase revenues from mid-decade.

site_title: Banyan Tree Q4 net down 27% due to unrest in Thailand
summary: Banyan Tree Holdings reported a 27% drop in Q4 net profit due to unrest in Thailand, with earnings from its core market falling. The company expects operations to remain negatively affected in Q1. Forward bookings for hotels in Thailand fell 11% and many countries issued travel advisories, impacting tourist arrivals. Revenue per available room (Revpar) for Thailand resorts decreased by 10%, while Revpar in Maldives and Seychelles increased by 20% and 39% respectively. Despite this, the company's full-year net profit rose 22% to $18.1 million.

site_title: S'pore slips in global retirement ranking
summary: Singapore has dropped to 41st in Natixis Global Asset Management's 2014 Global Retirement Index, a decline from 28th in 2013. The country's welfare issues, including high out-of-pocket health expenditure and low physician numbers, contributed to the fall. Singapore's income inequality also worsened, pushing its Material Well-being sub-index ranking lower. The index's findings highlight the need for retirees to plan ahead for demographic shifts and financial security.

site_title: Wealth of Filipino art
summary: The Philippines is home to a rich and diverse art scene, with various museums and galleries showcasing the country's contemporary art. The Ayala Museum in Makati features Ai Wei Wei's "Baby Formula" and Elmer Borlongan's social realist paintings, while the Metropolitan Museum of Manila's "The Philippine Contemporary" exhibition provides a comprehensive overview of the country's art development from modern to contemporary era. The National Museum in Manila houses the iconic "Spoliarium" painting by Juan Luna, and the Ateneo Art Gallery in Quezon City is recognized as the first museum of modern Filipino art, featuring works by Rodel Tapaya.

site_title: Ukraine's unfinished revolution has mansion to match
summary: Ukraine's former president, Viktor F Yanukovych, had a luxurious Black Sea retreat built for him, but workers abandoned the construction site after he fled the country. The mansion, with a 40-foot-high ceiling and indoor swimming pool, was built on a protected forest and featured rare species of trees being cut down. The project was shrouded in secrecy, with no building permit posted, and workers were not paid. Yanukovych is now facing trial for mass murder in Ukraine, and his welcome in Crimea, where he had fled, has worn off, with some residents calling him a coward for running away from protesters.

site_title: Will incentives lead to desired SME outcomes?
summary: Singapore's Budget 2014 introduced more incentives for businesses, with 65% of respondents saying the measures enabled them to invest in equipment or raise labor productivity. However, half of the respondents stated that the measures had no impact on innovation. Economists question the definition of innovation under the Productivity and Innovation Credit (PIC) Scheme, suggesting that a more independent body could address practical issues. The budget also gave more to the stronger businesses, raising concerns over its impact on productivity growth and competitiveness.

site_title: Singapore, UK plan offshore yuan cooperation
summary: Singapore and the UK plan to establish a private sector forum and financial dialogue to boost the offshore yuan market. The forum aims to increase cooperation between the two countries' markets and promote the fungibility of the yuan globally. This move follows Chancellor George Osborne's visit to Singapore and comes alongside the establishment of a dialogue to facilitate the exchange of views on domestic and international financial issues. The goal is to encourage innovation in yuan-denominated products and services, meeting the growing appetite for yuan-denominated investment instruments.

site_title: UEM Sunrise CEO Wan Abdullah dies
summary: UEM Sunrise CEO Wan Abdullah Wan Ibrahim, 56, has died, according to the company's statement. He had been on medical leave since December and resigned as a director in Tuesday's announcement. Wan Abdullah oversaw the transformation of UEM Sunrise into a leading Malaysian and international property player.

site_title: New ship orders threaten to derail recovery
summary: Ship owners and investors are placing orders for new vessels, threatening to derail a fragile recovery in the global shipping sector. A survey found 40% of respondents cited overcapacity as the biggest threat to recovery, with optimism growing in the sector despite this risk. New orders in the oil products tanker and dry bulk sectors have reached their highest levels since 2009, with 233 and 176 vessels ordered, respectively, in the past year. This could lead to a shortage of skilled personnel, exacerbating existing concerns about the industry's future growth.

site_title: Thailand's homebuilders face tough times as crisis drags on
summary: Thailand's homebuilders face significant challenges due to the ongoing crisis, with new project launches expected to drop 30% this year. The country's real estate market, valued at $20 billion, is experiencing oversupply and political unrest, leading to a decline in consumer confidence and housing demand. As a result, developers such as Pruksa Real Estate and Land & Houses are canceling new launches and expecting lower revenue growth, with some predicting a 2-5% contraction in the market this year.

site_title: Still boxed in by excess supply
summary: The container shipping industry is expected to continue suffering in 2014 due to an oversupply problem exacerbated by large vessel orders. Industry players attribute the downward pressure on freight rates to the gigantism of main lines, which have increased capacity but not demand. Geared feeder vessels below 3,000 TEUs, however, are expected to remain in high demand and see increasing rates, as only half of the world's top 500 ports can be accessed by vessels of this size. Managing capacity to match demand will require shipowners to analyze their fleet and consider scrapping or removing non-economical vessels.

site_title: Turkish Airlines turns to US investors for financing
summary: Turkish Airlines is selling bonds to US investors to finance plans to double passenger numbers by 2020, with a potential debt sale of up to $1 billion. The airline, which features sports stars like Lionel Messi and Kobe Bryant in its ads, is looking to increase its fleet two-fold and is working with Goldman Sachs Group and Citigroup to sell debt backed by aircraft. This move comes as airlines seek alternative financing amid rising global competition, with $6.8 billion in dollar-denominated EETCs sold last year.

site_title: Seven sailors injured in India submarine accident
summary: Seven Indian sailors were injured in a submarine accident off Mumbai's coast, with another two missing. The incident occurred during a routine training exercise, resulting in a leak in the submarine's battery compartment. The injured sailors suffered smoke inhalation and were airlifted for treatment. The Indian navy has taken measures to contain the situation, with naval ships providing assistance. The submarine, INS Sindhuratna, is a Russian-built vessel, and this incident highlights the challenges faced by the Indian navy with its aging fleet.

site_title: Tokyo Philharmonic takes on the world
summary: The Tokyo Philharmonic Orchestra is set to embark on its 100th Anniversary World Tour, starting in New York City on March 11, after being postponed due to the 2011 East Japan earthquake and tsunami. The six-city tour will feature renowned conductor Eiji Oue and include performances of Stravinsky's Rite of Spring and Tchaikovsky's Violin Concerto. The tour aims to share the orchestra's "dialect of the global language" with the world, with a poignant tribute to the victims and survivors of the 2011 disaster.

site_title: OUE Hospitality Trust's Q4 DPU at 1.67 cents
summary: OUE Hospitality Trust reported a Q4 DPU of 1.67 cents, surpassing its forecast by 2.5%, driven by strong performance from its portfolio assets, including Mandarin Orchard Singapore Hotel and Mandarin Gallery. Distribution income reached $21.9 million, beating forecasts, and NPI exceeded estimates. The trust is considering acquiring Crowne Plaza Changi Airport and prefers a yield accretion of 4.5-5.0% for new properties. Units of the trust edged down 0.57% lower, a 4.3% discount to net asset value.

site_title: LNG push for energy security, opportunities
summary: Singapore's decision to build a second LNG terminal, LNG T2, aims to boost energy security and opportunities. The existing SLNG facility on Jurong Island has already expanded its capacity and now serves as the region's first open-access, multi-user facility. The new terminal will further enhance Singapore's position as a regional LNG hub, with potential for intra-regional "break bulk" and transhipment. The move is seen as a calculated risk to capitalize on growing energy needs and trading opportunities in the region.

site_title: Groupon clones giving up business model
summary: Singapore's StreetDeal, a group-buying site, is shifting from its voucher model to traditional e-commerce after struggling to maintain its voucher business. The company, which operates in Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, the Philippines, and Indonesia, has about 1.1 million subscribers. StreetDeal's revenue is now split evenly between its voucher and e-commerce businesses, indicating a strong demand for online shopping. The company's decision comes as other Groupon clones in Singapore have failed, and it aims to reduce costs by selling products directly.

site_title: Cosco Corp's full-year net tumbles 71%
summary: Cosco Corp reported a 71% decline in full-year net profit to $30.6 million, down from $105.7 million in 2013, due to a 6% drop in revenue and a 34% fall in gross profit. Lower shipyard revenue was the main factor contributing to the decline.

site_title: Rising risks in emerging Asian markets: EY
summary: Global accounting firm EY highlights six emerging themes in emerging Asian markets that companies should be aware of, including the changing landscape for cross-border disputes, bribery and corruption, and cyber-crime. Companies must balance growth opportunities with perceived corruption risks, and perform robust due diligence to manage these risks. Regulatory pressure will continue to intensify, particularly in the financial services industry, and companies will need to take proactive measures to prevent reputational harm and cyber-crime. Compliance with anti-bribery laws, such as the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, will also remain a top priority.

site_title: SLNG open to spot use of terminal
summary: Singapore LNG is set to open its Jurong Island terminal for short-term use by LNG producers and traders, with the goal of optimizing the terminal's $1.7 billion capacity. The terminal's expansion, including a new secondary jetty, has increased its capacity to six million tonnes per annum. The move aims to boost price discovery and accommodate more competitively-priced gas. SLNG is in talks with international traders, including Gazprom, and may seek approval from the Energy Market Authority if customers request short-term use.

site_title: China rental biz drives second-home sales
summary: China-based Tujia Technology is revolutionizing the rental market by allowing homeowners to rent out their properties on short-term stays, generating rental income while the property appreciates. The platform has listed over 80,000 properties in China and abroad, with annual rental revenue exceeding 100 million yuan. Tujia's model has helped drive sales of second homes, with many homeowners opting to rent out their properties to generate rental income and property management services. The company has attracted 400 million yuan in funding from investors, including HomeAway and Ctrip.com, and has expanded its listings to over 3,000 properties, with occupancy rates exceeding 70% in 2013.

site_title: Honouring our pioneers
summary: Singapore's government has been commended for its efforts to honor the country's pioneers through the Pioneer Generation Package, which includes lifetime medical benefits and other forms of support. Companies such as ABN Amro and PrimeStaff Management Services have also taken steps to recognize and support the pioneers, including volunteering their time and resources. Experts argue that while the package is a good start, more can be done to enhance the quality of life for the pioneers, including providing financial security, housing support, and job opportunities. The government is seen as taking a step in the right direction, but more comprehensive support is needed to ensure the well-being of the pioneers in their golden years.

site_title: Budget 2014: looking ahead
summary: The 2014 Singapore Budget focuses on achieving quality growth and an inclusive society. Key initiatives include extending the Productivity and Innovation Credit (PIC) scheme for three more years, a 10-year extension of enhanced tax deduction for R&D, and the creation of new industrial spaces through cluster strategies. The government also aims to enhance healthcare affordability, increase support for the pioneer generation, and address inequality. However, some tax-related initiatives were not fulfilled, including tax certainty for companies disposing of equity investments. The government expects a tighter budget position in the coming years and may consider increasing the GST rate to offset expenditures.

site_title: Low January inflation masks underlying price pressures
summary: Singapore's inflation rate dropped to a near four-year low in January, falling to 1.4% from 1.5% in December. However, economists say this is due to a decline in private road transport costs and accommodation costs, which mask underlying price pressures. Core inflation, which excludes these costs, rose 2.2% from 2% in December, driven by higher contributions from services and food prices. Economists expect core inflation to continue rising, with some predicting inflation will tick up past Q1 as base effects wear off.

site_title: China XLX net profit falls 15% on flat revenue
summary: China XLX Fertilizer reported a 15.1% decline in net profit to 264.05 million yuan for FY2013, due to lower average selling prices of urea. Revenue rose 0.6% to 3.97 billion yuan, driven by higher sales volumes of methanol and compound fertiliser. The company declared a final dividend of six fen per share. China XLX expects low selling prices for urea and coal, and has commenced production at its new plant IV, which will improve cost efficiency and strengthen its industry position.

site_title: Taiwan's 'aerotropolis' plan finally taking off
summary: Taiwan's long-stalled "aerotropolis" plan has finally gained momentum, with the interior ministry approving urban development plans for the Taoyuan International Airport. The project, estimated to cost up to US$16 billion, aims to create over 200,000 jobs and attract significant investment. The plan includes a free trade zone, a third terminal, and an industrial park, with the goal of transforming the airport into a regional aviation hub. The project's approval comes as Taiwan's economy struggles, but the island has seen a surge in tourist arrivals, largely due to improved ties with China.

images.alt_text: Coming up: Taoyuan International Airport will be transformed into an 'aerotropolis' with a free trade zone, a third terminal and an industrial park to house goods distribution and aviation related industries. - PHOTO: AFP

site_title: Surge in buying and buybacks
summary: Singapore Exchange filings show a surge in buying and buybacks by directors and substantial shareholders between Feb 17-21, with 26 purchases worth $8.76 million and 30 repurchases worth $5.33 million. Courts Asia and Koh Brothers Group resumed buying back shares after releasing earnings results, while GP Batteries International and Aspial Corporation made significant purchases. However, some substantial shareholders, including Asia-Pacific Strategic Investments and Frencken Group, sold shares. The buybacks and sales were largely driven by the companies' earnings results, with some shares rising and others falling.

site_title: A timely $500m ICT carrot for SMEs
summary: Singapore's government plans to spend $500 million over three years to support small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in adopting information and communication technology (ICT) innovations, experimental solutions, and high-speed connectivity. The initiatives aim to boost productivity and economic growth among SMEs, which are the largest employers in the country. The subsidies will cover areas such as mobile devices, mechanized systems, and internet connectivity, targeting those that can benefit from transformational or growth-oriented ICT-based solutions.

site_title: Building capabilities with a social bent
summary: Singapore's Budget 2014 emphasized building the country's medium-term capability with a social bent, focusing on supporting the elder generation through the Pioneer Generation Package, a $8 billion universal healthcare concessions system. The budget also aimed to boost productivity, defying the aging population and diminishing land resources, with a small planned deficit of 0.3% of GDP. The government introduced new measures, such as the "PIC+" and extended tax deductions for R&D expenditure, to support firms in building capability and investing in productivity-boosting measures. The fiscal position remains strong, allowing for expansion of big-ticket programs and alleviating the sandwiched middle-income households.

site_title: Second LNG terminal to be built in the east
summary: Singapore is set to build its second liquefied natural gas (LNG) terminal in the eastern part of the island to enhance energy security and grow the LNG industry. The new terminal will provide a strategic buffer and support the development of ancillary services. The government aims to diversify LNG import infrastructure and prepare for the possibility that demand for natural gas may be met entirely by LNG. The investment will also support the growth of gas-related businesses and promote Singapore as a hub for LNG activities in Asia.

site_title: SingHaiyi upbeat as it unveils third US acquisition
summary: SINGHAIYI GROUP, a property developer, has unveiled its third US acquisition, a US$24.4 million site in California that will be turned into a high-end continuing care retirement community. The company aims to consolidate its shares and move to the mainboard by next year, with a post-consolidation target of 50 cents per share. SingHaiyi has spent US$102.5 million on US investments and plans to obtain bank borrowings to recycle capital, positioning itself for a growing market in the US.

site_title: New Asian hedge fund assets in 2013 down a fifth at US$3.85b
summary: Hedge funds launched in Asia in 2013 raised US$3.85 billion, down 20% from 2012's record US$4.74 billion. The number of new funds increased by 10% to 71, but launch sizes got smaller. This is attributed to investors being less attracted to the industry in 2013, one of the quietest years since the 2008 global financial crisis.

site_title: RM1m floor price won't impact Iskandar projects
summary: The new RM1 million floor price for foreign property buyers in Iskandar Malaysia is unlikely to significantly impact the economic zone, according to a property consultant. Only about one in five buyers are foreigners, with most purchasing properties costing more than RM1 million. Exemptions in areas like Medini and Putri Harbour will also minimize the impact. Realtors believe a three-to-four-year property boom has led to a more cautious market, with fears of oversupply in luxury units, particularly in Iskandar. Experts predict the oversupply will self-regulate in the long term.

site_title: BOC Singapore sells 3b yuan 'Lion City' bonds
summary: BOC Singapore has sold 3 billion yuan (S$620 million) 'Lion City' bonds, the largest yuan bond deal in Singapore, with orders exceeding 9 billion yuan. The two-year and five-year bonds were priced at 3.30% and 4% respectively, with 52% of investors from Singapore and 25% from Asia. The issuance reflects Singapore's increasing status as an offshore renminbi centre, with BOC's general manager citing the continued internationalisation of RMB as a leading currency.

site_title: Berlin's Tegel outpaces rivals as doomed airport draws travellers
summary: Berlin's Tegel airport saw a 7.9% passenger growth last year, surpassing other major Western European hubs like London Heathrow and Frankfurt. The airport's boom is its final act, as a new, 4.5 billion-euro replacement hub is set to open. Tegel's passenger numbers rose from 19.6 million in 2013 to 26 million overnight guests in 2014, making Berlin the 3rd European city destination and 4th in Germany. Despite being a relic of the Cold War era, Tegel's unique design has contributed to its enduring popularity.

site_title: Yanlord Q4 profit jumps 85%
summary: Yanlord Land Group reported a 85% year-over-year increase in fourth-quarter net profit, driven by higher fair value gains on investment properties. The company's net profit for the quarter ended December 31, 2013, was 1.1 billion yuan, up from 590 million yuan in the same period last year. The full-year net profit fell 19% to 1.47 billion yuan, due to lower other operating income and higher administrative expenses. Revenue for the full year increased 9% to 11.28 billion yuan.

site_title: Hagel to downsize army, eliminate all attack jets
summary: Defence Secretary Chuck Hagel plans to downsize the US Army to its smallest force since World War II and eliminate Air Force attack jets in a new spending proposal. The proposal aims to shift the military away from protracted foreign occupations, making it capable of defeating any adversary but too small for prolonged engagements. This move takes into account government austerity and the need to end costly land wars, with officials describing it as the first Pentagon budget to aggressively push the military off the war footing adopted after the 2001 terror attacks.

site_title: Chinese developers increase promotions for projects
summary: Chinese property developers are increasing promotions for suburban housing projects amid a slowdown in property prices, a sign that a slowdown may be spreading beyond major cities. In smaller cities, prices are falling, causing concern among investors. The government has a goal to cool the frothy property market, but a sharp fall in prices could have huge economic consequences. Developers are offering discounts of 5-10% in some areas, and analysts predict a split between cities of different sizes, with tier-1 cities continuing to rise while tier-2 and tier-3 cities may see slowdowns.

site_title: Australia to buy 8 Boeing spy planes for A$4b
summary: Australia will purchase eight Boeing P-8A Poseidon long-range spy planes for A$4 billion, boosting its ability to patrol 2.5 million square km of marine jurisdiction. The purchase comes amid rising tensions in the region, particularly with China's growing interest in protecting its commercial sea lanes. The planes, designed to replace the Royal Australian Air Force's AP-3C Orions, will be delivered in 2017 and fully operational by 2021, with an option for a further four aircraft. The deal is expected to be worth more than US$2 billion for Boeing.

site_title: Viva's maiden DPS of 1.08 cents in line with forecast
summary: Viva Industrial Trust announced a distribution per stapled security (DPS) of 1.08 cents for the period Nov 4 to Dec 31, 2013, slightly below its forecast. The trust reported income available for distribution of $6.4 million, driven by higher rental income and lower marketing expenses. Earnings per stapled security were 0.135 cents, with an annualised distribution yield of 8.8% based on its closing share price. The trust expects to benefit from government measures to lengthen lease periods and stabilize the industrial property market.

site_title: Sembmarine's Q4 profit up 9.2%, boosted by rig-building
summary: SembCorp Marine's Q4 net profit rose 9.2% to $182.4 million, driven by rig-building projects and operating income. Excluding non-operating items, the net profit was 45% higher. Revenue recognition from its rig-building segment contributed to a 22.8% increase in top-line revenue. The company proposes a final cash dividend of 8¢, the same as in the previous year.

site_title: Choppy equity markets push investors to bonds
summary: Investors are flocking to bonds amid choppy equity markets, driven by a small supply of new deals and a stronger Singapore dollar. The Markit iBoxx SGD corporate total return index reached an all-time high in February, while the Thomson Reuters/SGX SFI corporate bond index has seen its best start to the year since 2009. Low interest rates and concerns about the US Federal Reserve's tapering of bond purchases are also supporting the bond market, with yields declining and gold prices rebounding.

site_title: Understanding Reit structures
summary: Real estate investment trusts (Reits) in Singapore offer investors a yield of 5-8% and are easily traded on the stock market. Reits are structured as companies, with a sponsor company that feeds the Reit with cash-generating properties. The Reit manager optimizes the Reit's capital structure and identifies assets, while the property manager provides on-the-ground services. Fees are charged by the trust manager and property manager, which can be a sticking point for unitholders. To address this, some Reits have implemented performance fees that align incentives with unitholders, such as OUE Commercial Reit's performance fee based on distributions per unit. Reits have become popular with both buyers and sellers, providing steady streams of income and a place in every portfolio.

images.alt_text: Financial innovation: Reits break up large pieces of property into smaller, easily bought and traded chunks. They were introduced in Singapore in 2002, with the listing of CapitaMall Trust. - THE STRAITS TIMES FILE PHOTO

site_title: Services sector business receipts up 6.4% in Q4
summary: Singapore's services sector saw a 6.4% year-on-year increase in Q4 sales, slower than the revised 7.9% in Q3. Growth was broad-based, excluding recreation & personal services, which contracted 1.7%. Education services led with a 15.4% jump, while financial & insurance services grew 12.4%. The overall business receipts index increased 1.3% compared to Q3, and 6.2% compared to the same quarter last year.

site_title: Orderly share trading adds to confidence
summary: Singapore's boards of listed firms should exercise vigilance in monitoring price volatility, as excessive and prolonged share-price movements can negatively impact a company's public profile, distract management, and raise funding costs. Boards should be wary of volatility caused by non-systemic market forces, including rumors, price manipulation, and insider trading. Strong internal controls and effective investor relations can help mitigate such issues. Regulators will continue to monitor significant share-price movements and may impose curbs, including suspension or designation of shares, if necessary.

site_title: Thai govt to sell 20b baht of debt to fund rice subsidy
summary: Thailand's caretaker government plans to sell up to 20 billion baht of short-term debt to fund a rice-buying scheme. The Finance Ministry's Public Debt Management Office will auction eight-month, state-backed paper this week. This move aims to help cover the cost of the controversial rice-buying program, which has been a contentious issue in Thailand.

site_title: Veteran actors bring new scripts to life
summary: Veteran actors Daniel Jenkins, Amy Cheng, and Catherine Sng will star in a doublebill of Singapore Repertory Theatre's "Made In Singapore" series, featuring plays "A Wedding, A Funeral & Lucky, the Fish" and "Stand Behind the Yellow Line - Garisan Kuning". Written by Dora Tan and Michelle Tan, the plays explore changing attitudes towards marriage and the lines people draw around others, respectively. The doublebill runs from March 7 to 9 at DBS Arts Centre - Home of SRT.

site_title: HK to further connect with mainland China
summary: Hong Kong has proposed financial initiatives to further connect with mainland China, aiming to strengthen its position as the world's largest offshore yuan business centre. The initiatives include waiving stamp duty for the trading of all listed exchange-traded funds (ETFs) and mutual recognition of fund products. This move is expected to enhance Hong Kong's competitiveness and promote the development of the market. The proposals are part of Hong Kong's efforts to expand its offshore yuan businesses, which include yuan trade financing, financial products, and cross-border investment.

site_title: ArchXpo show to be pillar of Archifest
summary: The inaugural ArchXpo 2014, an international architecture and built environment exhibition, will be a key component of the Archifest festival held at Marina Bay Sands Singapore from Sept 29 to Oct 1, 2014. ArchXpo will feature 270 exhibitors over 8,000 square meters and cater to 7,000 trade professionals, serving as a bridge between ideas and physical manifestations. It will be held in conjunction with the International Facility Management Expo 2014 and LED+Light Asia 2014, providing a professional industry component to the festival.

site_title: Alice in Chains shrugs off the rust
summary: Alice in Chains frontman William DuVall discusses the band's enduring success, 12 years after the death of original lead singer Layne Staley. Despite selling over 25 million albums worldwide, DuVall downplays the fame, citing it as a "work" rather than a defining aspect of his life. The band's latest album, The Devil Put Dinosaurs Here, debuted at number two on the Billboard chart. Currently touring, Alice in Chains will co-headline the Singapore Rock Festival alongside Alter Bridge, Korn, and Rob Zombie.

site_title: Lobby group: Force airlines to follow EU emissions law
summary: The Transport & Environment lobby group is urging EU authorities to enforce compliance with the EU's emissions trading system (ETS) for foreign airlines, which failed to submit permits for intra-European flights in 2012. Airlines such as Air China and Air India are at risk of fines of 100 euros per tonne of carbon, with 98% of emitters complying with obligations. The EU aims to reach a decision on the shape of the ETS for aviation by next month, with limits on emissions from international flights to apply only to the portion of trips within the bloc's airspace from this year until 2020.

site_title: Real feel of action
summary: Local action film "re:solve" has opened in cinemas, marking the directorial debut of 35-year-old Randy Ang and starring Jimmy Wong as a former Special Tactics Unit member. The crime thriller, which cost $1.2 million to make, features real firearms and explosives, requiring the cast and crew to take weapons handling courses. Ang aimed to achieve a particular look for the film, with 75% of the shots taken at night. Despite the risks, Ang and Wong wanted to fill a void in the local movie industry with an action film, determined to add variety to the local scene.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: Several Asian companies reported their financial results for the fourth quarter and full year of 2013. Lee Kim Tah Holdings saw a 48% decline in Q4 profit, while Zagro Asia reported a 19% increase in FY2013 profit. YHI International and Sinwa swung into profit, while HG Metal Manufacturing reported a net profit of $3.4 million. Meanwhile, GLP entered into a strategic alliance with Guangdong Holdings to develop logistics and industrial facilities in Southern China.

site_title: Culinary sleight of hand
summary: Chef Han Li Guang's restaurant Labyrinth offers a unique culinary experience with dishes such as chilli crab ice cream, crab bisque mousse, and nitro-fried seafood. Despite limited professional experience, Han's passion and creativity shine through in his original and flavorful creations. The $78++ price tag is reasonable for a six-course meal that emphasizes flavor over gimmickry. While some dishes require refinement, Han's genuine sincerity and eagerness to learn and improve make for an impressive debut portfolio, earning Labyrinth a rating of 7.5.

site_title: Technical issue hits SGX webpage
summary: A technical issue caused the corporate announcements page on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) website to be down for most of the day, affecting users trying to access financial results from major listed companies. The issue was resolved around 7:30pm, with users advised to access announcements through an alternative link. The timing of the outage coincided with the end of the corporate results reporting season, with some traders expressing frustration at the inability to access important information.

site_title: First-time London homebuyers up 33%
summary: London's first-time homebuyers increased 33% in the fourth quarter compared to the previous year, driven by a recovering economy and government assistance. Total mortgages rose 50% in value to £3 billion, with 13,400 borrowers, and first-time buyers borrowed £198,900 on average. The government's Help to Buy scheme, offering equity loans of up to 20%, contributed to the increase, with £1 billion worth of mortgages sought.

site_title: LifeBrandz plans reverse takeover
summary: LifeBrandz, a loss-making nightlife group, plans a reverse takeover to become a hospitality developer. The company signed memorandums of understanding (MOUs) with shareholders to acquire stakes in Acteam International Co Ltd and 122 Middle Investment Pte Ltd, and dispose of existing businesses to Centurion Private Equity Ltd and Massive Collective Pte Ltd. LifeBrandz will transfer its shares to the Catalist board and issue new shares to raise $3.4 million. The acquisition aims to transform the group's businesses into hotel, resort, and hospitality businesses to enhance long-term shareholder value.

site_title: Singles fall for Japan apartment fraud
summary: A group of 12 singles in Japan filed a lawsuit against 14 firms, seeking 200 million yen in compensation for allegedly being tricked into buying apartments by real estate agents who feigned romantic interest. The plaintiffs, all in their 30s or early 40s, were led to believe they were heading towards marriage, but were instead pushed into buying condominiums at inflated prices. The National Consumer Information Center warned of a growing trend of such deception, with 42 reported victims in 2013.

site_title: The shoo-ins at the Oscars 2014
summary: The 86th Academy Awards, held in 2014, are expected to favor "Gravity" and "Dallas Buyers Club" in major categories. "Gravity" is predicted to win Best Picture, Best Director, and Best Original Score, while "Dallas Buyers Club" is expected to win Best Actor and Best Supporting Actor. Other predictions include "12 Years a Slave" for Best Picture, Best Director, and Best Supporting Actress, and "Her" for Best Original Screenplay and "Frozen" for Best Animated Feature Film. The awards ceremony is expected to be hosted by Ellen DeGeneres and will be broadcast live in 225 countries.

site_title: Wheelock Q4 loss trebles on project provision
summary: Wheelock Properties reported a Q4 loss of $91.3 million, tripling from the same period last year, due to a $110 million provision for a project. Revenue edged up 3% year-over-year to $29 million, while loss per share increased to 7.63 cents. The group's full-year profit was $40 million, down 37% from FY2012, and has proposed a first and final dividend of six cents per share. The Panorama development, which faced a slow take-up rate, was also affected by the provision.

site_title: Stamp duty forecast not proxy for property market
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam has forecast a 30% drop in stamp duty revenues to $2.8 billion for the year ending March 2015. However, an analysis by The Business Times suggests this may not necessarily indicate a dire year for the property market. Property consultants expect a 10% correction, while some experts believe the actual decline could be between 10.4% and 31.8%. The government's estimate may be conservative, and actual stamp duty revenues could be between $3.5 billion and $7 billion, which could impact the private property residential price index.

site_title: Design Studio Q4 profit rises to $6.25m
summary: Design Studio Group, a furniture manufacturer, reported a 165% increase in Q4 profit to $6.25 million, driven by a 17.9% rise in revenue to $63.4 million. Gross margin increased to 19.3%, boosted by higher margins in completed projects and cost efficiencies in its China production facility. This marks a significant improvement from the previous Q4 2012 net profit of $2.38 million.

site_title: CAO's Q4 net dives 25.7% to US$13.5m
summary: China Aviation Oil (CAO) reported a 25.7% year-on-year decline in Q4 net profit to US$13.5 million, mainly due to lower contributions from associates. Revenue edged 1.2% lower to US$4.35 billion, driven by lower jet fuel prices. The company's earnings per share fell 25.1% to 1.88 US cents. Despite this, CAO's full-year net profit rose 6% to US$70.2 million, driven by higher gross profit and share of profits from associates.

site_title: Marginal rise in Venture's Q4 net
summary: Global technology company Venture Corporation posted a 0.1% increase in fourth-quarter net profit to $38 million, with a 6.1% net margin. Revenue rose 5.1% to $622.9 million. For the full year, net profit decreased 6.1% to $131.1 million, due to a 2.4% decline in revenue and higher income tax expenses. The company declared a final cash dividend of 50 cents per share.

site_title: A 'levelling up' budget
summary: Singapore's Budget 2014, unveiled by Finance Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam, is notable for its "levelling up" approach to addressing inequality, focusing on social initiatives such as healthcare subsidies, education, and housing support for lower and middle-income citizens. The budget provides $8 billion in funding for a lifetime healthcare package, expanded education subsidies, and wage support. The government also extends incentives for small and medium-sized enterprises, particularly in the areas of productivity and innovation, and technology adoption. However, critics argue that the budget lacks support for healthcare suppliers and may have missed opportunities to address property market concerns.

site_title: Thinking inside the Big Box
summary: Courts Asia, a regional retailer and electronics vendor, has grown from a pure furniture store into a sustainable business despite facing challenges. CEO Terry O'Connor attributes the company's success to its long-term focus, risk management, and community involvement. Courts has experienced a 28.8% decline in net profit for the first nine months of 2013, but has maintained revenue growth and is expanding into new markets, including Indonesia. The company is opening its first megastore in Bekasi, Indonesia, and is cautiously optimistic about the Indonesian market. O'Connor emphasizes the importance of community service and reinventing the business to ride out short-term bumps.

site_title: Yongnam's revenue up 20%, profit plunges 87%
summary: Yongnam Holdings reported a 20% revenue increase to $362 million in 2014, but a 87% plunge in net profit to $5.5 million. The company attributed the profit drop to cost overruns and lower margins from a change in project mix. Despite this, CEO Seow Soon Yong expects the first half of 2014 to be challenging, but predicts gross profit margins to normalize to 20% by year-end. Yongnam is bidding for potential projects worth up to $300 million and is also a contender for Myanmar's Hanthawaddy International Airport, with a potential contract value of $1 billion.

site_title: Building apps with little programming
summary: Progress Software has launched Progress Pacific, a cloud-based platform-as-a-service that enables users with little to no programming knowledge to build and deploy applications quickly. The platform offers point-and-click, drag-and-drop tools and supports business process management, mobile app development, and decision logic. Since its launch, Progress Pacific has helped independent software developers in Vietnam, the Philippines, and Australia bring new applications to market, with one example being a healthcare system provider that shortened its development time by half. The platform has also contributed to 100% growth in Progress' APJ revenue.

site_title: Weibo's IPO: Investors should be wary
summary: Weibo, China's version of Twitter, is planning a US$500 million initial public offering despite already being listed on parent Sina Corp. The move is seen as a response to high tech valuations, but investors may be skeptical. Weibo's revenue grew 34% in the last quarter, driven by a tie-up with Alibaba, and could potentially reach US$620 million in 2014. However, investors are being asked to pay a higher value for Weibo after a partial spin-off, which may be driven by chasing hot valuations rather than a genuine increase in value.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: China Fishery Group, a subsidiary of Pacific Andes Resources Development, can meet higher financing needs due to continued bank support and higher operating cash flow, despite a recent acquisition. Fitch Ratings has a negative outlook on the company due to a higher risk profile. RH Petrogas announced a $13.8 million write-off for unsuccessful exploration wells in Indonesia, while OKP Holdings reported a 62.1% decline in Q4 profit to $1.44 million. Kian Ho Bearings saw a 10% increase in earnings to $1.28 million.

site_title: Facebook - the telco's new friend?
summary: Facebook's partnership with Globe Telecom in the Philippines has led to a doubling of data and internet users on the telco's network, with 38 million mobile customers. This tie-up may influence how telcos generate revenue, as Globe saw strong mobile revenue growth before the partnership. Facebook co-founder Mark Zuckerberg stated this at the Mobile World Congress in Barcelona.

site_title: Ho Bee earnings soar on $489.6m revaluation gain
summary: Ho Bee Land's fourth-quarter and full-year net earnings soared to $506.1 million and $591.8 million respectively, driven by a $489.6 million revaluation gain from its Metropolis office project and rental income from its Rose Court office building in London. The group's revenue from property investment more than doubled to $25.7 million, while revenue from property development shrank 75% year-over-year. Ho Bee posted earnings per share of 87.4 cents and proposed a three-cent special dividend, with the group expecting earnings to be underpinned by its new projects and existing assets in 2014.

site_title: Despite Fed tapering, developed nations' bond prices stable
summary: US, European, and Japanese bond prices have remained stable over the past two months despite the US Federal Reserve's decision to taper its bond buying programme. Low inflation and funds' purchases have contributed to the stability, with yields below 2013 mid-year peaks. Bond bears' predictions of rising yields and falling bond prices have proven incorrect. Economists attribute the stability to low inflation, high government and consumer indebtedness, and pension funds' purchases as they require income to offset liabilities.

site_title: Wall Street-backed landlords take bad mortgage route
summary: Wall Street-backed landlords are increasing their purchases of non-performing loans, or NPLs, to acquire rental properties as foreclosed homes become scarce and housing prices rise. Companies like American Homes 4 Rent, Starwood Waypoint Residential Trust, and Altisource Residential are buying NPLs to expand their holdings, with some firms offering loan modifications to delinquent residents. The shift raises concerns that private equity firms may prioritize profits over keeping homeowners in their homes, potentially displacing residents.

site_title: Saccharine-sweet Disney
summary: Walt Disney's 20-year pursuit of Mary Poppins author PL Travers's rights to her classic book is dramatized in Saving Mr Banks. Disney (Tom Hanks) promised his daughters he'd make a movie, and after Travers (Emma Thompson) fended off Disney's initial offer, she begins to regret her decision when her career stalls. Travers travels to LA, where Disney and his team, including the Sherman Brothers, make their pitch, eventually convincing her to let them adapt her book into the beloved film. The story explores Travers's troubled childhood and its inspiration for the magical character.

site_title: Neeson's Die-Hard on a Plane
summary: Liam Neeson stars in the action-thriller Non-Stop, where he plays Bill Marks, an air marshal investigating a series of mysterious text messages threatening to kill someone on a plane every 20 minutes. As the plane is filled with potential suspects, Marks must use his skills to uncover the truth and save the plane, but the storyline is deemed too contrived and unbelievable. Despite this, Neeson's quiet confidence and inner calm make him a believable hero, and the film tries to convey a sense of unease among the audience.

site_title: More owners of luxury condos selling at a loss
summary: Luxury condo owners in Singapore are selling at a loss, with 7% of transacted units in prime districts 9, 10, and 11 selling at a loss in the first eight months of 2014, up from 5.5% a year ago. Fewer people are profiting from their resales, with only 62.2% enjoying capital gains. The low-rental environment is leaving more owners struggling to repay their mortgages, with yields under pressure. Analysts expect the trend of loss-making resale transactions to continue, but say it's unlikely to worsen significantly as long as economic conditions remain favorable.

site_title: Airbus faces battles over A330's future
summary: Airbus is facing challenges in securing the future of its A330, a wide-body jet that has been in service for 20 years despite being repeatedly predicted to be discontinued. Despite efforts to prolong its production cycle, analysts say time is running out for the 250- to 300-seat jet, with over 1,000 still in service. The A330 has outlived its A340 sibling and survived the introduction of lighter new jets like the 787 and A350, but its profitability is under threat as Airbus focuses on newer models.

site_title: Singapore firms surpass expectations in Q4: report
summary: Several Singapore-listed companies beat market forecasts in Q4, with about half of the covered companies exceeding analyst expectations. A Morgan Stanley report found Singapore had the highest proportion of better-than-expected performances among Asean countries. However, analysts are now turning more bearish on earnings estimates for the current year, with weaker expectations for 2014 results.

site_title: Sim Lian to buy 5 shopping malls in Australia
summary: Singaporean property group Sim Lian is acquiring five Australian shopping centers for A$133 million, entering the Australian market and expanding its portfolio. The centers, with a total area of 28,875 sq m, will include a Woolworths supermarket as anchor tenant. The acquisition, funded by internal funds and bank borrowings, is expected to smooth fluctuating development profits and align with Sim Lian's strategy of investing in high-quality assets with stable income streams. This is the group's second Australian acquisition, following a Sydney development purchase last September.

site_title: Super Group's profit up; proposes bonus issue
summary: Super Group, a maker of instant beverages, has proposed a one-for-one bonus share issue to boost trading liquidity. The company reported a 6% increase in net profit for its fourth quarter, driven by a stronger gross profit margin, forex gains, and a disposal gain. Net profit for the quarter was $22.6 million, up from $21.2 million a year ago. Revenue was flat, with sales of coffee and cup noodles increasing by 3% but food ingredients declining by 7%. The company also posted a 26% increase in full-year net profit to $100 million.

site_title: In everyone's interest to conclude TPP deal
summary: The US-led Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) free trade negotiations are at a critical stage, with 12 Pacific Rim countries, including Singapore, the US, Japan, and Australia, struggling to reach a broad agreement. Despite progress on major areas, issues such as Japan's auto and farm markets, state-owned enterprises, and intellectual property rights remain contentious. The US Congress faces opposition from House Democrats, and President Barack Obama's administration is under pressure to secure Trade Promotion Authority for fast-tracking approval. A speedy conclusion is seen as crucial to avoid a setback, with Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong warning that time is running out.

site_title: Air France warns of flight cancellations on Monday
summary: Air France warned of flight cancellations on Monday due to a looming strike by pilots over a dispute on contract terms for new hires. The airline expects to operate only 50% of scheduled flights, affecting tens of thousands of passengers and potentially incurring 15 million euros in extra costs. The dispute centers on the airline's plan to move popular leisure routes to its low-cost unit, Transavia, where crew members are paid less. Negotiations with union leaders continue through the weekend.

site_title: Art scene hots up in Manila
summary: Art collectors are flocking to Manila for its affordable and strong art market, with notable artists such as Rodel Tapaya, Manuel Ocampo, and Jose John Santos showcasing their work at the four-day Art Fair Philippines. Industry buzz suggests the Filipino art market is the hottest in South-east Asia, attracting art lovers and collectors like Melani Setiawan, a prominent Indonesian art collector and historian. The event aims to promote and celebrate Filipino art, providing a platform for local artists to gain international recognition.

site_title: Oil boom sparks congestion in Houston Ship Channel
summary: A sediment build-up in the Houston Ship Channel is threatening to disrupt $330 million a day in commerce, with the channel's century-old infrastructure struggling to keep up with the boom in oil and gas output. The channel, which handles over 400 vessels daily, is facing a shortfall in federal maintenance funding, with sediment accumulation cutting the channel's depth by 0.6 meters and increasing dredging costs by $20 million annually. The port authority is seeking additional funding to address the issue, which could impact the US economy, with the port's total economic impact estimated at over $499 billion nationwide.

site_title: No housing bubble in Singapore: Citigroup
summary: Citigroup has downplayed concerns of a housing bubble in Singapore, citing that the country's $203 billion of mortgages only accounts for 24.2% of property values. The lender believes that the majority of citizens live in government-built homes where many families have already paid off their mortgages, making it less likely for prices to drop significantly. Singapore's central bank and government have implemented measures to curb speculation, including tax increases and mortgage limits, which may help moderate the market.

site_title: Ethnic artistry
summary: The Sandalwood Room, a two-month-old ethnic homeware store in Singapore, offers a lavish inventory of handmade items from India, Turkey, and Syria. Founded by Jayashrree Mani, the store features 95% handmade products, including patchwork quilts, porcelain chinaware, and jewelry. Mani, who runs a successful machinery company in India, aims to share beautiful and unique items with others. The store's unique features include antique wooden doors and a restored historic shophouse, which adds to its ethnic charm.

site_title: Market unease likely to persist for the moment
summary: The US stock market is expected to remain volatile this week due to the Federal Reserve's policy statement and the Scottish vote on independence from the UK. A Scottish independence could lead to a 10% decline in the pound sterling, affecting the global economy. The US economy is showing signs of growth, while Europe and China are experiencing weakness. The Fed is likely to maintain its stimulus policy until mid-October, but may start to taper it. The market is anticipating a potential interest rate hike in 2015, with Treasury rates already rising.

site_title: Higher CPF contribution to have minimal impact on firms: DBS
summary: DBS Group Research reported that a proposed increase in Central Provident Fund (CPF) contribution for employers would have minimal impact on listed companies in labor-intensive sectors. The contribution increase, proposed by Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam, is expected to be capped at 1% of net profit. Analysts noted that sectors such as banks, retail, and transport are more labor-intensive, but the impact on these companies will be limited. Healthcare players are unlikely to benefit from the initiatives, and the construction sector is expected to remain underweight due to rising costs.

site_title: Analysts bullish on First Resources
summary: Citigroup maintains its "buy" call on Singapore-listed palm oil plantation company First Resources, citing its strong hectare growth and relatively young age profile. The company's analysts have set a target price of S$2.39-S$2.80, a premium over its current price. Despite a 20.6% drop in its share price since May 2014, First Resources is seen as a cheaper play compared to other plantation companies due to its lower valuation. The company's ability to control costs and grow downstream volumes is also seen as a key factor in its success.

site_title: Guilin moots China-S'pore park in Yangshuo
summary: Guilin, a South China city, has proposed a China-Singapore tourism park in Yangshuo, a scenic county, to develop it into an international tourist hub. Yangshuo attracts 11 million tourists yearly, with its Lijian river ranked among the 15 best in the world. Guilin Party Secretary Zhao Leqin proposed the idea to Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong during his visit, citing Yangshuo's potential for tourism development and existing business opportunities. The proposal aims to capitalize on the existing transportation links and Singapore's growing interest in China's tourism market.

site_title: Continued violence may risk Thailand's collapse: army chief
summary: Thailand's army chief, Prayut Chan-O-Cha, warned that the country risks "collapse" unless it pulls back from escalating violence after three children were killed in recent days, the worst political unrest since 2010. General Prayut urged reconciliation and talks, stating that troops are "ready to do their duty" but do not want to use force. Labour Minister Chalerm Yubamrung predicted more unrest, while the government faces a court ruling limiting its use of force against protesters. The country has seen 18 successful or attempted coups since 1932, with the current unrest deeply dividing the kingdom.

site_title: Vale signs iron ore shipping deal with Cosco
summary: Vale SA has signed a deal with China Ocean Shipping Co (Cosco) to transport iron ore, potentially resolving a two-year ban on its ships in China. The deal involves transferring ownership of four large iron ore carriers to Cosco and leasing them back for 25 years. This move aims to help Vale focus on mining and shore up its balance sheet by reducing its vessel ownership costs.

site_title: Online shopping - what's in store
summary: A recent survey suggests online shopping may significantly impact brick-and-mortar retailers, with companies adapting by investing in e-commerce platforms and digital marketing. Cisco Managing Director Joshua Soh notes the shift towards online shopping, stating it's essential for businesses to respond to the changing market. As the retail landscape continues to evolve, companies must prioritize digital transformation to remain competitive.

site_title: Lagarde favours affirmative action to boost 'womenomics'
summary: Christine Lagarde, the IMF's managing director, has expressed support for affirmative action to boost women's representation in key positions, citing the need for "womenomics" to address the labor shortage in Japan and other countries. She stated that introducing formal "quota" systems can ensure equal treatment under the law and promote women's empowerment. Lagarde's comments come as Japan aims to increase women's representation in leadership positions, with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's target of 30% by 2020.

site_title: GLP tightens its grip on China's logistics industry
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) has signed a strategic partnership with Sinotrans Logistics Investment Holding to develop a national network of logistics facilities in China. The deal will strengthen GLP's position as the top logistics solution provider in China, with the companies initially focusing on Shanghai and Guangdong. The partnership aims to reduce costs and improve efficiency in China's logistics industry, which continues to drive demand despite strong growth in domestic consumption.

site_title: Gender diversity and quotas
summary: Singapore's low board diversity, with only 8.3% of directorships held by women, has sparked frustration from Minister Grace Fu, who has suggested a gender quota as a possible solution. However, the author argues that quotas may not be the best approach, citing concerns over tokenism and undermining the achievements of qualified women. Instead, the focus should be on changing cultural mindsets and promoting diversity through initiatives such as aspirational targets for women directors, mandatory disclosures, and training programs. The government and companies must work together to address the issue and take a lead in promoting gender diversity in corporate governance.

site_title: Airbus, Qatar Airways settle dispute
summary: Airbus and Qatar Airways have resolved a three-month-old dispute blocking the delivery of the first A380 ordered by the Gulf airline. Qatar Airways had refused to take delivery due to concerns over the cabin interior quality, but no further details were provided. Meanwhile, Airbus has been holding off the maiden flight of the A320neo due to a "minor" technical issue, although its plan to fly the plane in the third quarter remains unchanged.

site_title: $ingapore Grand Prix: a costly affair
summary: The Formula One Singapore Grand Prix is considered a costly event, with Singapore ranking 13th out of 19 Grand Prix destinations in terms of affordability, according to TripAdvisor's TripIndex Racing. The cheapest ticket costs S$207.33, and including food, beverages, and accommodations, a spectator can expect to spend S$622.67. In contrast, Kuala Lumpur is the most affordable destination, with the entire experience costing just S$206.85. The most expensive ticket is found at the Monza circuit in Italy, costing S$877.50, but even then, the total cost is lower than in Singapore.

site_title: Halal wine with gold flecks
summary: Dubai has introduced a new type of halal wine that is non-alcoholic and contains 24-carat edible gold leaf. The US$150 bottle, called "halal" non-alcoholic sparkling white wine, is marketed as a luxurious and fun beverage. The wine is distributed by Lootah Premium Foods, and its head manager, Tony Colley, sees the product as a reflection of Dubai's opulent lifestyle. The wine's gold flecks are seen as a unique and frivolous addition, rather than having any functional purpose.

site_title: Hapag-Lloyd, CSAV tie-up wins EU's conditional approval
summary: Hapag-Lloyd and CSAV secured conditional European Union approval for their merger, creating the world's fourth-largest container shipping company. The deal, worth millions, aims to overcome the shipping industry's worst slump on record. Regulators' soft stance on concessions could lead to more consolidation in the industry. The merger, worth billions, is seen as a positive step for the shipping sector.

site_title: ChildAid 2014 brings back best performers
summary: ChildAid 2014, a charity concert, marks its 10th anniversary with a star-studded lineup of performers, including past and present child stars. The All-Stars Edition will feature pianist Abigail Sin and soprano Janani Sridhar, who have gone on to pursue successful careers in music. The concert aims to raise funds for The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund and The Business Times Budding Artists Fund.
