The shares of the three companies fell on the news, with Wilmar International, Goodman Fielder, and First Pacific experiencing declines of 1%, 1.56%, and 0.74% respectively.

images.alt_text: Massive recapitalisation needed: Goodman Fielder is A$549m in debt, and has some A$350m in capital expenditure planned in the next 2 years - PHOTO: BLOOMBERG

site_title: Bill to outlaw remote gambling tabled
summary: Singapore is set to enact the world's most restrictive laws on online and mobile gambling, with a bill tabled in Parliament to outlaw and criminalize remote gambling activities. The Remote Gambling Bill aims to block access to websites, payment channels, and advertising through measures such as blocking websites and payment channels, and the legislation is expected to come into force next year if passed.

site_title: Beijing may revamp unit of private shipbuilder
summary: China Rongsheng Heavy Industries Group Ltd, a private Chinese shipbuilder, is reportedly studying a possible restructuring of its Jiangsu unit due to financial struggles. The company has been notified by a government authority to consider restructuring assets, business, debt, and/or equity. The move comes after the company was listed among 51 shipbuilding facilities deemed worthy of policy support. Rongsheng's financial woes are attributed to the decline in ship orders, which fell to 20.5 million tonnes in 2012, forcing the company to seek government support and limit its ability to invest in new ships.

site_title: StarHub now offers 4G data roaming in 21 countries
summary: StarHub has expanded its 4G data roaming services to 21 countries, offering the same roaming rates as its existing 3G services. The 4G data roaming services are available on 25 mobile networks, surpassing its competitors SingTel and M1, which offer 4G roaming in 13 countries. StarHub plans to add more destinations in the coming months and is also upgrading its 4G base stations in Singapore to enhance in-building coverage and boost peak speeds.

site_title: Lippo to invest US$5b in retail and healthcare
summary: Indonesian conglomerate Lippo Group plans to invest up to US$5 billion in healthcare, food retailing, and telecoms in Vietnam, the Philippines, and Myanmar over 3-5 years. CEO James Riady identified these countries as key markets for expansion, citing diversification and new growth opportunities. Lippo aims to diversify its investments and tap into emerging markets in Southeast Asia.

site_title: Widower of 'morbidly obese' sick woman settles lawsuit with airlines
summary: A widower of a 56-year-old woman who weighed over 185 kg and had a disability has settled a lawsuit with airlines Lufthansa, Delta, and KLM, alleging they refused to transport her due to her weight and disability. The terms of the settlement were not disclosed. Vilma's husband claimed the airlines' actions led to her "wrongful death" after she died in October 2012 after being unable to return to her doctors in New York. The lawsuit accused the airlines of "recklessness, carelessness, negligence" in refusing to accommodate Vilma's needs.

site_title: Another potential deal for Midlink Plaza site?
summary: China's Nanshan Group is in talks to purchase the former Midlink Plaza site in Middle Road for approximately S$270 million. The 65-year leasehold property is being redeveloped into a 396-room boutique hotel and strata retail space. This deal comes after a previous proposal to inject the property into LifeBrandz as part of a reverse takeover deal was scrapped. Nanshan Group, which has acquired several properties in Singapore, is understood to be the Chinese party behind the bid, following its previous acquisition of the Park Regis Singapore hotel.

site_title: Slump in Japan's GDP worse than expected
summary: Japan's GDP dropped 7.1% in Q2, worse than the initially estimated 6.8% annualised contraction. This increase the likelihood of the Bank of Japan announcing fresh monetary stimulus, while reducing the chances of a planned sales tax hike next year. The drop was sharper than expected, following a surge in sales in Q1 ahead of the sales tax hike in April. Analysts say the decline raises doubts about the government's plan to increase the consumption tax.

site_title: Money managers back in the market for Singapore ETFs
summary: Money managers are increasing their presence in Singapore, with three-month inflows set to reach the highest level since 2009, according to Markit data. The city-state's shares are the most attractive among Asia ex-Japan and emerging-market equities, beating Hungary, Chile, and China, according to a Morgan Stanley study. Singapore's sovereign debt has returned 3% this year, and the benchmark Straits Times Index has rebounded 13% from its low in February, driven by the economy's quicker-than-expected expansion in the second quarter.

site_title: China shipbuilders' orders jump but earnings decline
summary: Chinese shipbuilders received 42.5% more orders, but saw a 21.5% decline in completed shipbuilding volume to 20.66 million DWT in the first seven months. Combined profits of the industry's 87 large shipbuilders dropped 8.5% to 4.07 billion yuan. The industry relies heavily on external demand, with ships delivered overseas down 11.9% to 18.12 million DWT. The market outlook is considered "not optimistic" due to overcapacity and fierce competition.

site_title: Early MH17 findings open up legal avenue for MAS
summary: A preliminary 34-page report by the Dutch Safety Board clears Malaysia Airlines of blame in the MH17 crash, concluding the Boeing 777 "broke up in the air" after being hit by high-energy objects. The report found no technical or operational issues with the aircraft or crew, but stopped short of pinning the blame on a missile attack. Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak welcomed the report, which suggests a possible legal angle for Malaysia Airlines if it is proven that a missile was responsible, but further investigation is needed to identify the perpetrators.

site_title: US expands air strikes to Iraq Sunni Arab heartland
summary: The US has expanded its air strikes in Iraq's Sunni Arab heartland, targeting Islamic State (IS) jihadists around a strategic dam on the Euphrates River. The strikes, conducted by US warplanes, aim to prevent the group from threatening the dam's security and flooding the area. This escalation marks the first time Washington has carried out air strikes in support of Sunni Arab militia forces. President Barack Obama will explain his plan to take on jihadist militants, seeking congressional support for his strategy to halt the militant group.

site_title: Pension systems need rapid reforms: EY
summary: EY's report "Building a better retirement world" emphasizes the need for rapid reforms in pension and retirement systems globally. The report identifies five critical areas: financial adequacy, financial sustainability, performance, efficiency, and effectiveness, as well as political aspects. It also highlights opportunities for pension providers to deliver social policy, including improving regulation and transparency. The report recommends rebalancing benefit expectations with financial resources and increasing focus on operational excellence, customer-centricity, and simplicity in complex systems.

site_title: Governance and corporate valuation
summary: Good corporate governance is essential for trust in capital markets, enabling funds to be allocated to innovation and economic growth. Companies with good governance structures generally enjoy premium valuations due to perceived lower risks, better operating performance, and reduced agency problems. Empirical studies have consistently shown a positive relationship between corporate governance and firm valuation. Effective governance can be achieved by a well-diversified board with various skills and independent perspectives, and by engaging in robust debate and considering strategic investment decisions.

site_title: New Bill tightens rules on using phone while driving
summary: Singapore has passed a new bill tightening rules on using mobile devices while driving. The Road Traffic (Amendment) Bill 2014 expands the scope of the offence to include all 'mobile communication devices', including tablet computers, and broadens the definition of 'use' to cover any function of the device, such as internet surfing or playing games. The bill aims to reduce distracted driving and improve road safety. The new rules will come into effect soon, with penalties for offenders yet to be determined.

site_title: Drones score a hit with businesses
summary: Drones are gaining popularity in the business world, with the global industry projected to reach $89 billion in the next decade. Companies in Singapore are using drones for various commercial applications, such as inspecting oil and gas facilities, detecting leakages, and performing aerial mapping and photography. However, the lack of international regulations poses accountability and safety issues, creating uncertainty for companies planning to expand globally. Experts emphasize the need for licensing, certification, and liability protection to ensure public safety while promoting drone development.

site_title: Consult business sector on policy, SCCCI urges govt
summary: The Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce and Industry (SCCCI) urges the government to consult businesses closely in policy-making and provide affordable business space, citing rising costs and falling profits among small and medium enterprises (SMEs). A survey found 82.7% of businesses faced rising costs, with 45.8% reporting a drop in profit margins. 97% of respondents were SMEs, with 88% being business owners and decision-makers. The SCCCI aims to support SMEs in navigating the challenging business environment.

site_title: Aspire proposals lauded; challenges seen
summary: Singaporean MPs have lauded the principles behind the Aspire proposals, which aim to address the issue of an over-supply of graduates and provide a dual vocational training model to better train and match a skilled workforce with industry demands. However, concerns were raised about the need for better communication, clarity, and a mindset change among the public and employers. The proposals were seen as a key piece in the government's economic restructuring jigsaw puzzle, but implementation challenges and practical problems, such as assessing competencies and track records, were also highlighted.

site_title: STI delivers, but returns lag peers
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) delivered a 9.6% yearly return over three years, lagging behind peers such as Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index (14.3%) and the US Standard & Poor's 500 (24%). Only four of the 30 STI counters experienced negative total returns, with Thai Beverage Public Co and ComfortDelGro Corp being the best performers, with total returns of 190.5% and 111.6%, respectively. The STI's returns were also lower than those of the ABF Singapore Bond Fund, which delivered a 1.2% three-year return.

site_title: Asean focusing on non-tariff barrier removal
summary: Asean countries aim to remove non-tariff barriers to enhance economic integration by 2015, with efforts including a self-certification system and the Asean Single Window. This will facilitate smoother customs procedures and lower costs for businesses. As part of Asean's post-2015 agenda, collaboration between governments and businesses is crucial to foster positive change. The Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) negotiations with China, India, and other countries are also ongoing, aiming to establish simple and flexible trade rules.

site_title: Abbott, get back to repairing economy
summary: The Australian government, led by Prime Minister Tony Abbott, is struggling to pass budget measures despite repealing taxes like the mining tax and carbon tax. Repealing taxes seems to be the easy part, while budget reforms face resistance. Abbott's reform agenda is stalled, including a paid parental leave scheme and changes to welfare payments. To distract from its economic woes, the government is focusing on foreign events, such as joining the US-led fight against ISIS. However, experts warn that Abbott should prioritize repairing the economy, which is facing a budget emergency, growing at its slowest pace in over a year.

site_title: China imports in August down for 2nd straight month
summary: China's imports unexpectedly fell for the second consecutive month in August, posting its worst performance in over a year, amid concerns about domestic demand. Imports declined 2.4% from a year ago, while exports rose 9.4% and the trade surplus reached a record $49.8 billion. The data suggests that Chinese demand is fizzling, and policymakers may need to loosen policy further to revive the economy. The cooling housing market and reduced credit supply are also weighing on the economy, with analysts predicting that the yuan could rise further.

site_title: Ryanair in talks to buy 100 Boeing planes
summary: Ryanair is in talks to purchase at least 100 Boeing 737 MAX jets with extra seats in a potential $10 billion deal. The deal, which could be finalized in days or weeks, comes after Boeing announced plans to offer more seating in its 737 MAX. If reached, the agreement would be one of the largest orders for Boeing in recent years.

site_title: Life sciences firm Esco sets up S$10m venture fund
summary: Singapore-based life sciences firm Esco has set up a S$10 million venture capital fund, Esco Ventures, to invest in early-stage life sciences, medical, and healthcare technologies over three years. The fund aims to provide mentorship and support to local scientists and researchers to commercialize their ideas globally. Esco president and CEO Lin Xiangqian, who has hands-on experience in the industry, will use his expertise to help startups succeed. This move aims to boost the local startup scene and create higher-value jobs in Singapore.

site_title: Delivering a unique travel experience
summary: Singapore's tourism industry faces challenges, and new concepts are needed to keep visitors coming. A recent article by Landor Associates, led by President Nick Foley, explores innovative ideas to revitalize the city-state's tourism scene. However, no specific details on new tourism concepts are provided in the given article.

site_title: ABN Amro rises again
summary: ABN Amro, Singapore's oldest surviving bank, has made a significant comeback after being rescued by the Dutch government during the global financial crisis. The bank now employs 520 people in Singapore, with 330 working for the private bank, and reported a 190 million-euro profit increase in the first half of 2014. ABN Amro aims to increase international contribution to 17-18% and international revenues to 20-25% by 2017, with a focus on growth in Singapore and Asia.

site_title: Harvard receives US$350m from HK developers
summary: Harvard University received a record $350 million donation from the Morningside Foundation, a family foundation of Hong Kong-based real estate developers Gerald and Ronnie Chan. The gift will focus on addressing pandemics, humanitarian crises, and social threats to health. The Harvard School of Public Health will be renamed the Harvard T H Chan School of Public Health in honor of the Chans' late father. The donation will provide resources for researchers and students, including financial aid and new classrooms and computer resources.

site_title: Resale prices of condos up a tad in August
summary: Resale prices of non-landed private homes in Singapore rose 0.4% in August, led by city area and city fringe properties, but analysts caution this is not a turnaround in the market. The increase is attributed to pent-up buyers' interest, while the weak leasing market continues to deter buyers. Despite a slight increase in resale prices, analysts expect a 4-8% drop in the next 12 months, primarily due to city-area condominiums.

site_title: S'pore firms' investments in US rise to nearly US$20b
summary: Singapore companies invested nearly US$20 billion in the US in 2014, with income rising from US$720m in 2012 to US$808m. This is the highest among Asia-Pacific economies, with Japan and South Korea also posting higher incomes. The US Department of Commerce reported a 12% increase in total Asia-Pacific investments in the US, with Japan and South Korea accounting for over half the increase. Foreign investments in the US yielded a total of US$163.91 billion in income last year, with most of it going to European companies.

site_title: Dubai's 2nd airport eyes 120m passenger capacity
summary: Dubai's Al-Maktoum International Airport aims to expand its passenger capacity to 120 million per year within eight years. The expansion, launched in the first phase, will enable Emirates to relocate its operations from Dubai International Airport. Dubai Airports chief Paul Griffiths stated that the plan is part of a long-term strategy to shift growing operations from the current airport.

site_title: Asian VLCC rates to stay steady this week
summary: Asian VLCC rates are expected to remain steady or slightly increase this week as charterers fix remaining cargoes for September. Charterers took advantage of lower rates for Middle East-to-Japan voyages, pushing rates higher. Rates for West Africa to China also rose, while aframax tanker rates from Southeast Asia to East Coast Australia fell. Clean tanker rates from Singapore to Japan remained steady. Charterers have covered most of their cargo requirements for the first 20 days of September, with around 125 VLCC cargoes from the Middle East expected for the month.

site_title: Singapore working out drone regulations
summary: Singapore's Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) is developing local regulations for drones, following global efforts to standardize unmanned aerial vehicle operations. Current regulations only apply to drones weighing 7kg or less, while heavier drones require permits and follow similar rules as manned aircraft. The proposed framework, to be released for public consultation, aims to address safety concerns and pave the way for commercial drone operations. The CAAS is working in parallel with international standards set by the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO).

site_title: Temasek, JTC say entities' merger unlikely to impact industrial rents
summary: Temasek Holdings and JTC Corporation stated that a proposed merger of their entities involved in urban planning and development, including Ascendas and Surbana International Consultants, is unlikely to impact industrial rents in Singapore. The entities are in exclusive talks to explore the merger, but no further details were provided. The companies aim to enhance their services and capabilities, but their merger is not expected to affect the rental rates for industrial spaces in Singapore.

site_title: Scottish fish merchants on edge as vote looms
summary: Scottish fish merchants are on edge ahead of the country's independence referendum on September 18. The looming vote has raised concerns about potential barriers to trade with England, which could increase paperwork and costs for exporters. The port authority in Peterhead, a major wholesale fish market, plans to build a new market hall despite these concerns. Fish merchant Gary Mitchell fears that the increased paperwork and potential charges could lead to a significant upheaval in the industry. The outcome of the referendum remains uncertain, but the impact on Scotland's fishing industry is already being felt.

site_title: Foodie finds in Seah Street
summary: New restaurants, Restaurant SELA and Tess Bar & Kitchen, have opened in Seah Street, offering solid dining experiences. Both restaurants fill a gap between "concept" restaurants and cafes, with comfortable pricing and reliable cooking. SELA boasts a chef with experience at indie favourite Lolla, while Tess Bar & Kitchen features chef Martin Wong, formerly of L'Atelier de Joel Robuchon. The restaurants offer a range of dishes, from salads to lamb ribs, with an emphasis on balance and care in cooking. Both SELA and Tess have received a 6.5-star rating, indicating a promising dining experience.

site_title: ANZ launches new measure of confidence
summary: ANZ has launched the ANZ-Roy Morgan Singapore Consumer Confidence Index, a monthly survey of 1,000 people aged 14 and above, providing an earlier gauge of consumer sentiment. The index will be released on the last Wednesday of each month, ahead of the government's retail sales data. This new measure aims to address the gap in timely data on consumption patterns, offering insights into economic trends and consumption trends, particularly for lower-income cohorts affected by tight foreign labor policies.

site_title: Taking the bump out of turbulence
summary: Airlines have improved their ability to navigate through turbulence and bad weather, thanks to advanced computing power, satellite technology, and radar systems. This has led to a decrease in delays and injuries, with 36% of all airline delays caused by weather last year, down from 50% in 2003. New technologies, such as sensors on planes and real-time weather maps, allow for more accurate forecasting and in-flight adjustments. However, climate change may increase turbulence over the North Atlantic, and airlines still face challenges such as congested airspace and mechanical problems.

site_title: Crafting spaces
summary: Japanese interior designer Norihiko Shinya, vice-president of Super Potato, emphasizes the importance of harmonious storytelling in hotel design and high entertainment value in restaurant design. He attributes his success to understanding local cultures and traditions, as well as using materials like iron, timber, and natural stone to express nature. Shinya also employs "offsite construction" or "pre-fab" method to meet client briefs, schedules, and budgets, resulting in successful projects in hotels and restaurants worldwide, including the Grand Hyatt Singapore and The Island Shangri-La in Hong Kong.

site_title: Ascott's mission: 80,000 serviced apartments by 2020
summary: Ascott, a CapitaLand outfit, aims to more than double its serviced apartments to 80,000 by 2020, driven by growing demand from travelers. Despite challenges in acquiring assets due to rising real-estate prices, the company plans to expand in second-tier Chinese cities, India, and London. Ascott is also exploring franchising opportunities and online booking channels to boost sales, and may enter new markets such as the US and Africa if feasible. The company's CEO, Lee Chee Koon, emphasizes the importance of patience and adapting to changing market conditions.

site_title: Ukraine truce in jeopardy after shelling by govt and rebel forces
summary: A truce in Ukraine's conflict is at risk after shelling by both government forces and pro-Russian separatists. A civilian was killed and three injured in an overnight attack in Mariupol's Skhidny district, while separatists reported losses from Ukrainian fire in Makiyivka and Zuyevka. The Ukrainian National Security Council says shelling constitutes a truce violation, despite the head of the council stating there's no talk of ending the ceasefire. The incident jeopardizes the fragile peace agreement intended to stem months of bloodshed.

site_title: RBS planning to raise up to US$4b from US unit's IPO
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) plans to raise up to $4 billion from the initial public offering (IPO) of its US unit Citizens Financial Group, the largest US bank share offering this year. RBS, 81% owned by the UK government, will sell 140 million shares at $23-$25 each, with a further 21 million shares available for sale. The IPO is expected to significantly improve RBS's capital and is seen as an important milestone for both RBS and Citizens. The separation of Citizens from RBS is expected to boost the UK bank's core capital adequacy ratio by 2-3 percentage points.

site_title: US direct investments in S'pore climb to US$154b
summary: US direct investments in Singapore reached a record high of US$154.44 billion in 2013, making Singapore the second-largest country for US investments in the Asia-Pacific region after Australia. This represents a 10.8% increase from 2012 and a US$43.7 billion jump from 2012. Singapore also yielded the largest investment income for US companies in the region, with US$22.67 billion in 2013. Globally, US investments in Europe generated the highest returns, followed by the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Buyers active, but sellers are absent
summary: Buyers in Singapore's stock market remained active in the first week of September, with 21 firms recording 36 purchases worth S$17.3 million. In contrast, sellers were absent. The buyback activity among listed firms increased with 13 companies posting 50 repurchases worth S$11.9 million. Several notable transactions included Global Invacom Group buying back shares for the first time since October 2013 and UOL Group Chairman Wee Cho Yaw purchasing 1.39 million shares at S$6.41 each. Other executives, including GRP Ltd's Kwan Chee Seng and Health Management International's Gan See Khem, also made significant on-market trades.

site_title: Cyber defence is not just about technology
summary: Cyber defence is not just about technology, but rather an integrated approach that considers people, processes, and technologies. A holistic view is necessary to turn information risk into a business advantage. Organisations should focus on leadership, people, information risk management, business continuity, and compliance to regulations. They should also invest in critical talent, update skills, and monitor staff attitude to combat cyber threats. A comprehensive programme is needed to address cultural weaknesses and prevent data leakage, both accidentally and intentionally. Prioritising and managing information asset lifecycle is crucial, and organisations must be prepared against cyber attacks with a good resiliency plan.

site_title: Huge canal schemes may be missing trade boat: analysts
summary: A new trade route from Asia to the US east coast may reduce the importance of the Suez and Panama canals, according to analysts. The Suez Canal expansion and a proposed second canal in Egypt and Nicaragua may not be enough to offset this shift. The Panama Canal's widening to accommodate larger ships may have some impact on container trades, but it's unlikely to be revolutionary. The efficient overland distribution network from California to the US east coast also provides an alternative route. Experts believe the Suez Canal's importance is waning, particularly for oil imports from China and India.

images.alt_text: Increasing traffic flow: Egypt's president has launched plans for a second Suez canal built parallel to the existing one. - PHOTO: REUTERS

site_title: All the better to clinch big projects with
summary: Temasek Holdings and JTC Corp are merging four infrastructure and development units to form a merged entity that can offer integrated solutions for large-scale urbanization projects. The combined entity, expected to have annual revenue of over S$1 billion, will boast expertise spanning the value chain in urban development. This move is seen as a strategic response to the predicted rapid urbanization trend, which is expected to drive 80% of global GDP growth over the next decade. The merger may also have trickle-down benefits for other Singapore companies, particularly in the construction and development sectors.

site_title: Craft vodka made from cow's milk
summary: A UK-based company, Black Cow Vodka, has successfully produced vodka from cow's milk, challenging conventional spirit-making methods. The vodka, made from cow's milk, is available for purchase on their website. This innovation showcases the versatility of ingredients in crafting spirits, highlighting the possibility of creating unique beverages from unconventional sources.

site_title: A spirited craft
summary: The craft spirits industry is booming in Singapore, with new entrants and existing players alike capitalizing on the trend. Craft spirits are typically defined as small-batch, independently owned distilleries with maximum annual sales of 52,000 cases. However, the industry is facing challenges, including high prices due to high alcohol taxes, making mass adoption difficult. Despite this, distributors and importers are optimistic about the market's growth potential, with some even opening "spirits-forward" bars to educate consumers and promote their products. As the industry expands, the definition of "craft" may become diluted, with larger organizations slapping the label on mass-produced items.

site_title: Serviced apartments gaining favour over hotels
summary: Serviced apartments are gaining popularity among business travelers due to shrinking corporate budgets and the need for longer-term transient homes. These apartments offer a more home-like experience, complete with kitchens and laundry areas, at a lower cost than hotels. Hospitality operators, including traditional hoteliers, are entering the market to capture the trend. New entrants, such as Mapletree Investments and Banyan Tree, are developing serviced apartment brands, while existing players are expanding their offerings. Industry experts expect the trend to continue, with demand driven by globalization and the rise of global mobility.

site_title: All that jazz
summary: The new Honda Jazz, the third generation, boasts significant improvements in technology, performance, and safety features. With an all-new body and platform, it offers a spacious cabin, better headroom, and ample rear legroom. The 1.5-litre DOHC i-VTEC engine provides strong torque and good fuel economy, while the seven-step continuously variable transmission offers smooth and linear shifting. Safety features include Vehicle Stability Assist, Hill Start Assist, and Emergency Stop Signal. Despite its unattractive design, the Jazz RS is a great drive, with a precise steering and instant response.

site_title: Iraq takes a new tack to seize tanker off Texas coast
summary: Iraq's Oil Ministry has asked a US judge to change its legal arguments in an attempt to seize $100 million in Kurdish crude waiting in a tanker off Texas since July. The move comes after a judge ruled last month that he didn't have jurisdiction under admiralty law. Iraq is now citing maritime and Texas statutes to recover the crude, which was exported from wells in the northern Iraqi region of Kurdistan without permission. The tanker's ownership dispute remains unresolved.

site_title: Week when brokers talked of 'false starts' and 'false alarms'
summary: The Straits Times Index surged 20 points on Wednesday before the European Central Bank's meeting, boosted by hopes of a Ukraine ceasefire, but weakened afterwards. The index gained 14 points for the week. The market's performance was also influenced by traders exploiting the "buy in anticipation, sell on news" strategy. Hopes of a permanent ceasefire were dashed when talks failed.

site_title: New measure shows plunge in August consumer sentiment
summary: Singapore's consumer confidence index dropped 16.9 points to 119 in August, a sharp decline from July's record high, according to a new private-sector measure. This decline follows a surge in positive sentiment during the Great Singapore Sale. The August reading is in line with the year-to-date average, indicating a stabilization in consumer sentiment.

site_title: Goldilocks play pushes stocks to record highs
summary: Stocks reached record highs last week despite a weak jobs report, driven by the "Goldilocks" theory that growth should be strong enough to boost corporate profits but not hot enough to prompt interest rate hikes. The US economy added only 142,000 jobs in August, far short of the monthly average. Fed officials argue that the jobs market remains "slack" and that rate hikes may be delayed, while others believe the economy is on the mend and a rate hike is imminent. Investors will face tests this week with key data releases, including Apple's product launch and retail sales report.

site_title: ISOTeam to add more to its toolkit
summary: ISOTeam, a Singapore-based company, plans to expand its services to include handyman services, following its successful private home retrofitting business. The company has not been affected by the current soft patch in the Singapore property market, and its revenue has remained steady. ISOTeam has spent 14 months listed on the Catalist and has been rejuvenating mature housing estates for 16 years. The company aims to leverage its expertise in restoring and repainting estates to offer handyman services, increasing its toolkit.

site_title: Sun Venture buys Straits Trading block for S$450m
summary: Straits Trading Company has sold its office tower, Straits Trading Building, to Singapore-based Sun Venture Group for S$450 million. The sale price of S$2,800 per square foot is a 6-year high for an office block, making it one of the most expensive transactions in the market. Straits Trading expects to realize an estimated capital gain of S$39 million from the sale. The buyer, Sun Venture, is a real-estate developer and investor with a portfolio of commercial assets.

site_title: Around Town
summary: The Sentosa Buskers Festival is taking place this weekend at Palawan Beach and Beach Plaza, featuring international and local performers showcasing their talents in sword-swallowing, juggling, and magic. International acts include Aeriel Manx from Australia and Francis Gadbois from Canada, while a local tribal group Flaming Matrix will perform a fire show. The festival offers a variety of entertainment options for attendees.

site_title: Garena joins global billionaire club
summary: Garena, a Singapore-based social gaming start-up, has joined the global billionaire club with a valuation of US$1 billion, according to the World Start-up Report. This brings the total number of mobile Internet companies worth at least a billion dollars to 25, with 12 from the US, nine from Asia, and three from Europe. Garena's valuation is attributed to its massive player base of over 100 million members since its founding in 2009, with an average annual growth of US$200 million.

site_title: Keppel Corp unit to acquire 10% stake in LNG carrier owner
summary: Keppel Corp's indirect wholly-owned subsidiary, KSI Production, has acquired a 10% stake in Golar Hilli Corp for US$50. The stake is part of a US$735 million contract for converting the Moss LNG carrier HILLI into a floating liquefaction vessel. Keppel Shipyard will also extend a US$21.69 million shareholders' loan to Golar Hilli. The acquisition strengthens Keppel's alignment with Golar LNG, a world's largest independent LNG carrier owner, and is expected to provide an attractive risk-adjusted return.

site_title: Boutique craft dream
summary: A Singapore-based couple, Richard and Simin Kayhan Ames, are launching Paper Lantern, a boutique craft distillery producing luxury spirits with local flavors. The initial range includes gin, passionfruit vodka, and Mandarin liqueur, all made in consultation with an Australian master distiller. The Ameses plan to eventually set up a full-fledged distillery in Singapore, with estimated costs ranging from $1 million to $1.5 million. The company aims to release its products through high-end restaurants and cocktail bars before expanding.

site_title: Jobs growth at 8-month low, labour force shrinks
summary: US employers hired the fewest workers in eight months in August, with 142,000 new jobs created, according to the Labor Department. The unemployment rate fell to 6.1%, but the labor force participation rate declined to 62.8%. More Americans dropped out of the labor force, and manufacturing saw no job growth. The slowdown in jobs growth is at odds with other labor market indicators, leading to concerns about sluggish wage growth and underutilization of labor resources.

site_title: Business briefing
summary: Businessman Ang Kok Teong acquired a 50.6% stake in China Kunda Technology Holdings for S$0.0729 per share, representing a 65.68% premium over the last transacted price. Meanwhile, Soilbuild Construction Group secured a S$47.6m contract, Stamford Tyres reported a 39% increase in Q1 earnings, and SMRT entered a 50:50 joint venture with Hailo Network Holdings. SPH unit ShareInvestor acquired a 60% stake in Waterbrooks Consultants for S$910,000, and Intraco bought a 70% stake in KA Group.

site_title: Sunny days ahead for REC Solar
summary: REC Solar, an Oslo-listed company, is experiencing a positive outlook due to a larger solar power market, higher US anti-dumping tariffs against Chinese manufacturers, and stable solar cell prices. These favourable factors have helped the company regain stability, providing a positive outlook.

site_title: Dietary fads: truth or fallacy?
summary: Research suggests that dietary fads may not be entirely effective in reducing LDL-C, or "bad" cholesterol. The main source of cholesterol is liver production, and saturated fat may have a greater impact on increasing LDL-C. A healthy diet high in vegetables, fruits, and whole grains, and low in sweets and red meats, is recommended. Low-glycaemic diets may not have a significant impact on heart health for non-diabetics, and excessive calorie consumption is detrimental regardless of glycaemic index. Reducing saturated fat, trans fat, and sodium salt intake can lower LDL-C and blood pressure, while moderate exercise has a minimal impact on cholesterol levels.

site_title: Eyeing the lucrative world of Asian sports
summary: The inaugural Sports Matters conference in Singapore aims to grow the sports sponsorship pie in Asia, building on conversations from last year's event. Key speakers include Sebastian Coe, Jamie Reigle, and Xavier Asensi, who will discuss globalization of sport, social media, and tapping into a wider fan base. The conference also highlights the launch of the Asian Sponsorship Association (ASA), with 35 corporate members and a goal of 100 companies by the end of the year. Jasper Donat, CEO of Branded, notes that Singapore's thriving sports industry and favorable market conditions made it the ideal location for the event.

site_title: White house
summary: Sri Lankan designer Lalin Jinasena and his wife Michelle Sielman, a fashion designer, have found their ideal home in Singapore's Holland Road area. The couple, who moved to Singapore two years ago, was drawn to the house's unfussy layout and attractive location, which features dappled sunlight in its rooms. The house, designed by two architects, was rented for a year before the couple decided to make it their permanent residence, citing the need for more space for their dog. The couple views the house as the perfect blend of form and function.

site_title: By the book
summary: Bookbinding, an ancient craft, is experiencing a resurgence among craft enthusiasts in Singapore. Despite the rise of e-readers, many readers appreciate the tactile experience of holding a physical book, with its distinct scent and feel. Afficionados are reviving the craft, with some even creating bespoke notebooks and stationery. Local bookbinding enthusiasts, including Winnie Chan and Adelene Koh, are sharing their passion and skills, offering classes and workshops. The craft requires investment in education, but the end result is a unique, handmade product that can't be replicated by digital means. With the rise of nostalgia and a desire for personalized, artisanal products, bookbinding is becoming increasingly popular among young adults.

site_title: Apple gets set to introduce bigger iPhones
summary: Apple is set to unveil its new iPhone 6 on September 9, featuring two screen sizes: 4.7 inches and a phablet category 5.5 inches. The devices will come with sapphire glass for a virtually indestructible and scratch-proof screen. They will also feature iOS8 operating system, a new processor, and a higher resolution screen. Additionally, Apple will announce its iWatch, a smartwatch with NFC chip and wireless charging capability. The devices are expected to generate huge demand and be among the best smartphones on the market.

site_title: Banks slow in going digital: report
summary: Many banks, including Singapore's traditional retail lenders, are slow in implementing digital services demanded by customers, despite growing competition from non-traditional banks. A Bain & Company report found that 90% of polled banks see the integration of physical and online platforms as crucial, but only 60% have a clear migration plan with budgets. This is expected to lead to branch closures and cost savings, with some banks potentially losing up to $120 million in costs.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: STI constituents remain unchanged following the latest quarterly review, with Keppel Land, UOL Group, CapitaCommercial Trust, Suntec Reit, and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding Holdings replacing ineligible constituents. Charisma Energy secured a US$72 million contract for offshore support vessels. TIH's Killian Court acquired a portfolio of assets for S$129 million. Eng Lam Contractors is recovering damages against Hong Hua Engineering owner Koh Lai Wah.

site_title: Made in Brazil, but just for Asia
summary: A Brazilian couple, Catarina Longman and Andreas Schneider, are launching Maracatu, a premium brand of cachaca, in Asia. The couple, who have lived in Singapore for four years, saw an untapped market for the Brazilian spirit and created a made-for-the-region marque. Maracatu is made from fermented sugar cane juice and distilled in small batches using traditional methods. The brand's premium cachaca is bottled at 38% ABV, a lower strength than most other versions, to appeal to Asian drinkers. The couple aims to promote Brazil through the brand and plans to introduce further editions of cachacas aged in different types of Brazilian wood.

site_title: Temasek, JTC plan to wed units, make cities
summary: Temasek Holdings and JTC Corporation, a Singapore state-owned entity, plan to merge their units to create an urban development behemoth. The merged entities will combine expertise spanning the value chain for urban development projects, with estimated annual revenue of S$1 billion. The move aims to capitalize on emerging markets' urbanization trend, with 45% of Fortune Global 500 companies expected to be from emerging markets by 2025. The merger is expected to preserve the companies' flexibility and not affect industrial rentals in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Temasek Holdings and JTC Corporation plan to create an infrastructure and development behemoth to ride the rising wave of urbanisation washing over emerging markets, the Singapore state-owned entities announced on Thursday - PHOTO: SPH

site_title: More firms leveraging IP for growth
summary: Companies in Singapore are increasingly leveraging intellectual property (IP) to drive growth, with patent filings and trademark applications rising 20% and 25% respectively in the last decade. The Intellectual Property Office of Singapore (IPOS) has introduced initiatives such as the IP Hub Master Plan, IP ValueLab, and the Global Patent Prosecution Highway network to support small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in protecting their IP. These efforts aim to make IP protection more accessible and affordable for SMEs, with IPOS estimating that it costs between S$10,000 and S$15,000 to draft and register a patent.

site_title: GIC giving PE firms a run for their money by investing directly
summary: Singapore's Government Investment Corporation (GIC) is investing directly in unlisted firms, bypassing traditional private equity funds, to achieve higher returns. The move, led by veteran executive Lim Kee Chong, has saved GIC on fees and given it greater control over deal structures and company management. This approach is expected to be emulated by other sovereign wealth funds as they seek to outperform traditional asset classes. GIC's direct investments have been made in companies such as Century Canning Corp, Metro Pacific Investment Corp, Netshoes, and Flipkart, marking a shift in the fund's strategy to become a more active player in private equity.

site_title: UOB partners Japan's ORIX for fund aimed at S-E A firms
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has partnered with Japan's ORIX to launch a US$200 million mezzanine fund targeting mid-sized South-east Asian companies. The fund, called United Orient Capital Fund, will provide expansion capital to these companies, offering an alternative to traditional financing. UOB is taking a 60% stake in the fund, while ORIX will invest in companies through loans or bond purchases. The fund aims to support companies' expansion plans and business development through mezzanine financing, a hybrid of debt and equity.

site_title: Refreshing whites
summary: Six white wines from Austria, Spain, New Zealand, Australia, and Germany have been shortlisted in The Business Times Wine Challenge 2014. Gruner Veltliner from Austria, Verdejo from Spain, and Riesling from Germany, New Zealand, and Australia showcase the versatility of these grape varieties. Austrian producers have regained prestige after a quarter-century wine scandal, while Spain's modern winemaking methods have elevated the quality of its wines. New Zealand's Sauvignon Blanc and Australia's Rieslings have gained international recognition, with Germany's Mosel Valley producing some of the world's best Rieslings.

site_title: Linc Energy starts ops at Arckaringa Basin
summary: Linc Energy Ltd has started operations in the Arckaringa Basin, South Australia, with the first rig expected to arrive on site later this month. The three-well drilling programme was selected based on a field appraisal study by shale expert Baker Hughes. This follows a lengthy appraisal process, with the first well expected to begin shortly after the rig's arrival.

site_title: Worldwide airline shares up 3% in August
summary: Worldwide airline shares rose 3% in August, outperforming the broader market, as easing jet fuel prices provided relief. US carriers led the pack with a 5% increase, while Asia Pacific carriers posted a net profit of $234 million despite an operating loss. Crude oil prices slipped 4% in August, and jet fuel prices also fell 4%. Passenger yields picked up in 2Q14, but South-east Asian airlines face competition and overcapacity pressures.

site_title: UOB's proposed A$300m notes get Aa1 rating
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has been assigned an Aa1 debt rating by Moody's Investors Service for its proposed A$300 million senior unsecured notes, which matures in September 2018. The rating is in line with UOB's Aa1 global local currency deposit rating and reflects the bank's strong credit fundamentals, solid balance sheet, and significant market share in Singapore. Moody's also notes a high likelihood of systemic support for UOB, given its size and market share. The rating is stable, and Moody's will consider lowering it if UOB's exposure to higher-risk markets increases or its funding structure shifts.

site_title: Following her gut to become an arts impresario as well
summary: Spa Esprit Group's Cynthia Chua is setting aside S$100,000 annually to support emerging artists and build the company's art collection. Chua aims to create a house museum and curate local and international artists, prioritizing unconventional gallery spaces. Her interest in the arts stems from her personal passion and desire to nurture creativity and discover new talents. Chua has partnered with Ofr to host a one-day photo exhibition featuring Helmut Newton's portraits and works by two French photographers, showcasing her commitment to the arts impresario field.

site_title: HK jeweller Chow Tai Fook to study S-E Asia market from S'pore
summary: Hong Kong-based jeweller Chow Tai Fook plans to expand its presence in South-east Asia, leveraging Singapore as its regional hub. The company, which derives 99% of its revenue from mainland China, Hong Kong, Macau, and Taiwan, will open its second store in Singapore in December 2014 to gain a better understanding of the local market. The expansion aims to attract local customers and learn about their demand, with no immediate plans for regional expansion. Chow Tai Fook also aims to increase its e-commerce presence, projecting a 5% rise in e-commerce transactions to 5% of total sales within five years.

site_title: ECB to buy securitised loans, covered bonds
summary: The European Central Bank launched a new scheme to boost the eurozone economy, starting next month. The ECB will buy securitised loans and covered bonds to help unblock lending. The bank also cut its main refinancing rate to 0.05% from 0.15%, a record low, in an effort to stimulate economic growth. ECB President Mario Draghi stated that the move aims to push money into the economy and help private sector assets.

site_title: Quiet, hard-hitting chamber piece
summary: A collaborative performance piece, "I Stand Corrected," tackles the horrific issues of corrective rape and homophobic murder through dance, movement, and drama. South African dancer Mamela Nyamza and British writer Mojisola Adebayo's performance tells the story of a lesbian bride whose partner is raped and murdered, but focuses on the emotions rather than the acts of violence. The piece, part of a double bill, explores themes of perception, violence, and the power of dance to convey emotion, with a meditative second piece by Nyamza and her son.

site_title: A mature selection to nurture and relish
summary: A group of wine enthusiasts in Singapore gathered to taste mature burgundies, including four from Swiss friend Francois Gautier's collection from the 1978 and 1993 vintages. The event highlighted the importance of aging fine wines, as mature champagnes and burgundies offer increased complexity and richness. However, these wines are often not available off-the-shelf, making self-aging a viable option for those willing to invest time and care. The event also showcased the need for patience when it comes to aging fine wines, with some reaching their best flavor at 15 years or older.

site_title: Indonesian tycoon Tahir picks up 12 Grange Infinite units
summary: Indonesian tycoon Tahir purchased 12 units at the Grange Infinite project in Singapore for approximately S$70 million, pricing the apartments at S$2,050 per square foot on average. The deal includes 11 four-bedroom apartments and a 6,039 sq ft "junior penthouse" on the 20th level of the 36-storey freehold project.

site_title: Sheng Siong plans to place out 120m new shares
summary: Sheng Siong Group Ltd plans to issue 120 million new shares at 67 Singapore cents per unit, raising approximately S$80.4 million to shore up capital for expansion plans. The placement represents about 8.67% of the company's present issued share capital and is expected to dilute earnings per share for FY2013 to 2.59 Singapore cents. The new shares are pending approval from the Singapore Exchange Securities Trading Limited (SGX-ST) and will provide funds for acquiring properties for new retail outlets and a proposed joint venture with Kunming Luchen Group Co Ltd in China.

site_title: Molotov cocktail of race, class and sex
summary: A South African adaptation of the classic play "Miss Julie" has received critical acclaim in Singapore, exploring themes of race, class, and sex in a contemporary setting. The play, "Mies Julie," has been praised for its acting, direction, and script, but some performances feel worn after repeated tours. The production, which features strong lead actors, has managed to make the original play scandalous again, sparking urgent and poignant discussions about racial and economic inequities in South Africa. The play runs at the DBS Arts Centre until September 13.

site_title: SunMoon taking 51% stake in fruit, vegetable business
summary: SunMoon Food Company has entered into a memorandum of understanding to acquire a 51% stake in Ban Fresh's fruit and vegetable business. Under the agreement, SunMoon will acquire 296,000 shares for S$5.6 million and issue 2% more shares for S$400,000. The acquisition is expected to help SunMoon grow its market share, sales, and profitability in the fresh fruit business. The deal will also provide a strategic fit between Ban Fresh and SunMoon's existing businesses.

site_title: Asia's top brokers and stock analysts
summary: Deutsche Bank has been named the top brokerage firm in Asia under the 2014 StarMine Analyst Awards for the region. This is the 10th year of the awards, recognizing the brokerage firm whose analysts won the most awards. Deutsche Bank took the top spot in the "most award-winning brokers" category.

site_title: Teenage-romance drama with nice, supportive cast
summary: The article discusses the movie "If I Stay", a teenage romance drama based on the best-selling Young Adult novel. The film, starring Chloe Grace Moretz, received mixed reviews, with the critic stating it fails to breathe life into the story. The article notes that the movie's success is likely due to its built-in fanbase, similar to "The Fault In Our Stars", but ultimately concludes that it is a "flat-lining tween weepie".

site_title: Outsource or take it in-house?
summary: Businesses are considering shared service centres (SSCs) and outsourcing as options for transformation, driven by the need for productivity and cost reduction. While saving costs has become less of a priority, SSCs can fuel efficient growth and improve compliance and controls. Experts note that setting up an SSC involves upfront investment, which takes time to break even and show visible benefits. This shift reflects a change in the business landscape, where companies are prioritizing growth and efficiency over cost savings.

site_title: Samsung sends Apple a curved Note
summary: Samsung has unveiled its latest-generation phablet, the 5.7-inch Galaxy Note 4, a week ahead of Apple's highly-anticipated "exclusive event" on September 9. The device boasts impressive specs, including a high-resolution display, latest-generation processor, and fingerprint scanner. Samsung also launched the Note Edge, a phone with a curved screen at the right edge, which could be a game-changer in the market. The company's strategy to release its Note series just ahead of Apple's announcements is designed to counter the advantage Apple gains from being the first to unveil its flagship phones.

site_title: Investors chasing property outside US at record pace
summary: Investors are putting money into non-US real estate at a record pace as interest rates recede and economies expand. The SPDR Dow Jones International Real Estate ETF attracted $304 million in net inflows in August, driving its shares outstanding to a record. Real estate has emerged as the asset of choice due to its relatively high yields, with investors looking to take advantage of pockets of distress outside the US. The top 10 countries holding shares in the ETF are Japan, the UK, Australia, Hong Kong, Canada, France, and Singapore, with yields ranging from 4-6% in Japan and 3-5% in other countries.

site_title: Ancient ritual dance bewitches and baffles
summary: Japan's oldest and most sacred dance, Sambaso, was performed at the Singapore International Festival of Arts, captivating the audience with its centuries-old ritual. The dance, believed to bless a harvest, involves a male performer stamping on the ground to release energy, which then unites the audience in spirituality. Legendary photographer Hiroshi Sugimoto designed the set and costumes, but it was the dance and music that stole the show. The performance, led by 83-year-old kyogen master Mansaku Nomura, was both spellbinding and incomprehensible to non-Japanese audiences due to its lack of narrative and emotion.

site_title: A sequel that never quite takes off
summary: Disney's Planes: Fire & Rescue, a sequel to the 2013 Planes, receives mixed reviews for its dull storyline and brief runtime. Despite its technical achievements, the film's plot, which combines elements of Ron Howard's fire-fighting drama and a children's book, fails to resonate with both kids and adults. Comedian Dane Cook returns to voice Dusty, a crop duster turned racing legend, but the film's merchandising potential and short length make it feel like a cash-grab. The film rates a C, indicating a mediocre experience.

site_title: Creepy, growing success
summary: Filmmakers in Asia are gaining recognition in Hollywood for their horror movies, with local audiences enthusiastically embracing the genre. Recent successes include Gilbert Chan's "23:59" and Japanese franchises "The Ring" and "Ju-On". Four new local horror productions are set to be released in the coming months, including Tony Kern's "Afterimages" and Kelvin Tong's Hollywood-bound film "The Faith of Anna Waters". Award-winning writer-director Lee Thean-Jeen has also completed his first horror feature, "Bring Back The Dead". The increasing success of Asian horror is expected to continue with these upcoming releases.

site_title: Hedge fund chief pays US$71.3m for NY home
summary: Hedge fund manager Israel Englander has purchased a duplex apartment on New York's Park Avenue for a record-breaking $71.3 million, surpassing the previous co-op record set by Edgar Bronfman Sr. at $70 million. The six-bedroom unit, designed by Rosario Candela and Arthur Loomis Harmon, was sold by the French government. The price, which includes transfer taxes, was the result of a bidding war among three qualified buyers. Englander's purchase marks another record-breaking sale in the Manhattan real estate market.

site_title: Tycoon Ananda Krishnan hit by graft charges in India
summary: Tycoon Ananda Krishnan, one of Asia's richest men, is facing graft charges in India related to the 2006 Maxis Communications Berhad's (MCB) buyout of Aircel. The Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) filed charges against Krishnan, his trusted aide Ralph Marshall, and Indian media baron Kalanidhi Maran under the Prevention of Corruption Act, alleging they conspired to coerce the sale of Aircel to MCB. The charges stem from a larger investigation into corruption scandals involving the award of 2G spectrum licenses. Krishnan's firms, MCB and Astro All Asia Networks (AAAN), have denied the allegations and vowed to defend themselves.

site_title: Preliminary report on crash expected on Tuesday
summary: Dutch air crash investigators will release a preliminary report on the downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight MH17 on Tuesday, providing factual information based on available sources. The report will be released on the Dutch Safety Board's website at 10:00 am and will not include a press conference. The investigation, led by the Netherlands, aims to determine the cause of the crash that killed 298 people, including 193 Dutch citizens. The West blames Russian-backed separatists, while Moscow blames Kiev, and further investigation is expected before a final report is written within a year.

site_title: Passenger car COEs flat
summary: Singapore's passenger car Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premiums remained flat in the latest bidding exercise, with Category A prices dropping to $64,841 and Category E prices increasing to $74,403. Despite steady demand, consumers are hesitant to push up COE prices, citing the current restriction on vehicle financing and a preference for alternatives like the Early Turnover Scheme. Dealers attribute the flat premiums to consumers waiting for prices to drop below $60,000-$65,000.

site_title: 2 local artists in tussle for hefty prize
summary: Two Singaporean artists, Ho Tzu Nyen and Zhao Renhui, have been shortlisted for the Asia Pacific Breweries (APB) Foundation Signature Art Prize, with their works "PYTHAGORAS" and "Eskimo Wolf Trap" respectively. The top prize of S$60,000 is being awarded to the winner, up from S$45,000 previously. The prize recognizes interdisciplinary artworks that combine various art forms, and the finalists were chosen from 105 nominated artworks from 24 countries.

site_title: EU aviation regulator wants to improve coordination
summary: The European Aviation Safety Agency is proposing a European alert system to improve coordination of information about threats to aviation, following the downing of MH17 in July. The system would process information about conflict zones and provide recommendations to airlines. The agency is seeking support from military intelligence to enhance the system, but some European Parliament members are unhappy about a lack of clear responsibility for warning airlines about airspace risks. The current system relies on individual countries providing advice, which can lead to conflicting information.

site_title: SGX, take a leaf or 2 from other bourses
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) can learn from other stock exchanges in enhancing disclosures, particularly in showing actual delivery trading volume and proprietary trader activity. Currently, the SGX only requires short sales to be marked as such, with limited usefulness due to delayed reporting. In contrast, the Malaysian and Hong Kong bourses publish regular short-selling reports with timely data, providing accurate insights into market sentiment. Additionally, breaking down turnover by investor category, such as foreign versus local institutions, can offer valuable information to investors.

site_title: MAS' revamp to address root of problems: analysts
summary: Malaysia Airlines (MAS) has unveiled a massive overhaul plan to address its financial woes, including a RM4.6 billion capital injection and a 30% workforce reduction. Analysts see AirAsia X as the only clear winner from the restructuring, while MAS is reshaping itself into a quasi low-cost carrier model. The airline aims to reduce costs to 17 sen per available seat kilometre, closer to its current revenue per available seat kilometre. A recovery is unlikely in the near future, with capacity expansion on regional routes expected to continue.

site_title: Airshow 2014 pumped S$319m into economy
summary: The 2014 Singapore Airshow generated S$319 million in economic impact, a 25% increase from 2012. Foreign visitors' spending drove the growth, with S$284.9 million spent on travel and accommodation, events, and other personal expenses. The airshow saw a 30% increase in foreign exhibiting personnel and a 23.4% rise in total exhibitors. The event also contributed to the long-term sustainability of Singapore's aerospace and defence industry, with over 75% of exhibitors confirmed for the 2016 event.

site_title: Changi/Batam maritime borders treaty signed
summary: Indonesia and Singapore have signed a maritime borders treaty, marking a significant milestone in their bilateral relations. The treaty, covering a 9.45-kilometer stretch, aims to maintain sovereignty and enforce law in territorial waters, while promoting cooperation in navigational safety, maritime affairs, and fisheries. The agreement follows nine rounds of technical discussions, which began in 2011. This is the second maritime boundary treaty between the two nations, following a 2009 deal. The pact is seen as a demonstration of strong political commitment and cooperation between the two ASEAN neighbors.

site_title: US firm buying over Singapore eDev's HotApps
summary: US firm Fragmented Industry Exchange (FIE) plans to acquire Singapore eDevelopment's instant messaging software unit HotApps for US$700 million in shares and bonds. The transaction will give SeD a slightly below 20% stake in FIE and potentially 99.84% ownership if all bonds are converted and the call option is exercised. The acquisition aims to allow HotApps to tap the US capital market without diluting Singapore investors' equity, and the deal is expected to accelerate the launch of HotApps' mobile apps in North and South America.

site_title: Global appetite for M&A still strong: KPMG
summary: KPMG's M&A Predictor suggests the world's largest companies will maintain strong appetite for mergers and acquisitions (M&A) over the next six months, with predicted forward price-to-earnings (PE) ratios remaining high and companies continuing to pay down debt. A 13% increase in capacity is expected, driven by rising cash reserves. Despite strong deal announcements, deal completions fell 2% in the first half of 2014, likely due to companies' ability to keep profits without M&A transactions.

site_title: DBS credit profile unaffected by China exposure: Moody's
summary: Moody's Investors Service has stated that DBS Bank's rapidly growing presence in mainland China has not significantly weakened its credit profile. DBS' exposure to China is mostly through overseas borrowers exporting to China, and the bank has set aside strong buffers against loan losses. The bank's direct exposure to shadow banking and local government vehicles is minimal, and its real estate exposure is limited to large state-owned enterprises with strong credit profiles. As of June 2014, DBS' total mainland China exposure was approximately S$50 billion.

site_title: Sunningdale to acquire Anchorage Singapore Holdings
summary: Sunningdale Tech Ltd plans to acquire privately held Anchorage Singapore Holdings for US$80 million, creating a precision plastics engineering company with combined revenue of S$636 million. The acquisition will span nine countries and include manufacturing operations and sales offices. Anchorage Singapore Holdings is the ultimate holding company of First Engineering Limited, a manufacturer of precision plastic moulds and components for the automotive, consumer IT, and healthcare sectors.

site_title: Time's up for buyers of Cyprus Airways
summary: Potential buyers of Cyprus Airways, including Ryanair and Aegean Airlines, had until September 3 to submit non-binding offers for the loss-making national carrier. The deadline was extended to allow more time for interested parties to submit bids. Ryanair had previously stated its intention to submit a firm offer, but no official statement was made regarding the deadline extension. The government's decision aims to find a buyer for the struggling airline, which has been loss-making.

site_title: China media in bid to rekindle interest in stocks
summary: China's state-run media are promoting stock investing through various articles and campaigns, aiming to boost the market after a slump. Authorities have cut trading fees, made it cheaper to open new accounts, and organized investor presentations. This push follows forecasts for gains from brokerages and may help reduce speculative investing in the property market. The Shanghai Composite Index rose to a 15-month high, and the number of equity accounts is rising, fueling speculation that China's economy is weathering its real-estate slump.

site_title: Global Yellow Pages narrows Q1 loss
summary: Global Yellow Pages reported a net loss of S$649,000 in Q1 2014, narrowing from a loss of S$680,000 in the same quarter a year earlier. Revenue declined 8.5% to S$4 million, mainly due to a decline in its search solutions business. The company offset this decline with higher revenue from Singapore River Tour & Taxi Services. Global Yellow Pages plans to use the net proceeds of a recent rights issue to fund future acquisitions, including the proposed acquisition of Gloria Jean's Coffees for S$11.7 million.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: Rex International is raising S$95.76 million through a placement to settle liabilities and fund field development plans in Oman. The company will issue 168 million shares at S$0.57 per share, a 7.7% discount. Net proceeds will be used for these purposes, with the acquisition of RTM expected to be completed by Dec 1.

site_title: Samsung Hub floor sold at S$3,225 psf
summary: The entire 18th floor of Samsung Hub, a 30-storey office tower in Singapore, has been sold for S$42.35 million, or S$3,225 per square foot. This is the highest price paid for an entire office floor in the building, surpassing the S$3,030 psf paid for the 14th floor earlier this year. The sale was brokered by CBRE and advised by Cushman and Wakefield, and is expected to be occupied by an Asia-based group involved in the oil and gas business.

site_title: Speculators leaving Brazil property market
summary: Brazil's residential real-estate market is experiencing a slowdown, as speculators and short-term investors abandon the market, leading to a levelling off of prices. Builders like Rossi Residencial SA are selling off less-profitable homes to make room for more lucrative sales. The market adjustment may boost cash flow and make apartments more affordable, but investors remain cautious due to the country's economic contraction and high debt levels among builders. Experts predict prices will increase with inflation, but it's too early for the market to attract investors again.

site_title: A look at home from afar
summary: An artist-curated contemporary art exhibition, "The Beach That Never Was," explores the concept of home through the works of 10 artists from various countries currently based in Los Angeles, Japan, or Singapore. The exhibition, which runs at the Institute of Contemporary Arts Singapore until September 14, features a diverse range of mediums and themes, including video, sculpture, and photography. Curated by Mike HJ Chang, Juka Araikawa, and Krister Olsson, the show aims to showcase the artists' independent thinking and optimism, with prices ranging from S$1,000 to S$4,000.

site_title: China services sector rebounds but property remains a worry
summary: China's services sector rebounded in August, with the services purchasing managers' index (PMI) jumping to 54.1, the strongest in 17 months, and the official non-manufacturing PMI rising to 54.4. However, the property sector remained a concern, and employment remained lacklustre. The rebound is seen as a positive sign, but the economy still faces downside risks, particularly from the property sector slowdown. The government is sticking to its "targeted" policy stance to keep growth on track, with Premier Li Keqiang focusing on investment projects in bottleneck areas.

site_title: LionGold delays Aussie deal to Sept 30
summary: LionGold Corp has delayed its planned acquisition of Australian gold mining and exploration assets for a second time, pushing the deadline to September 30. The company had previously announced the deal on June 30, but no reason was given for the delay. The acquisition involves LionGold Australia's purchase of a pre-development project and an early exploration project in New South Wales.

site_title: Aug HDB resale prices fall 1.1% from July: SRX
summary: Singapore's HDB resale prices fell 1.1% in August, with a 7.1% drop from last year and 8.6% from 2013 peak, according to SRX data. The decline was within expected "soft landing" boundaries, with consultants predicting a 5-8% drop in prices for the year. Resale prices for three and four-room flats dropped 2% and 0.9% respectively, while larger flats edged up. Resale transactions fell 1.1% and rental prices remained relatively flat, with forecasters predicting a 5-10% drop in rents by year-end.

site_title: Linc Energy shares jump on offers for US oil assets
summary: Linc Energy shares rose nearly 8% after the firm revealed it received unsolicited offers for its US oil assets, valued at 95% of its external revenues. The company is in talks with these parties and aims to conclude discussions before the year ends. Despite a 19% revenue rise, Linc Energy reported a widened loss of A$223.3 million in its full-year results. The company will continue to develop its existing assets while exploring and developing new opportunities, including its Sapex shale assets in South Australia.

site_title: SingPost stock up on postage hike news
summary: Singapore Post's shares rose 3.2% to S$1.78 on news of an upward revision in postage rates, the first since 2006, to mitigate escalating costs. However, the initial surge was short-lived, with the stock ending the day 1.2% higher at S$1.745.

site_title: Singapore-Indonesia ties a top priority
summary: Indonesian President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono emphasized the importance of maintaining good relations with Singapore, citing the country's strategic value and the two nations' strong bilateral ties. He acknowledged that relations between the countries were not always easy, but emphasized the principle of equality between nations, respect, and cooperation. Yudhoyono highlighted his efforts to deepen the partnership between Indonesia and Singapore, including regular meetings with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and frequent consultations between ministers. He expressed gratitude for the recognition of his contributions to regional cooperation and stability, and praised Singapore for its support during the 2004 tsunami crisis.

site_title: Norwegian Cruise to buy Apollo's Prestige Cruises
summary: Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings has agreed to buy Prestige Cruises International, the parent company of luxury cruise operators Oceania Cruises and Regent Seven Seas Cruises, for $3 billion. The deal aims to expand Norwegian's high-end luxury cruise offerings. Shares of Norwegian Cruise rose 13% following the announcement, while Prestige's shares were halted pending the completion of the deal. The acquisition will bring Prestige's eight ships and approximately 6,500 berths to Norwegian's fleet, bolstering its position as the world's third-largest cruise operator.

site_title: China moves to modernise shipping sector
summary: China has published guidelines to modernize its shipping sector, aiming to secure supply chains and grow its maritime industry. The country will introduce tax and regulatory reforms, encouraging firms to upgrade and modernize their fleets by 2020. The goal is to build an efficient, safe, and environmentally friendly shipping system. The government will also promote shipping centers and encourage firms to retire vessels early. The move is seen as a response to China's growing assertiveness in the South China Sea and its need to secure its supply chains.

site_title: The lives of regular people in a pivotal year
summary: Singapore's 50th birthday celebrations are commemorated in the film "1965", which follows ordinary people in 1965 as they navigate racial tensions and events that shaped the country that year. Executive producer Daniel Yun says the long-delayed project was revised 60 times before its release, and the timing is a coincidence rather than a cash-in on the country's jubilee. The film explores the lives of several individuals, including a young Chinese girl kidnapped, and its climax unfolds quickly, unraveling the characters' stories.

site_title: Tuan Sing to buy over Aussie hotel associate
summary: Tuan Sing Holdings agreed to buy Morgan Stanley's 50% stake in Australian hotel group Grand Hotel Group for A$126.04 million. The deal, expected to be completed before year-end, will give Tuan Sing full control of the group, which owns two five-star hotels in Australia. The acquisition will add to Tuan Sing's Australian portfolio, now estimated at 35% of the group's total property value. CEO William Liem aims to make GHG more efficient and profitable through strategic plans.

site_title: Maybank sees pick-up in investment banking
summary: Malayan Banking Bhd (Maybank) expects a pick-up in investment banking in South-east Asia due to increased share and debt sales in Malaysia, Singapore, and growing stability in Thailand. The bank attributes this to the resolution of elections in Indonesia and a recovery in Thailand's economy, with GDP expanding 0.4% in the second quarter. Maybank also anticipates more deals in Vietnam, particularly from state-owned companies, over the next 12 months. The bank's investment-banking division is optimistic about the market, citing a robust debt pipeline and upcoming IPOs in sectors such as utilities and property.

site_title: S'pore still 2nd most competitive in the world
summary: Singapore has been ranked as the world's second-most competitive economy for the fourth year in a row by the World Economic Forum. However, economists warn that further tightening of foreign labor policies could harm the country's future ranking. The country's strong infrastructure, prudent fiscal management, and transparent policy-making processes have contributed to its high competitiveness. Nevertheless, labor constraints and restrictive labor regulations are seen as potential risks to Singapore's ranking, and economists stress that a short-term loss of competitiveness may be necessary for long-term restructuring efforts.

images.alt_text: According to the WEF's latest Global Competitiveness Index (GCI), Singapore kept its No 2 spot for the fourth year running - PHOTO: SPH

site_title: Failed home deals in UK rise with bank limits
summary: The Bank of England has introduced measures to limit mortgage lending after home prices in the UK rose 9.9% in the past year to a record £270,636. The new regulations include limits on mortgage lending relative to a borrower's income and requirements that banks turn down loans to homebuyers who fail a stress test. As a result, failed home deals have risen to 26.4% in August, driven by potential buyers getting cold feet and unwilling buyers being prevented from closing deals. The measures aim to curb the market's 16-month rally and prevent a housing bubble.

site_title: Changi Airport operator boosts long-haul flights, transfer traffic
summary: Changi Airport Group (CAG) is boosting long-haul flights and transfer traffic through its Growth and Assistance Incentive (GAIN) package. The S$50 million initiative includes landing fee rebates and incentives for airlines to grow transfer traffic, aiming to bolster Singapore's position as a leading air hub in the region. The measures, which will last 19 months, include 50% rebates on aircraft parking fees and 15% rebates on aerobridge fees. The goal is to help airlines cope with costs and boost productivity, while also encouraging them to tweak pricing and network revenue management models.

site_title: Beware risks of illiquid, low-volume market
summary: The US equity market is experiencing a low-volume, low-volatility trend, with trading volume and S&P 500 closing above 2,000 for the first time. This has led to concerns among investors, as it may indicate a low-risk environment, but also poses risks such as difficulty exiting positions quickly and exaggerated price movements. The decline in liquidity is attributed to the US Federal Reserve's tapering of quantitative easing, which may lead to rising interest rates and a potential correction in the market, with some analysts warning of stretched valuations and low earnings forecasts.

site_title: Tokyo property investments surge on rising rents
summary: Tokyo's property market is experiencing a surge in investment, driven by rising rents and expected growth. Office rents are projected to increase by 30% over the next three years, attracting investors seeking higher returns. Real estate investment in Japan rose 70% to 4.6 trillion yen in the past year, with private real estate investment trusts (Reits) accounting for 30% of investments. Major transactions include the acquisition of the Citigroup Center building by Fosun Group and the purchase of an office complex by Mori Trust Co. for over $1 billion.

site_title: Office revamp in S'pore offers high returns
summary: Singapore ranked 4th globally in a report by Arcadis, with a 7.53% yield for minor office building refurbishment investments.
