This is one of the top three Asian cities, behind Shanghai and Hong Kong. The report considers 15 cities worldwide and ranks them by expected net rental income return.

site_title: Company Briefs
summary: EMS Energy is proposing a one-for-one rights issue to raise up to $14.66 million despite cancelling the purchase of International Offshore Equipments. Singapore eDev sold 35% of its Texas project for $20.7 million. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed.

site_title: Focus of new Abe team on economy, better China ties
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe reshuffled his cabinet, focusing on the economy and improving relations with China. Former finance minister Sadakazu Tanigaki was appointed LDP secretary-general, shifting attention to economic issues. Tanigaki's close ties with China and the appointment of "China-friendly" Toshihiro Nikkai as LDP general council chairman may help mend strained relations. The move aims to address concerns about Abenomics running out of steam and boost regional economies. The changes also reflect a more "militant" approach to security issues, but Abe may be cautious not to antagonize voters.

site_title: Quota for female directors not ruled out: Grace Fu
summary: Singapore Minister Grace Fu suggests the possibility of imposing a quota for female directors on the boards of listed companies, but prefers to increase representation through non-regulatory means. Currently, women hold only 8.3% of directorships in Singapore-listed companies, below the global average. Large companies such as Genting Singapore, Global Logistics Properties, and Wilmar International have no female board members. Fu emphasizes the importance of board diversity, but notes that it should be based on bringing in people with different expertise and perspectives, not just gender.

summary: Two award-winning companies share their ideas on innovating and boosting productivity in the SME Magazine. Meanwhile, Royal Healthcare is set to open a specialist centre in Tokyo or Osaka after Sojitz takes control. Researchers at NUS are working on a startup to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel. OCBC aims to provide S$5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028. Other news includes Shatec shutting its Orchard campus, an otah business rebranding heritage, and a modernized traditional snack, Munchi Pancakes.

site_title: Ramping up productivity
summary: Singapore's National Productivity Month 2014 will be launched by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong on Oct 7, focusing on productivity-themed sector-level events. Meanwhile, recent news includes a startup aiming to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel, OCBC targeting S$5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028, and Shatec shutting its Orchard campus and training restaurant, cutting 42 staff and putting the building up for sale.

site_title: Yoma 1-for-3 rights issue to fund more acquisitions
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings, a Myanmar conglomerate, plans to fund new acquisitions through a one-for-three rights issue worth up to S$430.7 million. The issue, priced at S$0.38, will be used to pay for acquisitions, including a land bank expansion, purchase of operating rights to a golf club, and expansion of its automotive division. The deal is worth S$95.9 million, with Serge Pun & Associates (Myanmar) Limited and its associates involved.

site_title: Logistics to acquire Johor land for development
summary: Logistics Holdings, a Singaporean construction group, has acquired a 11.5-hectare plot of industrial land in Johor, Malaysia for RM38.8 million. The land will be used to build 70-80 light and medium industrial factories, serving the demand from nearby Scientex Innoparc. This marks the company's maiden overseas property development venture, aiming to diversify its income stream and boost revenue. The acquisition is part of the company's expansion into Malaysia, following the commencement of a precast manufacturing operation in Iskandar region in July.

site_title: Jurong Shipyard sells longer dated bonds
summary: Jurong Shipyard, a unit of Sembcorp Marine, sold S$600 million bonds with two tranches: a 7-year S$275 million bond priced at 2.95% and a 15-year S$325 million bond priced at 3.85%. The long-duration 15-year bond is the first from a non-bank corporate issuer in two years, with orders exceeding S$400 million. Strong investor demand for bonds has led to higher prices, with the Singapore Fixed Income index reaching an all-time high.

site_title: Airline fares in Malaysia to dip on overcapacity
summary: Malaysia Airlines' (MAS) fare prices are expected to decline 8% over five years due to overcapacity. The airline faces significant challenges, including a high cost structure and low revenue per employee. Khazanah, the owner of MAS, proposes a RM6 billion injection, workforce reduction, and restructuring to turn the airline profitable within three years. Analysts question the success of the plan, and Malaysia's opposition parties criticize the government's potential bailout.

site_title: M'sia developer mulls towers next to UBS HQ in London
summary: AlloyMtd Group, a Malaysian developer, is considering building two towers near UBS AG's London headquarters. The proposed project would include 19,500 sqm of office space, a hotel, and 21,700 sqm of apartments. AlloyMtd bought the land plot for £57.5 million from UBS subsidiary Sun Street Properties Ltd last year. The Hackney borough council will debate the project on September 10, following a long history of vacant buildings on the site, including a 2011 occupation by Occupy London protesters.

site_title: Lease buyback: 75% of elderly HDB households can benefit
summary: Singapore's enhanced lease buyback scheme (LBS) can benefit 75% of elderly HDB households, up from 35% previously. The scheme, set to launch in April 2025, offers greater flexibility on lease length and cash proceeds. Despite expected increased take-up rates, Minister Khaw Boon Wan warns against excessive spending by elderly residents, urging them to use the proceeds to top up their CPF Retirement Accounts or their spouses'. The scheme aims to provide financial support to seniors, with 80% of HDB flats owned by seniors aged 55 and above sitting on net equity.

site_title: Avi-Tech Electronics placed on SGX watch-list
summary: Avi-Tech Electronics has been added to the Singapore Exchange (SGX) watch-list due to consecutive three-year losses. The semiconductor solutions provider has two years to apply for removal by achieving pre-tax profit and maintaining a minimum market value. This is the 15th company added to the watch-list this year, including steel company Novo Group and China Essence Group. Avi-Tech's business will continue as usual, and the company has options to apply for removal, including achieving cumulative pre-tax profit or a minimum market value.

site_title: Emirates not interested in Qantas investment
summary: Emirates has ruled out investing in Qantas' international operations, citing its airline's strategy as not aligning with their own. The move comes as Qantas hives off its international arm from its domestic business, allowing a foreign airline to take a 49% stake. Emirates' CCO Thierry Antinori stated the company prefers to operate independently and not engage in traditional airline alliances. The decision is seen as a blow to Qantas' restructuring efforts and a testament to Emirates' commitment to its solo strategy.

site_title: Travellers suffer power outlet drought at US airports
summary: Travellers in the US are struggling to find available power outlets at airports, with many forced to camp out on the floor or search for charging stations. The demand for power outlets has increased exponentially with the proliferation of devices, with over 1.3 billion laptops, tablets, and phones expected to be used on work trips this year. There are no nationwide standards for providing electricity for air travellers, resulting in a patchwork of power availability. Airlines and airport operators are investing in upgrades, but the cost of installing outlets can be high, ranging from $1,000 to $2,500.

site_title: Los Angeles Harbor selling most bonds in 5 years
summary: The Los Angeles Harbor Department is selling $340 million in debt, the largest amount since 2009, to refinance debt and upgrade facilities at the Port of Los Angeles. The sale comes after a tentative agreement on healthcare costs between longshoremen and shippers reduced the risk of a crippling strike. The agreement, announced in August, could prevent a 10-day strike that would have cost 169,000 jobs and $2.1 billion daily to the US economy. The bond issue will help automate container movement and reduce air pollution, backed by port revenue.

site_title: STATS ChipPAC shares take a hard knock
summary: STATS ChipPAC shares plummeted 11% to 62 Singapore cents after a potential Chinese bidder, Jiangsu Changjiang Electronics Technology Co, stated a low likelihood of a deal within the next three months. The company had previously announced talks with JCET and Tianshui Huatian Technology Co about a possible acquisition. After Tianshui Huatian Technology terminated its approach, STATS ChipPAC's shares fell in opening trade and remained volatile throughout the day. The stock's sharp price drop was attributed to the reduced chances of a deal, leaving investors uncertain about the company's future.

Meanwhile, a Singaporean startup aims to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel, while OCBC targets S$5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028. site_title: Wage growth raises hopes for Japan economy
summary: Japan's monthly pay, including bonuses, rose 2.6% in July, exceeding 2% for the first time in 10 years, easing pressure on the Bank of Japan to ease monetary policy. This increase in wages may temper criticisms of the central bank's anti-deflation strategy, which has driven up prices faster than wages. Average basic salaries rose 0.7% and underlying wages are still not keeping pace with inflation, but the gap between price and wage developments is narrowing, suggesting potential for real income growth.

site_title: Rotary Engg wins deals worth S$80m
summary: Rotary Engineering, a Singaporean engineering company, has secured contracts worth S$80 million, including its first liquefied natural gas (LNG) contract with IHI Corp. The contract involves providing tankage works for two LNG storage tanks in Thailand's Map Tha Phut petrolchemical hub. This marks Rotary's entry into the LNG space, supporting the oil and gas industry.

site_title: Mixed bag of results for fiscal year ended June
summary: Singapore's corporate sector posted mixed results for the fiscal year ended June, with 68 firms reporting profits and 25 suffering losses. Total net profits rose 6% to S$2.5 billion, with 33 firms achieving higher profits and 25 earning less. Key challenges included rising cost pressures, market volatility, and a global economic cycle that failed to turn around as expected. Some firms, such as shipowner CH Offshore and commodities trader Olam International, reported significant improvements, but overall, the sector's performance was seen as disappointing due to anaemic demand and escalating costs.

site_title: Global outlook: What's in store for investors
summary: Global growth remains patchy, with investors facing a mixed outlook. The US economy is expected to grow around 3% this quarter, but is not booming. The Eurozone is stalled, with Germany, Italy, and France showing weakness. Japan's economy has weathered a sales tax hike, but faces uncertainty. China is on track for growth of around 7.5% despite periodic slowdowns. Emerging markets, including India and Indonesia, are showing promise, but Brazil and Russia face challenges. The global economy is characterized by two steps forward, one step back, with easy monetary conditions and benign inflation supporting growth assets.

site_title: Asia investments in global real estate soar 40% in H1: CBRE
summary: Asian investors poured US$16.2 billion into global real estate in the first half of 2014, a 40% year-over-year surge. Singapore overtook China as the top source of Asian capital, accounting for 29% of outbound investments. The majority of Asian dollars (63%) went into office assets, with London, New York, and Los Angeles being the top destinations. Asian investors are diversifying their market exposure, with the top five cities now accounting for 58% of total Asian cross-border investments, down from 66% last year.

site_title: PM Lee opens S$950m Jurong Rock Caverns
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong officially opened the S$950 million Jurong Rock Caverns, a commercial underground storage facility for oil and petrochemicals, on Tuesday. The project, conceived in 2001, is the first in South-east Asia and provides 9.2 million barrels of storage capacity. The caverns, located 150 meters below ground, will free up land for petrochemical plants and reduce the need for in-house storage facilities. The government sees the petrochemical industry as a key sector, contributing a third of manufacturing output and providing good jobs for Singaporeans.

site_title: New capitalism is the new normal, says SID chairman
summary: SID chairman Willie Cheng states that a new form of capitalism, dubbed "new capitalism," has emerged, prioritizing the needs of all stakeholders over just maximizing shareholder value. This shift aims to address the "increasingly unacceptable" current state of capitalism. The concept, discussed at the SID Directors' Conference 2014, seeks to create a more altruistic economic system.

site_title: Australia to scrap dumping plan: report
summary: Australia plans to scrap a proposal to dump three million cubic meters of dredged sand into the Great Barrier Reef area to create the world's biggest coal port, citing concerns over potential damage to the reef and seagrasses. Green groups and tour operators opposed the plan, which was set to be submitted to Environment Minister Greg Hunt. Instead, North Queensland Bulk Ports, Adani Group, and GVK will re-submit a proposal offering alternative dumping sites on land.

site_title: Eurozone needs more monetary easing
summary: The European Central Bank is set to decide on interest rate policy, with many expecting a further cut in rates to combat deflation and low inflation in the eurozone. ECB president Mario Draghi has emphasized the need for an accommodative monetary policy to address high unemployment, currently at 11.5% in the EU, and has called for more activist fiscal policy. A decision to launch quantitative easing is also seen as a possibility, with markets expecting an aggressive monetary policy to stimulate the economy.

site_title: Samsung to merge two business units
summary: Samsung Group is set to merge its shipbuilding and engineering units, Samsung Heavy Industries Co and Samsung Engineering Co, in a deal valued at 2.5 trillion won (S$3.08 billion). The merger aims to reduce overlapping areas and increase sales to 40 trillion won by 2020. The combined entity will provide solutions for onshore and offshore projects, and will not affect the workforce. The move is part of Samsung Group's restructuring efforts ahead of a potential succession, with billionaire chairman Lee Kun Hee hospitalized and his son Lee Jae Yong as the heir apparent.

site_title: LionGold, Blumont clarify reports
summary: GOLD miner LionGold Corp and Blumont Group have issued clarifications regarding a story on the penny stock crash in October. The story, "Hunting for the Truth," alleges Malaysian businessman Soh Chee Wen as the ringleader behind the incident. The companies' stocks are under investigation by the Commercial Affairs Department for possible breaches of securities laws. The clarifications were issued in response to the article, which was published in The EdgeSingapore and The Edge Malaysia.

site_title: UK rejects 'Boris Island' airport plan
summary: The UK's Airports Commission has rejected the 'Boris Island' airport plan, which aimed to build a new major airport in the Thames Estuary. The commission, led by Sir Howard Davies, will now consider three remaining options to expand Britain's runway capacity, including plans to expand Heathrow and Gatwick airports. The decision is a blow to London Mayor Boris Johnson, who had championed the 'Boris Island' plan. A final recommendation is expected by summer 2015.

site_title: Singapore PMI contracts for first time this year
summary: Singapore's Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) contracted for the first time this year, falling to 49.7 in August, down 1.8 points from the previous month. This marks the largest retreat since March 2011 and the lowest reading since December last year. The decline is attributed to lower levels in new orders, inventory, and stockholdings of finished goods, indicating a slowdown in the manufacturing sector. The contraction in PMI dashes hopes of a sustainable recovery in manufacturing this year.

site_title: Japan pact unmasks Modi's growth ploy
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi completed his 100th day in office with a $34 billion investment agreement with Japan. The pact is part of Modi's broader growth strategy, which aims to cut similar deals with China and other countries in exchange for investment dollars and local jobs. Modi's government is struggling with a cash-strapped economy and bad loans, presenting an opportunity to absorb foreign capital. However, challenges lie in cutting bureaucratic red tape and improving the investment climate, with a track record of business-friendly governance in the state of Gujarat offering optimism.

site_title: Credit Suisse fails in bid to dismiss suit by S'pore wealth client
summary: Credit Suisse Group AG has lost a lawsuit by a former private wealth client, Koh Kim Teck, who claims the bank's Singapore unit failed to explain the risks of a complex investment product. Koh sued for $26 million, alleging the bank gave him insufficient time to raise collateral after he suffered losses from derivatives in 2008. The Singapore High Court rejected Credit Suisse's bid to dismiss the case, ordering the bank to present a defense by September 11. The bank claims the lawsuit is frivolous, as the relationship was with Koh's company, not his personal capacity.

site_title: Draghi's QE stance impacts Australia mortgages
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi's shift towards quantitative easing has led to lower Australian mortgage rates, boosting domestic demand. Relative yields on Australian financial debt are at seven-year lows, trimming mortgage rates and aiding the Reserve Bank of Australia's efforts to rebalance growth towards domestic demand. The move is expected to continue, with traders pricing in a 7 basis point reduction in the cash rate over the next 12 months, despite economists predicting no change when the central bank meets on Tuesday.

site_title: Margins 'halved' for new condo launches
summary: Developers' profit margins for new condominium launches in Singapore have halved from last year, according to a Knight Frank study, dropping to 5-10.3% due to government cooling measures. This contrasts with margins of 15.6-22.5% in 2013, when the market was hot. The study focused on 99-year leasehold sites acquired through the government land sales (GLS) programme. The decline in margins is attributed to the cooling measures, which have subdued the market.

images.alt_text: Developers' profit margins for new condominium launches have halved from a year ago, a focused study by Knight Frank suggests - PHOTO: WORLD CLASS LAND

site_title: At the top of the world
summary: Singapore's port has topped a survey of 46 major ports and cities, beating London, Hong Kong, Rotterdam, Hamburg, Dubai, and Shanghai. The port's success is attributed to its efficient operations, strategic location, and favorable business environment. The top 10 global shipping centers are predominantly in Asia, with five locations, followed by three in Europe, one in the Middle East, and one in the US. This recognition highlights Singapore's position as a premier maritime hub, but it is advised to approach such reports with a critical perspective.

site_title: Asia stands out as alternative safe haven
summary: Asian currencies are strengthening as investors seek safe havens due to geopolitical tensions and US monetary stimulus withdrawal. Seven of the region's 10 largest economies posted current account surpluses, with South Korea's won and Malaysia's ringgit leading the gains. Asian countries are favored over Latin American and European economies, which saw deficits and shortfalls, respectively. The Bloomberg JPMorgan Chase & Co Asia Dollar Index rose 0.6% in August, its biggest monthly advance since October, with investors expecting higher rates in the US and a stabilizing Chinese economy.

site_title: Hotel Clover to open hotels in Shanghai and Bangkok
summary: Hotel Clover, a Singapore-based hospitality brand, has announced plans to expand into Shanghai and Bangkok with two new hotels. The Shanghai hotel, set to open in 2015, will feature 320 rooms and is expected to have an occupancy rate above 90%. The Bangkok hotel, opening in 2016, will have 359 rooms. Despite declining tourist arrivals, Hotel Clover CEO Teo Kok Hwee believes the brand will thrive locally due to its unique character and niche market focus.

site_title: China's PMI falls from 27-month high in Aug
summary: China's Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) fell to 51.1 points in August, down from a 27-month high in July, indicating continued weakness in the economy, mainly in the property sector. The drop was attributed to weakness in output, new orders, and employment. Economists warn that the shallow growth recovery may be losing momentum due to structural problems in the economy, and risks remain in the property sector. The government has already implemented targeted easing measures and is expected to take further steps to support growth.

site_title: Telcos urge EU to rein in Facebook, Google
summary: European telcos Vodafone and Telefonica urge the EU to focus on regulating Facebook and Google, citing concerns that network neutrality proposals will hurt their business and stifle innovation. The carriers argue that internet companies' dominance will control what applications are developed and used by consumers, while Vodafone CEO Vittorio Colao warns that network neutrality could hinder the development of new services like driverless cars. In contrast, internet companies have advocated for stricter rules to protect the free flow of traffic on the Web.

site_title: 68 golfers to take part in Boustead event
summary: Boustead Singapore is sponsoring the Boustead Golf Open 2014, a professional golf tournament featuring 68 golfers from Singapore and the region, from September 2-5 at the Raffles Country Club. Top-ranked Singapore Professional Golfers' Association golfers, including Koh Deng Shan and Lam Chih Bing, will compete in the three-day event, followed by a Pro-Am tournament.

site_title: EDB launches pre-project innovation initiative
summary: The Economic Development Board (EDB) in Singapore launched the Pre-Project Innovation Consortium (PPIC) initiative to facilitate innovation in the building industry. The program brings together developers, architecture firms, and technology companies to conduct research and development (R&D) on sustainable building solutions. Two consortia have been confirmed, focusing on retail and healthcare use, and are working with companies like Asahi Glass and Bosch. The initiative aims to develop new technologies before deployment, aligning with EDB's vision for Singapore as a "living lab" for innovation.

site_title: CDFH has wealthy in mind in AmFraser bid
summary: Taiwanese merchant bank China Development Financial Holding Corp (CDFH) is set to acquire AmFraser Securities for S$38 million, gaining a securities licence in Singapore and expanding into the wealth management business. CDFH aims to capture the cross-border capital flow potential and target individuals with S$500,000 to S$3 million in investible assets. The acquisition will allow CDFH to become a full-service lender and broker, leveraging its existing risk management practices and infrastructure.

site_title: ASME spreads its wings with 2 big projects
summary: The Association of Small and Medium Enterprises (ASME) has launched two major projects, a cloud-based platform and a code of fair tenancy practices, to support Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The cloud-based platform, expected to be rolled out in 2016, will offer functional processes such as accounting, HR administration, and customer relationship management. ASME aims to qualify the programme by industry and hopes to push it out to 12,000-15,000 SMEs within the first 6-8 years. The association is also working with other organizations to develop sustainable practices and greater transparency in rental rates.

site_title: New CEOs for CapitaMalls Asia, CapitaLand China
summary: CapitaLand, an Asia real-estate giant, has announced new CEOs for two units following the departure of Lim Beng Chee. Jason Leow, current CEO of CapitaLand China, will assume the role of CEO of CapitaMalls Asia on September 15. Leow will replace Lim Beng Chee, who is taking a personal sabbatical and will leave the company by the end of the year.

site_title: GIC, Brigade to invest S$309m in south Indian property sector
summary: Indian developer Brigade Enterprises and Singapore's GIC have agreed to jointly invest S$309 million in residential real estate projects in south India. The investment will focus on acquiring land and building homes and mixed-use projects. This move is part of sovereign wealth funds' interest in India's real estate sector, where property prices have been declining due to the country's slow economic growth.

site_title: Global Yellow Pages in ice-cream business deals
summary: Global Yellow Pages has agreed to buy intellectual property rights, including recipes and formulas, from Wendy's Supa Sundaes and Innovation Ice Cream for A$10 million. The deal aims to expand the ice-cream retail business in Asia, particularly in China. The acquisition is part of Global Yellow Pages' strategy to diversify its business and invest in the food and beverage sector. The deal is expected to boost earnings per share, but net tangible assets per share will decrease.

site_title: Taiwan's first budget airline set for maiden flight
summary: Taiwan's first budget airline, Tigerair Taiwan, is set to launch its maiden flight on September 26 with a route to Singapore. The airline, a joint venture between China Airlines and Singapore's Tigerair, plans to introduce 12 A320s in three years and expand to other routes in Southeast Asia and Japan. This move taps into the growing demand for cheap travel in Asia, where 12 foreign budget airlines already operate services to and from Taiwan.

site_title: Norwegian Cruise said to be near US$3b Prestige Cruises deal
summary: Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings Ltd is in advanced talks to acquire Prestige Cruises International Inc for around $3 billion, giving it access to luxury cruise ships and affluent clientele. The deal could be announced as early as this week, pending negotiations. The acquisition would give Norwegian Cruise access to Prestige Cruises' eight ships traveling to various destinations, and its owner, Apollo Global Management LLC, owns a 20% stake in Norwegian Cruise. The deal is part of the growing US$29 billion cruise industry, expected to benefit from the rise of the middle class in emerging economies.

site_title: GIC joins 2 lead investors to fund North Sea oil firm
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund, GIC, is investing in Siccar Point Energy Limited, a North Sea oil-and-gas exploration and production company, alongside affiliates of Blue Water Energy and Blackstone Energy Partners. The initial investment of up to US$500 million makes it one of the largest private equity investments in the North Sea oil sector. The new company will focus on resource-rich waters surrounding the UK, marking its first venture.

site_title: CaixaBank to buy Barclays' Spanish ops
summary: CaixaBank, Spain's third-largest lender, has agreed to buy Barclays' Spanish banking operations for approximately $1.1 billion in cash. The deal includes retail banking, wealth management, and corporate banking businesses, adding 270 branches and boosting the client base by 550,000 to over 14 million. The purchase follows Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria's acquisition of Catalunya Banc earlier this year, as Spain's economy experiences growth. The deal is seen positively by analysts, adding affluent clients and expanding CaixaBank's presence in Madrid.

site_title: Macau casino revenue falls for third month
summary: Macau casino revenue declined 6.1% to $3.6 billion in August, its third consecutive drop, due to China's anti-graft campaign curbing high-stakes gambling by VIPs. The decline was worse than analysts' estimates, with casino shares falling. The number of visitors to Macau remained steady, but the mix of lower-end gamblers increased, while efforts to shift tables and attractions to attract more mass-market visitors failed to keep pace.

site_title: DBS beefs up transaction banking management
summary: DBS Bank appointed John Laurens, an industry veteran with 30+ years of banking experience, as head of global transaction services (GTS) on Nov 10. Laurens, currently HSBC's Asia-Pacific head of global payments and cash management, will oversee the business across 19 Asia-Pacific markets. He succeeds Tom McCabe, who will relocate to the US to head the DBS franchise. The move is part of DBS' strategy to build a regional leading transaction banking business.

site_title: China house prices fall at slower pace in August
summary: China's home prices fell at a slower rate in August, decreasing 0.59% from July to an average of 10,771 yuan (S$2,200) per square metre. This marks the fourth consecutive month-on-month decline, but the rate of the fall is slower than the 0.81% recorded in July. Local governments have loosened purchasing restrictions to prop up sales, contributing to the slower decline.

site_title: Rare 1962 Ferrari sold for record US$38.1m
summary: A 1962 Ferrari 250 GTO Berlinetta sold for a record-breaking US$38.1m at the Bonhams Quail Lodge auction in Carmel, California. The sale more than doubled the previous record and is part of a surge in classic car prices, with the US$400m total sales from the Monterey peninsula auctions, a 28% increase from last year. Experts say the market may be in a bubble, but others believe the values are rational, driven by rarity and provenance. The Ferrari's sale has sparked debate about the next great asset class, with some questioning whether classic cars will reach the same value as art.

site_title: Yudhoyono to be conferred Order of Temasek (First Class)
summary: Outgoing Indonesian President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono will make a state visit to Singapore from Tuesday to Thursday, marking what is likely to be his final trip before stepping down. He will be conferred the Order of Temasek (First Class), Singapore's highest honor for a foreign leader, on Wednesday. This visit comes as Yudhoyono prepares to hand over power to a new president.

site_title: Overseas debt load piling up for China builders
summary: Cash-strapped Chinese developers are borrowing a record amount in the offshore loan market, adding to their highest debt loads since 2005. They secured US$5.9 billion from foreign banks, with builder debt reaching 128% of equity. This comes as new home prices fell in July in almost all cities tracked by the government, and developers are missing sales targets. The high leverage on their balance sheets poses a financial burden, increasing the risk of trouble for builders if presales are not met.

site_title: Air France back in the air after strike costing 280m euro
summary: Air France has returned to normal operations after a two-week pilots' strike that cost the airline an estimated 280 million euros. The strike, which inconvenienced nearly one million passengers, did not achieve significant concessions from management, and analysts predict that the airline will likely report a sixth consecutive year of losses for 2014. The pilots' delay in Transavia's European expansion plans may force Air France-KLM to rely more on intercontinental and premium-class services, potentially relegating the airline to second-tier status in Europe.

site_title: Further consolidation seen for S'pore market in near term
summary: Singapore's equity market is expected to continue consolidating for 3-6 months due to a global slowdown and regulatory changes, according to China Development Financial Holding Corp executives. Despite this, the country's strong fundamentals will pay off during a recovery. The market consolidation is evident in low equity trading volumes.

site_title: More efficient energy use in commercial buildings
summary: Commercial buildings in Singapore have become more efficient in their use of electricity over the past five years, with a 14% increase in annual electricity consumption despite a 20% growth in gross floor area. The Electrical Utilisation Index (EUI) improved by 5% from 333 kWh/sq m to 316 kWh/sq m, with benchmarks for four commercial building types - offices, hotels, retail buildings, and mixed developments. The improvement is attributed to environmental sustainability standards and data submission by building owners since 2013.

site_title: Global search for best young violinists
summary: Singapore is set to host the first-ever Singapore International Violin Competition (SIVC) in January 2015, featuring the best young violinists worldwide. The competition will be held at top concert halls and will include performances with the Singapore Symphony Orchestra. The winner will receive a $50,000 prize and a chance to perform with the London Philharmonic Orchestra. The competition is backed by key partners, including the National Arts Council and the Singapore Symphony Orchestra, and is seen as a way to position Singapore as a beacon of artistic excellence in South-east Asia.

site_title: MAS, SGX seek feedback on bond framework
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Singapore Exchange (SGX) have proposed changes to a bond framework, aiming to give retail investors better access to bonds. The proposed "seasoning" framework would allow retail investors to buy bonds initially offered to institutional investors after six months, with safeguards in place to protect retail investors. The framework also allows issuers to sell retail investors additional bonds without a prospectus and capping re-tap offers at 50% of initial size. The changes aim to improve retail access to simple investment products with decent returns and diversify wealth management portfolios.

site_title: What do retail investors really want?
summary: A recent surge in interest among retail investors in Malaysia's penny stocks has contradicted efforts in Singapore to attract similar investors, despite stricter measures to prevent speculation and bubble inflation. In Malaysia, the introduction of new rules has led to increased liquidity and attracted retail participation, with some stocks experiencing significant price gains. This has raised concerns that regulators in Singapore may have gone too far in reacting to the 2014 penny-stock crash, and that retail investors may prefer less regulation and more speculative trading.

site_title: Grand treat for six lucky golfers
summary: Six lucky golfers participating in the SPH's World Golfers' Championship final game on Oct 7 may win a luxurious meal at the Grand Mandarin. The event also offers a chance to represent Singapore in South Africa in November.

site_title: UK must back single hub airport to ensure growth
summary: The Confederation of British Industry recommends that the UK supports the development of a single hub airport, such as London Heathrow, to ensure long-term economic growth and lock in essential trading links to emerging markets. A single hub can boost trade by £128 million per year, serving almost three times as many destinations as point-to-point airports. Expansion of Heathrow over Gatwick is favored, with a third runway expected to add 40 new destinations and 122 routes, while a new hub in the Thames Estuary would be the most expensive at £65 billion.

site_title: MAS must be given every chance to succeed
summary: Malaysia Airlines (MAS) has effectively declared bankruptcy through a restructuring plan, creating a new company (Newco) to hold assets and liabilities. The plan includes cutting thousands of jobs, renegotiating contracts, and potentially swapping debt for equity. A single parliamentary act is required to push through some changes. The airline announced a loss of RM307 million in the first half of 2014, totaling RM750 million for the year. Khazanah Nasional, the 69% shareholder, has spent over RM7 billion on the company since 2001. MAS needs a drastic but necessary solution to survive.

site_title: Maples Fund Services unveils HK and S'pore acquisitions
summary: Maples Fund Services has acquired the Hong Kong and Singapore operations of Vistra Fund Services to enhance its leadership in fund administration. The acquisition, the company's first, brings Vistra's Asian fund services business into alignment with Maples' existing Asia business. With US$47.5 billion in assets under administration, the deal is expected to further solidify Maples' position as a market leader in the industry.

site_title: OCBC rights issue attracts strong interest
summary: OCBC Bank's fully subscribed rights issue attracted an overwhelming response, with 749 million rights shares representing 171.5% of the available 437 million shares. The issue price was a 25% discount to the closing price of S$10.20. This is the highest subscription rate for a rights issue in Singapore, surpassing the 132% subscription rate of OCBC's 2005 one-for-five rights issue. The successful issue will raise S$3.37 billion for the bank's S$6.2 billion acquisition of Hong Kong's Wing Hang Bank.

site_title: Company briefs
summary: Croesus Retail Trust acquired a Tokyo shopping mall for 11 billion yen (S$131.8 million), a 5.2% discount to its independent valuation. Olam sold its dairy processing plant in Cote d'Ivoire for US$18.7 million and assigned its "Pearl" trademark for US$6.3 million. WWMG, an associated company of SPH, was disposed of for S$400,000. STATS ChipPAC's talks with JCET remain at a preliminary stage, with another interested party terminating its approach.

site_title: GIC buys stake in UK roadside rescue business from Carlyle
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC is buying a majority stake in the UK's second-largest roadside rescue business, RAC, from Washington-based private equity firm Carlyle Group. The deal, expected to be completed by year-end, will see both parties co-owning the firm, with RAC Management holding the remaining shares. Carlyle's plan to float RAC in a £2 billion transaction is no longer on the cards. GIC and Carlyle will own an equal share in the firm, marking a strategic investment in RAC's growth potential.

site_title: Shipping alliance approval by US a formality: Maersk
summary: US regulatory approval of a proposed shipping alliance between Maersk and MSC, known as 2M, is expected to be a formality, according to Maersk CEO Nils Andersen. The alliance, set to start in early 2015, will run 185 shared vessels on critical trade routes and aims to cut costs, fuel usage, and emissions. Despite initial opposition from China, the deal is expected to receive automatic approval from Chinese, EU, and US regulators if no objections are filed.

site_title: Hewson's acting boot camp
summary: Eve Hewson, daughter of U2's Bono, stars in the Steven Soderbergh-directed period medical drama "The Knick" as Lucy, a young and naive nurse. Hewson praises her co-star Clive Owen for his professionalism and warmth, despite a scene where she injects him with liquid cocaine. She describes working with Soderbergh as "boot camp" due to his fast-paced directing style. Hewson, who has also appeared in indie films like "This Must Be The Place" and "Enough Said", relishes playing the role of Lucy, which is the opposite of her personality.

site_title: Next target: Building owners and tenants
summary: Singapore's third Green Building Masterplan aims to improve energy efficiency in commercial buildings by changing the behavior and practices of building owners and tenants over the next 5-10 years. The plan, launched at the International Green Building Conference 2014, focuses on working with end-users to adopt more sustainable practices. The goal is to achieve 80% greening of built-up area by 2030, and Minister for National Development Khaw Boon Wan stated that Singapore is "on track" to meet this target.

site_title: Raffles Medical net profit up 49% at $84.9m
summary: Raffles Medical Group's net profit surged 49.3% to $84.89 million in the 12 months ended Dec 31, 2013, driven by higher revenue and a gain from the disposal of a subsidiary. Revenue increased 9.4% to $340.99 million, with hospital services and healthcare services growing 12.4% and 6.2% respectively. The group recommended a final dividend of four cents per share, and its directors expressed confidence in the group's pipeline of growth, particularly in China.

site_title: London Sinfonietta soars and scores
summary: The London Sinfonietta's six-concert series, "Listen To The 20th Century," showcased 21 groundbreaking works by composers such as Debussy, Schoenberg, and Stravinsky. The series, held in collaboration with the Southbank Centre and the Yong Siew Toh Conservatory, aimed to challenge classical music lovers with avant-garde 20th-century music. The concerts featured expert talks and performances by the London Sinfonietta, with notable solos by John Constable. Despite its enriching content, the event was poorly attended, with few people turning up to provoke and challenge their musical tastes.

site_title: Tanjung Langsat Port to sell Johor storage terminal
summary: Malaysia's Tanjung Langsat Port is selling its 100,000 cubic metre storage tank terminal in Johor, with at least five companies shortlisted for a second round of negotiations. The terminal may be sold with an adjacent 15-hectare piece of land. The sale is seen as an opportunity to tap into rising oil demand in Asia, with oil pricing agency Platts proposing to include Malaysian ports in cargo loading points. The terminal has been empty since a fire in 2008, and negotiations could take around three weeks.

site_title: S'pore-Okinawa charter flights set for takeoff
summary: Singapore and Okinawa will see 14 direct charter flights between Changi Airport and Naha Airport between September and January, with SilkAir and Jetstar operating the services. The flights will cut flying time to about 5 hours, boosting tourism and trade between the two destinations. The memorandum of understanding signed in March aims to develop a scheduled passenger service between the cities in the future, with the goal of establishing Okinawa as a hub for Japanese businesses and travelers in Southeast Asia.

site_title: Boeing struggling to sell early 787 Dreamliners: sources
summary: Boeing is struggling to sell its early 787 Dreamliner jets, valued at $1.1 billion, as two airlines dropped orders for the holdover models. The partially completed planes, known as the "terrible teens," have been parked for four years due to issues with suppliers and manufacturing. Boeing is upgrading the jets, which weigh more than new models, and is targeting bargain-hunting airlines in Asia, where they could be sold at a discount. Experts estimate the jets could be sold for around $100 million each, significantly lower than their original list price.

site_title: Henderson to spend HK$6.5b on retail complex
summary: Henderson Land Development Co plans to invest HK$6.5 billion (S$1 billion) on a retail complex in Hong Kong's Tsim Sha Tsui area, beating 17 rivals in a land tender. The complex, set to be completed by 2019, will feature retail, services, and dining spaces, as well as a public carpark. Henderson won the site for HK$4.7 billion, the highest bid. The project will be located in a district with luxury brands and hotels, including The Peninsula.

site_title: Corrections
summary: A corrections notice was issued for an article regarding a bungalow up for auction in Singapore, correcting the address and auctioneer. The article was published on September 11, 2014.

site_title: BOJ upbeat on economy, leaves monetary policy unchanged
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) left its monetary policy unchanged, sticking to its official line that the Japanese economy is recovering "moderately" despite a second-quarter slump caused by a consumption tax hike and sluggish exports. Despite growing concerns about meeting its 2% inflation target, the BOJ maintained its stance, with sources indicating that further easing may be considered if inflation shows signs of easing back from its current annualized level of 1.3%. The BOJ's decision comes as the government prepares to consider a further planned rise in the consumption tax to 10% in October 2015.

site_title: Globe-trotting polyglot
summary: Paul Theroux, a renowned American author, is set to appear at the Singapore Writers Festival, discussing his life and work. A polyglot and award-winning travel writer, Theroux has written extensively on various genres, including travelogues, novels, and science fiction. His fascination with travel is driven by a natural curiosity and a desire to explore the human experience. Theroux's writing process is centered around discovery, and he emphasizes the importance of exploring subjects and emotions rather than technical subjects. He will also discuss humanitarian assistance and his 1979 film adaptation, Saint Jack.

site_title: Allure of old Burgundies
summary: A recent tasting of old Burgundies showcased exceptional vintages, with some wines still at their peak after 36 years. The Domaine Lamarche's 1978 Vosne-Romanee Premier Cru Malconsorts and Domaine Trapet's 1978 Chambertin Grand Cru stood out for their complex and youthful flavors. In contrast, Domaine des Varoilles' 1978 Gevrey-Chambertin Premier Cru Clos des Varoilles showed signs of aging, while Domaine William Fevre's 1990 Chablis Premier Cru Montmains aged remarkably well. The tasting highlighted the potential for old Burgundies to remain drinkable and enjoyable for years to come.

site_title: Big boost from M1 for modern dance here
summary: M1 has become the title sponsor of the T.H.E. Dance Company's Contact Contemporary Dance Festival for three years, starting this year's edition. The festival, which will run from November 27 to December 13, will feature six new works, 45 technique classes, and collaborations with artists from Korea, Japan, Malaysia, and the Philippines. The festival aims to promote contemporary dance in Singapore and the region, and M1's sponsorship provides financial stability and validation of the festival's vision.

site_title: Becton Dickinson to raise production profile in Asia
summary: Becton Dickinson, a medical technology firm, plans to manufacture more than half of its products in Asia over the next decade, with Singapore as its base. The company aims to become a "real device leader" in the region, driven by increased government expenditure on healthcare needs, particularly in China. BD has grown its business in Singapore from a single manufacturing facility to a US$1.5 billion industry with 1,200 employees. The company will focus on global talent development and testing solutions in Singapore, a "living laboratory" for healthcare innovations.

site_title: New IIF risk index sends warning signal
summary: The Institute of International Finance (IIF) has launched a new US Market Risk Index, warning investors to be cautious ahead of a potential US Federal Reserve interest rate hike next year. The index, which measures stress in financial markets, reflects growing uncertainty and suggests investors should be more cautious. The IIF notes that equities are outperforming bonds, the dollar index is rising, and portfolio capital flows from advanced to emerging markets have slumped, signaling a possible "turning point" in emerging-market investment.

site_title: Skill up to keep Singapore competitive
summary: Singapore's competitiveness is being eroded by high property costs and labour shortages, according to recent reports. The country remains strong in infrastructure, policymaking, and fiscal management, but faces challenges in attracting and retaining skilled labour. The lack of a skilled workforce and restrictive labour regulations are major concerns, with employers struggling to find trained technical staff. Proposals for a stronger dual vocational training programme may help address these issues and keep the economy competitive.

site_title: Xpress unit in tie-ups with UPS Singapore, SF Express
summary: Xpress Holdings has partnered with logistics companies UPS Singapore and SF Express to expand its services, including value-added documentation and tracking services, to enhance its end-to-end business services for clients. The collaborations are expected to provide greater convenience and extend services to more customers, particularly retail customers. The company also sealed reseller arrangements for corporate gifts and premiums. Xpress expects a positive financial impact on its topline for the next financial year, following a significant loss in the previous year.

site_title: Companies urged to build risk challenge culture
summary: A report by the Association of Chartered Certified Accountants (ACCA) and the Institute of Management Accountants (IMA) urges companies to build a risk challenge culture by rewarding employees who raise concerns about perceived risks. The report found that corporate cultures that prevent employees from questioning risks can only be changed if management leads by example and becomes more sceptical. Key areas to design and implement a risk challenge culture include diversifying the board's skills, recognizing cognitive biases, and conducting thorough risk analysis. The goal is to encourage scepticism and reward employees for challenging decisions.

site_title: Volvo mounting German offensive
summary: Volvo is expanding its premium car line-up, unveiling a new XC90 and plans for a new model every year for the next six years. The Swedish carmaker aims to reach 800,000 global sales by 2020, up from 500,000 annually now. The XC90, the first all-new car since 2010, boasts improved craftsmanship, environmental credentials, and connectivity features. Volvo's breakthrough entry-level V40 model in 2012 allowed the brand to attract new customers, paving the way for its expansion in the premium segment.

site_title: Star 360 a shoo-in to be global player
summary: Star 360 Holdings, backed by Temasek, is poised to become a global player with plans to expand its physical and online presence. CEO Andy Chaw aims to be a dominant player in three years, with a focus on connecting with young people through new retail concepts. The company is also in talks with major brands, although names are not disclosed. With recent investments, Star 360 is set to enter the next phase of growth, positioning itself for a significant role in the market.

site_title: MD of Magnus Energy Group resigns
summary: Magnus Energy Group's managing director Lim Kuan Yew, 55, has resigned to pursue personal ventures, effective Sept 30. This comes months after the company's former executive director Koh Teng Kiat stepped down amid a Commercial Affairs Department probe into false trading and market rigging allegations. The probe also involved the impounding of Koh's and CFO Luke Ho Khee Yong's passports. CFO Ho will assume Lim's duties and responsibilities as interim CEO.

site_title: Manhattan's Trump Soho facing foreclosure
summary: The Trump Soho hotel-condominium tower in Lower Manhattan is facing foreclosure due to its struggles to find buyers since its sales began in 2007. CIM Group, a Los Angeles-based investment firm, is planning to take control of the building and auction off the remaining condos. The 391-unit building, developed by the Sapir Organization and Bayrock Group LLC, has recorded about 122 completed deals, but 58 units remain unsold, with prices ranging from $915,000 to $50 million. Experts attribute the building's struggles to its high price per square foot and high carrying charges related to hotel services.

site_title: Staying ahead
summary: Companies must reassess business direction and improve operations to keep up with the demands of the new economy. Meanwhile, Royal Healthcare plans to open a specialist centre in Tokyo or Osaka after Japan's Sojitz takes control. Researchers at NUS have developed a startup aiming to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel. In local news, Hao Mart's Taste Orchard faces poor footfall and vacant units, while OCBC targets S$5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028. Shatec has shut its Orchard campus and training restaurant, cutting 42 staff, and putting the building up for sale.

site_title: First hike in postal rates in eight years on Oct 1
summary: Singapore Post will increase postage rates starting October 1, the first hike in eight years, due to rising costs and declining mail volumes. The rate increase will generate S$16 million in revenue annually, with 75% going towards infrastructure and staff investments. Domestic mail postage will rise 4-20 cents, while international mail postage adjustments will range from 5-25 cents. The postal service provider is also investing S$100 million in infrastructure and staff to boost productivity and service standards.
